During a recent trip to Hartford we decided to visit the famous Mozzicato bakery everyone's been raving about.  To our dismay they did not live up to their reputation.  I'm sure this used to be an amazing shop but the service we experienced was appalling.  The food wasn't edible though the cookies were mediocre at best. This bakery relies on their outdated reputation for business.  I didn't drive all the way to Hartford to be treated like a smelly hobo for lack of better terms.  I'd have better food and service at a Stop and Shop bakery counter.  The employees at this shop should all be fired!

We love it here!  Great place to take children (but up steps and small - not great if you bring a bunch of big strollers).  They do have a high chair.  The children are treated so sweetly by all the staff.  My daughter and I love to watch them stretch and shave the noodles right in front of the diners.  The staff will make a chop sticks trainer for your little ones to learn.  They taught us some words in Chinese and even helped me make a little cloth bib so she wouldn't mess up her outfit slurping up her favorite shaved peanut noodles - they are her favorite Asian twist on mac and cheese.  They put the scallions on the side without the bat of an eye.  I have tried many of their dishes and soups - love them all.  Great in the winter too - they pack up their food very well - never had a spill in the car when doing pick up.  If you are looking for something that looks sparkling clean no hair out of place, Chinatown in general is not for you.  But if you are adventurous and a foodie - this place is not to be missed.
Extremely delicious. Soo recommend!!

I love Swine! I was set on returning to one of my faves to enjoy a little  holiday dining with a good friend.  Swine did not disappoint!  As a matter of fact, I was once again swept off my feet.  My friend and I shared the Potato  Chips Nachos for a starter and it was delicious.  For my entree, I enjoyed the Bone Marrow & Brisket burger. This is hands down the best thing in the world! Orgasmic, if I may. It just melted in my mouth with a burst of yumminess. It's SO GOOD! Reasonably priced for the quality of food.   Swine also offers a full bar with tasty cocktail options and a formidable wine list. Reservations are recommended but you can always kill some time on the free pinball machine while listening to some great tunes if you find yourself waiting. I can't say enough about how kind and cordial the owners are as well.   Definitely go check it out!

It's rare for me to say I "love" a Japanese restaurant because I don't really eat all-things-sushi, if you know what I mean.  But Ocha has won my the little tastebuds I have that savor Japanese flavors. A friend and I came here on a whim.  She saw Ocha had good reviews on Yelp and that they has sushi pizza.  I've had sushi pizza with this very same friend before, and it was good.  But this sushi pizza at Ocha that everyone keeps talking about puts the other one to shame.  You have the option of salmon or tuna.  I chose tuna for us (obviously!), and we were oh-so-happy with this decision.  A healthy portion of fresh tuna is arranged on a crunchy, round crisp of goodness topped with things like seaweed, sesame seeds, avocado puree, and "spicy" kabayaki sauce.  FYI I'm not a spice fan and this was not in the slightest bit spicy!  I could have eaten another one of these by myself. For entrees, my friend got the Dancing Queen and Banana Tempura rolls and enjoyed.  I got a Chicken Tempura roll and Alaskan roll and requested the Alaskan roll to be cooked, like I always do.  Our server didn't mind fulfilling my request (some places flat out say "no").  Loved both my rolls.  The Chicken Tempura was freshly cooked - lightly battered chicken breast with, I believe, a panko crust.  The Alaskan roll was perfect and delicious.  Not too much rice on the rolls AND the rice stayed perfectly in tact when picking up your rolls with your chopsticks.  Last but not least, everything we ordered was truly pretty to look at. My friend and I have these dinners only once every other month, so when we see each other, we talk for hours.  Our server was super patient and did not bat an eyelash when we were the last patrons in the place.  We didn't realize everyone had left until it got really, really quiet lol.  We appreciated this so much since you know very well, other places are happy to let you know when it's time to go home. Ocha, thanks for a wonderful meal!  Highly recommend this place to sushi enthusiasts and sushi-ehhh-ists alike! p.s. It's BYOB and there is plenty of metered street parking.

I suppose that a restaurant review should start with the food, so let me say that it is absolutely amazing fare.  Vernick, Fiorino, Zahav, Talula's Garden - none of them can hold a candle to this place.  The burgers are melt-in-your-mouth.  The Firebird Chicken Sriracha is the best food in Philadelphia, and the lobster and crab patty beat anything that you'll find in Maine or Maryland. But it's not only the food.  It's the atmosphere.  The artisan design is reminiscent of the Sistine Chapel.  The servers are akin to choirs of angels singing down from the heavens, and the owner has personally cured cancer, created world peace, ended hunger and saved kittens all on his day off.   I would eat there every day if I could, if only to witness the miracles that are PYT.

Wonderful, affordable and friendly Thai restaurant. We love this beautiful little Thai place with great food and friendly service. We have never found it particularly crowded, have wondered why. We love their fish options.

Wow, I really liked this place. A couple girlfriends and I headed over here last Friday around 8 p.m. It's relaxed and casual, offering both indoor and outdoor seating. As far as the long wait goes- there was one, but we gave our number to the girl at the desk and headed next door for a drink at another bar. The Farm's bar was packed. Only one drink down and we got a phone call that a table inside was ready, so we took it. We actually had a chance to try three fish dishes- char, trout and Pollock. All of them were really great, although I had never had char before and thought it tasted strangely like salmon. Typically, I shy away from the freshwater taste of trout, but the Farm did it well because I actually liked the fresh grilled and filleted piece. The Pollock stood out as my favorite, as it was light and sweet and smothered in a pureed carrot sauce and topped with some sliced pea pods. YUM!
Awesome Pizza!  Best Margarita Pizza ever.

As an outsider I must say that both Pat's and its friend across the street are top notch for the traditional steak sandwich (each with their own twist).  I prefer not to choose sides and simply recommend to try them (both).  One more bit of advice, the servers are sometimes abrupt (almost rude) but that is just how this place is.  Don't take it to heart and enjoy your sandwich!

Went to the Elm Park Inn this past Friday night, haven't been there in over a year. Went with another couple who suggested the Elm Park Inn. The food was Ho-Hum and the service was less than average. I had broiled filet of sole, basically no taste, my wife had a combination fried seafood platter she said it was just not good. My friends girlfriend wanted to know what the vegetable was that came with the dinner, the waitress said steamed broccoli, steamed carrots came out Me and my wife had baked potatoes, they were hard and dry, I asked for butter and the waitress told me to look in the bread basket, their were two packets of butter there, not enough to help the dry hard baked potatoes. A nice "I will bring some more butter to the table"  would have been nice. Now I know why it has been such a long time since the last time I went to the Elm Park Inn for dinner. It will be a lot longer till the next time.

I read all the rave reviews and decided to go there last weekend. The dosas were not nice at all. The stuffing had lettuce and red bell pepper! Who puts that in dosas! If you want good dosas, I would rather go to Chennai garden! Those are so authentic and yummy!
Burgers and Men.  What more could a girl want?   Hooray... best time ever

Pros: Good food, Good Service, Free Shot of Tasty Vodka just before you leave Cons: It took an extremely long time to bring everything out. The restaurant wasn't that crowded. The appetizers 2 small salads took about 30 min to bring out. The Soup parts took another 15-20 minute, then there was another 30-45 minute wait for the main course. The food quality was good, i'm just at a loss why it took so long, i ended up sitting there like 2.5 hours each time waiting for the next thing to come out.

Awesome meat! Parking is tight. Good service. I normally get their fried rice, fresh diced vegetables (if they have it that day),  and plantain bananas first. Then I get their Top Sirloin (medium), Chicken Wings, and Beef Ribs. I've also tried their Chicken wrapped in Bacon and Lamb which are delicious but most of the times its dry. I just stick with the top 3 whenever I go there. And I get a soda to drink. I have to say they have the best Top Sirloin and the best Wings! Better than the other place around the corner which I got sick from eating their meat. I love how they grill their meat. It's natural and very tasty.
I went to Cafe Habana solely for their popular grilled corn on the cob and it did not disappoint... I find myself daydreaming about it every now and then! ; ) I highly recommend it to everyone!

I stopped here to buy a quick lunch. Besides remembering their name being mentioned on Yelp, I liked their "golden" sign and their large-enough parking lot. What can I say? I am a sucker for first impressions. I ordered their panini veggie sandwich. They put together pre-grilled veggies on top of focaccia bread and grilled it to give it some warmth.  It was pretty good, especially since I was quite hungry. But not the best sandwich I had. I will say that they did have many pre-cooked foods to choose from. I wanted to also buy some grocery while I was there.... The grape tomatoes looked good, but the price stopped me from purchasing it or anything else thereof. I walked out with just my sandwich, and with not even a drink.

This place has been around for 7 years but I don't hear much talk about it. It's surprising, considering their burgers are on par with a Corner Bistro or the like and no matter how played it may get, it's fun to actually be able to order a "Royale with cheese". I grow a sweet afro just thinking about it. Obviously it's not a Black Label from Minetta, but we're talking different genres here. It's some great bar food that's just the right size and won't leave you huddled and moaning in a corner. The bar itself gets a lot of light from the open storefront and outside patio in the back so it's pretty airy and pleasant in the warmer weather. The bartender was super nice and on top of everything. I heard they had some good beers but I stuck with a rum and coke this time. Maybe when I return, which I definitely will. Cheers!

Just had a wonderful business dinner there last night.  The bamboo covered booths are great for talking.   Great service and large portions.  Sushi boat for two and 2 speciality rolls and we were stuffed.  It is our regular place for our meetings.

I can understand being disappointed if you were to trek all the way out here for a sandwich, because it's always hard for something to live up to your expectations after a long ride. But if you happen to be in the area, then really this cannot be beat. It's cheap, and it's incredibly delicious. I'm all about the #1, my boyfriend loves the #3, and frankly you could polish off one of each before stopping to take a breath. Serious flavor explosion on a bun. That sounds like a retarded commercial, but I say it completely without irony. They make one of my absolutely favorite sandwiches ever.

I just had the spaghetti at Scarpetta. It was quite tasty. The only thing that threw me off the entire time I was eating the dish, was the fact that the spaghetti did not have the usual texture I would expect, al dente and starchy, instead each bite tasted exactly like Lo mien. Could it be?

Excellence!!!  My husband made reservations for our Anniversary on April 20th, let me start by saying that my experience was phenomenon! Starting from the hostesss to the manager they were great! They sat us by a romantic corner which was ready with a letter from Iron Chef Marc Forgione congratulating us on our Anniversary, then our awesome waiter Jason set us up with two glasses of the bubbly (tasty) as he told us about the menu....now we choose the tasting menu OH MAMMA MIA did he steer us right!! from the Frios Gras to the Lamb I wouldn't be able to choose which one tasted better then the next....the Chili Lobster with Texas toast was to DIE FOR!!!!...the Banana Jameson was so deliciousssss! as was the Strawberry sorbet, etc..Again this place made my night more special! I would of loved to meet Chef Forgione but I was happy no matter what! thanks to the staff at Marc's and my loving husband Joe!
It hadn't occurred to me at the time but I am Asian ... Perhaps in consideration of recent events, that better explains our treatment.

Honestly, I've had better burgers in other places in and around Philly. But they can make a pretty decent chicken sandwich and a nice cookie-skillet dessert. Other than that, nothing else to really write home about.

So delicious. Came here for brunch. The menu had a lot if great choices from conventional brunch to very creative spices and sauces. The service was great, everyone was very friendly and helpful. Definitely recommend the pastrami salmon eggs Benedict and the fresh house gelato dessert with fresh made rice Krispy granola, honey, and halva put through a cotton candy machine!
Racist? Standing. Waiting for a table. Polish guys come I  after me and they were seated before me! Speechless.

We were having a meeting, and our boss decided we should have dumplings at work, and so we got about 100 dumplings? $1 for 4 dumplings is a great deal, the dumplings were good and flavorful. Definitely one of my favorite spots beside Fried Dumpling Shan Dong in Flushing which is $1-5 dumplings!

Wonderful place to get a cheesesteak if you're on the way home from Center City.  Also the lines are shorter (than the joints in South philly) and the steak is just as good.  I feel my arteries clogging now. For someone who rarely finishes anything, I always eat the entire steak. No leftovers.

I think it is important to understand what the Corner Bistro is: an old school NYC dive bar serving really good burgers.   The package really works.  Now, it ain't fancy and it doesn't want to be. Stand alone I have had better burgers, but that's not it.  Note, it is not obvious a pure foodie who doesn't dig this type of atmosphere would like it.  Also, a few points to mention relative to other reviews: a) I sat at the bar so have no idea about table service complaints, b) At lunch was not crowded, and imagine late night experience would be completely different c) McSorley Dark was cheap, but original.   Best explanation to come to mind: Think about having a burger in a shopping mall food gallery and invert everything.
the food here isn't quite as good as at inoteca, but if you're in nolita and craving italian, you could do a whole lot worse.
A simple, well-cooked ramen! Thick chicken broth, a piece of seaweed, 2 pieces of char-siew, garnished with scallion & topped with chopped onions. Loved the garnishes & the thick broth.

This place is amazing. The line is long because the demand is high, and the demand is high because the food is EXCELLENT! and the price is CHEAP! I got 8 dumplings, a sesame sandwich, and a smoothie for $7! and it tasted like I should have spent $20+. And as far as the line goes, it went super quick and I only had to wait 5 minutes or so for my food. While in line, you can watch the whole process from beginning to end as the servers chop veggies and boil them and fold up the dumplings... The food came out piping hot, and my heart melted with every bite. I definitely can't wait to go back, and I encourage people to turn their heads towards the negative reviews on this page. Because this restaurant is simple, and is simply GOOD. If you want to get pampered and waited on, then go somewhere else. I'm sure the staff would appreciate that you do as well!

Manager out of line.  While attending the Passyunk Street Festival, we were stranded in a torrential downpour at around 3:30pm on Sunday July 24, 2013.  My wife and I along w/our 20 month old daughter stopped in Le Virtu in order to escape the rain.  After seeing highchairs and inquiring as to whether children were allowed, we were seated by the curly haired manager.  Mind you, there were 10 other customers,all seated at the bar, in the entire restaurant.   After receiving our risotto, my wife went to use the restroom.    On her way back to the table, she was standing directly behind the curly hair manager as he told the waiters that he was ready to kick us out as our daughter was crying at the time and for only a short time.  This was now 4:00, and a nearly empty restaurant. When the manager turned around and noticed my wife, he tried to play his comments off, and acted as if he hadn't said anything.     My wife returned to the table and informed me of the situation.  The waitress returned and informed us that the rest of our food was only a few minutes away.  That is when I questioned her re her manager's comments.  She acted surprised, but knew my wife had heard his wayward comments.   When the manager came to speak with us he rolled his eyes as if we had ruined his swamped Sunday.  He informed us that "He wasn't actually going to kick us out"(into the rain), and that he would "Give us a gift certificate for another day".   We politely declined, paid our tab, loaded our daughter into her stroller, and took a soggy walk back to our S. Philly abode in the down pour. Very unpleasant experience, would not return.

The food and service was excellent. The amount of food for the price we paid was amazing. We enjoyed the Taverna Chips for appetizer which are the deep fried zucchini and eggplant chips, yum! Also has the fried calamari, just as delicious. for the main course we enjoyed the atlantic salmon and the gyro plater, again the quantity and quality were excellent. Thanks for a wonderful experience.

Food: Went for brunch. This was my first time at Locanda Verde and the second time for my sister and bro-in-law.  Menu was nice, if pricey, but I wanted conventional breakfast fare.  I asked the waiter  whether he preferred the waffle, the pancakes, or the french toast (all dressed up versions of each).  He cautioned "not the french toast."  OK, pancakes it was.  My plate of ricotta pancakes topped with fresh blueberries and lemon curd looked like something from a magazine,  but each pancake was basically a sealed envelope of raw batter.  "Waiter, they seem a little undercooked"  "Oh no, they are supposed to be like that, they have ricotta." (completely indiscernible to the taste).   An hour later, I'm feeling sick to my stomach.  I can only imagine the gooey mess of raw egg that the french toast must be.  My sister's frittata was "uninspired" and my and my bro-in-law's uovo modena (poached eggs with hollendaise sauce) and pork hash was tasty but "nothing special and pretty hard to screw up."  The tab for the three of us with coffee but no alcohol was $75 before tip.  The fam, who as I mention had eaten there before say two times was enough, this place is not worth returning to, no matter what hype or PR DeNiro has bought for it. Service:  Hostess was a class-A bitch who gave us the once over at 10am and then tried to seat us us next to the silverware station in the back, despite the fact the place was nearly empty (and was still nearly empty when we left an hour later).  (We looked fine, we are all 30somethings in  in finance for chrisakes -- sister lives in Tribeca, I live UWS). Prior to seating us she, in front of us, bawled out the  'assistant hostess' who actually performs the act of seating guests for not following her instructions in seating the prior party (apparently this prior party also balked when they were thrown in the back corner and the assistant hostess seated them elsewhere without first receiving permission from her royal bitchiness.)  Our waiter was nice but I should have known when he steered me away from the french toast that he was in on the hustle and that we would have been better off just about anywhere else.   Conclusion: go elsewhere.
Simply put, one of the best restaurants I've ever experienced. Everything was perfect, the service, all the food the atmosphere and so much more!

Visited on our wedding anniversary in december and loved it! The atmosphere...very romantic (i should have asked for a light to see the menu..lol). I had ceviche for the first time and enjoyed! I ordered the brazilian shrimp stew for the final course (should have skipped the third course and got dessert). The stew was amazing! I'm sure i would have licked the bowl if i was in the privacy of my own home. Enjoy!

This place gets 4 for putting out one of the most ridiculous burgers I've ever had. Get this... Wagyu beef burger with Foie Gras and duck fat fries. I saw this on the menu and didn't even have to look at anything else. Who does this?!!?!?! Burger Baby. This all may seem very gimmicky, but it tasted amazing. It's almost like a heart attack in a bun, but you don't feel sick, slow, fat (well maybe fat), and lethargic after eating it. It was solid. A great bun, good beef (although I think any Great quality ground beef would have tasted just as good), foie gras (DUH!), duck fat, and beer. This is a combination for greatness. Would I have it every week? no, but once a year? Absolutely! I was honestly surprised to find something like this in Hartford.

We love this place since the day it opened in our neighborhood! If you think this place is great, imagine what it was like when it was brand new. The place was perfect perfect perfect it every sense from food, to service, to napkins, to cups, etc. Attention to details has gone down considerably since but it is still very good. Best time to go for dinner is Wen - Sat before 7pm (before the dinner rush) and for brunch on the weekends before 10am or after 1pm.
nothing phenomenal here, folks.
Fantastic Food and Service!!! A great place to go, for late night drinks. The Hanger steak and sea bass, that my friend and I had were cooked perfectly!!! I can't wait to return

wonderful place. Chef is a very modest but explosive culinary entite. i have been several times and basically only get my sushi and rolls from there. atmosphere is a mild , jazz cafe type mood with not much seating but if you have to wait it is so worth it. The New York Roll and The Incredible hulk are great Come see for yourself.I can basically swear that you will enjoy yourself. Oh bring your own alcohol. lol
it a very cozy place, the food its not bad and has fair prices.

Great find near bryant park. Wraps were delicious, including the chicken tikka and shrimp masala. Could use more diverse, less spicy options for kids, but menu was packedwith yummy choices for adults.

Went here for brunch recently, and it was really tasty. The food was terrific, and my friends and I had a great time. It got really crowded, though, so I'd definitely recommend getting there early or going with a reservation.

Good food, good delivery service. I ordered the Eggplant Parm sandwich and a Greek Salad. The salad was green, not iceberg yellow or white, which was GREAT! Feta was fresh, tomatoes were ok, olives were good. The Parm was fantastic. Melt in your mouth, from bread to cheese to eggplant. Not too much sauce, just enough cheese. Delivery was timely, friendly, and runs til late

Prices in restaurant higher than shown on the website. Service was adequate but one side dish came long after we got our meal. Steak was good but not worth the premium price. Expensive deserts nothing to rave about. Overall an average meal at an above average price.

My girlfriend and I have been here 4 times over the past year or so. Each time has been a good experience - we love the food (I now make a tomato, onion, pepper vinaigrette to go with my steak at home), the atmosphere is great (very intimate, nice decor), and we always seem to have fun at Samba (good vibes). We more or less order different dishes every time and have yet to be disappointed - one thing we do always get is the garlic shrimp appetizer...one of those dishes you find yourself craving. We can't wait to go back this spring and sit outside.
If you want authentic regional cooking this is the place to go!! If you want  chicken or veal parm stay home or go to Olive Garden!!
Overrated. $18 for a chicken tikka masala. Not very much food. Avoid.

This review is for their burgers and wings only. Tavern has their wings night on Mon and burgers on Weds. Their wings are meaty and acceptably spicy for a Korean-American who loves flavorful heat. Their burgers are the best in the area -- hand-formed, large patties, good bun and great sweet potato fries or onion rings. They skimp on the lettuce, tomato and red onion, but you'll live. I also like their salmon burger when I want something slightly "healthier." I doubt the patty is house made, but I like the tzaziki sauce that comes with it. Also, their craft beer selection has improved immensely, which is a draw for me. Overall, it's a good option for a night of drinking any warm night on their outdoor patio by the lake. If you want a place to eat burgers or wings in Hightstown, come by on a Mon or Weds.

This place is a tiny sandwich shop in the south end of Burlington and the sandwiches at Four Corners are penom and extremely unique-- every sandwich is named after a country and 'loosely' influenced by that country! I have tried quite a few of their vege options, but consistently go with either the Greek Artichoke or the Jamaican Avocado (I prefer to have it grilled on the French bread but the sourdough is also good). The crowd is almost entirely a local bunch since it is a bit off the beaten path and only has a sandwich board and no other external signs. It has a funky/junky decor that is quite eclectic but very well done. It's a small spot so would be tough for a group of more than 4 people and the parking is very tight in the small, shared lot, but definitely worth a small walk available parking on the side streets or nearby lots. They're open from 11am until 6pm. T-A-S-T-Y!
Really skeptically of this place when I first saw it but man they have some of the best quality fish and prices that are very affordable! Service is great and quick delivery!
tasty tasty tasty mac and cheese,fried chicken and tater tots a must. smoked  brisket was very good . home made ketchup and dill chive dip was a nice addition to the meal. friendly staff

I returned to Burger Baby for lunch today and was blown away yet again. They have a contest running right now where apparently, customers submitted there ideas for burgers, and the five best ideas are now available, and whichever gets the most votes (orders) gets a permanent spot on the menu. I think its running for the next three weeks. I ordered the "Triple Smoke," which was one of there specially-blended burger patties, seasoned with chipotle and paprika, and topped with avacado, bacon, raw red onion, cilantro and chipotle aioli. It was a fantastic combination. Another thing I love about the place is that they can take care of just about any special requests without a problem. I am low-carbing for a few weeks before my wedding, so I opted for the side-salad instead of fries, and asked for no bun. My plate came beautifully assembled, and it was probably the most delicious and gorgeous burger/salad I've ever eaten. I'm going back again soon for one of the other limited-time burgers.

Went to check out Room 55 last night with a few friends and could not have been more impressed.  The staff was friendly and informative.  I had the duck served with risotta squash and sauteed spinach.  I'm not even a big fan of duck but was looking to see if this dish would change my mind.  Mission accomplished!  I tried some of the roasted bone marrow and the strip steak rolls which were both excellent.  We passed on dessert but after seeing the reviews on dessert, I will be sure to check them out the next time.  Go to this place.  You will not be disappointed.

Sottocasa is an absolutely wonderful little space. The design is minimalist and not "over-designed" -- the tables are very basic, and the lightbulb's are those cool old edison bulbs.  To get to the restaurant you are basically going into a basement-type area (hence the name), and it feels like a cool little hidden away space.   The staff and owners are very friendly, and the menu echo's the design in its simplicity. We generally start with a meat and cheese plate (a little pricy but good) and some focaccia, and maybe a salad to round things off.  That is already pretty feeling, but the pizza is good enough where you'll definitely be eating until you burst.  This is true wood burning oven pizza. As a matter of fact, that is the only thing they cook anything with -- the wood-buring oven. The pizza goes in for like a minute or so, and them comes out perfectly charred -- a little chewy (in a good way) with that nice burnt flavor on the end of the crust. The cheese and sauce are top notch too. Because the cheese has a lot of moisture in it you tend to get a soupier/wetter pizza, like Keste, but that is a type of pizza that a I really like. It turns into a big, delicious sauce and cheese mess that's darn good. If you're up for something a little different, try the calzone.  It has ricotta cheese, which seems to be atypical, but it gives the calzone a really unique flavor (ie, different from Roberta's etc).  Of course the calzone crust is the same as the wonderful pizza crust, so you really can't go wrong. The beer and wine list is also good.  They have some funky Italian beers that will hit your wallet a little hard but are worth it in the end.

The food is superb and the service is good. The only reason I didn't put 5 stars is because their tea is bad. Just a regular tea bag with unfiltered water you can taste the chlorine.  Other then that one of the best Thai in queens .

very loud music. the pork bone soup base was very yummie. if you get half pork base and half mild or spicy its 15. but if you get just pork bone soup base its 20$. all items were very fresh. also at the end if you check into Facebook, you get free melon bars! :) on yelp it says if you check in you will get free fish skin but they didn't accept it. overall i enjoyed my time there and will be back soon.

Rye oh Rye didn't I go here earlier? I lived a block over from this place for close to a year and never once ventured in. I think I was scared away by the three dollar signs. Big mistake. Also, not really that expensive. Also also, if you think it's expensive, get over yourself (or leave new york) because being poor is soo 2000-and-late.* On to the meal. Starters: 6 Wellfleet oysters and a scotch egg. The Oysters: as the waiter described, they were very brine-forward. I realized I'd never actually just eaten an oyster straight up before (no lemon, no migonette) and damn was it tasty. If these oysters are on deck, get em. The Scotch Egg: it's a scotch egg if you're the kind of person who likes scotch eggs get this one. while you're at it, schedule a visit with your cardiologist because your scotch egg habit is likely killing you. Main course: Rib Eye and Long Island Duck Breast w/ Brussel Sprout side I split the 48oz Rib Eye with my Mom (we go hard). It was damn tasty although not as much meat as I was expecting. They did present the uncooked slab to us before preparing, which I thought was cool/unnecessary. Like would I reject the cut you present to me? "sub par marbling, take it back!" Brussel Sprouts - ohhh yaaaa My father had the duck, as is his custom. It was good, but I'm no canard-connoisseur. He was especially delighted by the charcoal flavor imparted on the meat. Apparently they pan sear it and then toss it on a grill or something. I can't really remember as I was fairly drunk, which brings me to the drinks. Drinks: The Old Fashioned (not a hand job for you South Park dorks, the drink) It was good. Served with one large ice cube, which is aesthetically pleasing but functionally disappointing--more booze, less ice. Ice cube issues notwithstanding, it got me drunk. Yayyy! So four stars for that. *If you are poor, the happy hour sounds like fantastic deal ($5 old fashioned's and bugers) And, real talk, I'm totally poor too so I'll probably be back for that.

The first time I went to Sang Kee, I tried their duck noodle soup. I hated it. I had a duck noodle soup at their Reading Terminal Market location weeks before and disliked it, so I thought I would give this University City location a try. But it turned out I still disliked it. A year later, I decided to give Sang Kee another chance. Perhaps I just dislike bone-in duck. So this time I ordered the beef brisket noodle soup. It was not the best I've tried, but passable. It came out fast despite the restaurant being packed on a Saturday night. My boyfriend's beef chow fun was really good. The dumplings, however, were way too greasy. I then tried papaya with snow fungus for dessert. I really liked it. It wasn't too sweet. Sang Kee seems to be a hit-or-miss for me overall.

Perfect brunch on a snowy Saturday morning. We braved the snow an drove from Bayside and Forest Hills. We got lucky with parking and with claiming the last 4 person table when we arrived :) Service was prompt and friendly. The dining space in the back of the restaurant is a little tight but I'm sure it's better in the warmer months when some people can sit out on the outside patio. Anyhoo, no kidding, you get free carrot cake on your bread plate! Mmm.. We each ordered a different item from the menu so that we could try different things. We got the duck hash, pulled pork sandwich, pancakes, and the slow cooked pork w/rice and beans. You can also get a side of the spicy salsa which was great with the duck hash and slow cooked pork plates. Everything was fantastic, and you don't get overly stuffed from the meals unless you eat more than what you're served! I really liked the pancakes too. They were so fluffy and delicious. The pumpkin seed butter is pretty unique, and I liked the blackberry jam too. They also don't rush you to get out when you're finished with your meal. I'm sure that they would have liked for us to give up our table but we were just busy catching up. They were nice enough to fill our coffees and water and enjoy the atmosphere a bit more :) I highly recommend it. It's a lovely little joint in the heart of LIC.

I can't say enough good things about this place.  The sushi is great, and service is the best in the city.  If you're looking for a friendly sushi/bar restaurant with friendly staff and patrons look no further than Zento!

There is something original, sincere, and authentic about this place.   The food tastes just like the food I had in Puerto Rico.  The food is cook very well and taste authentic.  The servings are huge and the prices are cheap.   The place looks like it haven't changed since the Eisenhower administration.  There seems to be alot of history here remnant of another era when the area was a heavily Hispanic neighborhood.  The old cabbies and locals that inhabit this restaurant reminds me of a forgotten era in NYC history.   Now if they would just deliver.....

I've been meaning to come here for quite some time, mainly because I saw on their menu they had Mast Brother's hot chocolate and I've been on quite the hot cocoa kick as of late. We came on a Sunday for brunch around 1pm and had to wait about 15-20 minutes. They seated us at a communal table with a couple other groups. Boyfriend started out with some coffee which was a tad bitter. He ordered the Biscuit and Grits and I ordered the Gouda Grilled Cheese. Our food came out within 20 minutes. My sandwich was amazing! What a wonderful blend of savory (cheese), salty (black bean hummus), sweet (guava jam) and spicy (jalapeño). Yum! It also came with a side salad with a very light jalapeño vinaigrette. Boyfriend's meal came as a plate filled with grits, with a fluffy biscuit, sunny side up egg and 3 asparagus stalks layered on top. His was definitely more of a buttery cheesy comfort food breakfast - he said he liked my sandwich better because it had more flavor. On the way out, I got a hot chocolate to-go and to say I was disappointed is an understatement considering it's the main reason we came to this place. I was expecting a thick, rich chocolatey treat, but it was more like hot milk with a sprinkle of chocolate mixed in. So sad. Overall, this is a cute place with good food but I'm not a fan of the coffee or hot chocolate. Maybe their cocktails are better. I'd be willing to try again.

I really hate it when someone says, "I'm from NYC [or Jersey], so I know what real pizza tastes like." I think pizza is a personal thing and my favorite could be your worst and vice versa. Now, with that said, believe the hype that surrounds Lombardi's. Lombardi's pizza has a perfectly thin crust that is crispy on the exterior and chewy on the interior; well-balanced sauce; and generous toppings. I made a mistake by opting for meatballs because I found the meatballs to be a tad stale-tasting, so I would suggest crumbled Italian sausage instead if you're a carnivore. Prices are a tad steep, but that's predictable for a NYC pizzeria that boasts about being the first establishment, ever, of its kind. This pizza tastes excellent the morning after as well. Just saying. I'll be back.
I gotta say, there's every reason not to like this place it's a NY chain - but they make a great burger. Better than 5 Guys.
Great Banh Mi!!! It's probably the best I've had in NYC.

We went there on Saturday July 26th for Dinner after not wanting to wait on line at another restaurant. My wife sat at the table and were not attended to for about 10-15 minutes much to my dissapointment. Finally, a waitress came around to attend to us. She informed us that they were out of ice and bread however we were served warm water. How does a restaurant run out of ice and bread? I ordered a salmon dish with spinach and potatoes. The salmon was lacking flavor as were the potatoes. The spinach was disappointing. The place itself needs to be maintained better. There were tissues, napkins and straw papers scattered throught the dining room floor. The bathroom was horrendous. If they aren't maintaining the floor and the bathroom in a cleanly manner which is visible to customers what about the cleanliness of the kitchen? The signs were there and I should have gone with my gut and left. Dirty floor, staff members visibly bickering with each other and a manager foldking napkins instead of attending to a restaurant. Finally, upon my arrival home I became VERY ill. Needless to say, I will never go to Leone's again!!!

I work a couple of doors down from this place. I went there for New Years Eve last year. The place was fairly empty, which I loved! I dined in the main dining room and the food was decent. The rooftop is really nice although I don't know how it is after hours.

PAN FRIED NOODLES with beef.  That is my go to dish here.  The restaurant is very clean and the staff is very friendly.  If you are new to the area and looking for some good take out.  This is your place.

I tried mancinni's and another new place in clifton. To each his own, but their sauce and consistently top quality keeps me in love with their pies! And im with lauren ( previous reviewer) , call me a pig, but one pie per person is a minimum ! So good!

Went here for brunch a few months back and wasn't too impressed. We were three people and have to wait more than half an hour to be seated. Of course Sunday might not be the best day to go but oh, well.   Their food is decent, except for their seafood, which made my stomach sick several hours after. If you are looking for Latin-inspired cuisine and you happen to be in the area, sure, drop by. Or try out the other restaurants just around the block. The Slope has a variety of cuisines to offer and this happens to not be on my Top 10 list. End of story!

Going to visit your son in Philly requires the cheesesteak thing so where better to get the immersion experience than Passyunk Ave where you find both Geno's and Pat's. We chose Pat's. The fare is about typical PCS which is as good as that specialty gets, but the other fun feature of the visit was the faux abuse we get when the order taker detects our southern accents when we say "wit" indicating the inclusion of onions and white cheese. Of course we have to counter abuse back which results in the employee coming out to join us during his break and have a big time joking around. All in all a memorable time at an iconic American fast foodery and the steak was as good as any.

On a recent business trip to New York, the weather went from 100's and humid, to thunderstorms and lightening, and then to cold and rain. Needless to say, I craved a bowl of hot ramen. To avoid the long lines, I avoided the lunch crowd, and went straight after work at 5pm. I was by myself and seated right away at the counter. This place is small. Can only seat about 20-25 people at a time. You will get seated faster, if you have a small group. I ordered the Miso Ramen with extra char siu pork, and for an extra $3.50 got 2 smoked salmon onigilly (rice balls). Sitting at the counter, I got to watch the 2 guys behind the counter preparing all the food. There is no kitchen. Just 2 guys that probably speak very little english making your food right there. I was very amused by them singing to the american hip hop music they had playing in the background. What is also amazing is how they prepare the pork. Thin slices that they char with with a small torch, right before it is served to you. The broth in my ramen was delicious. I drank ever last drop. The pork was so flavorful, I almost wish I ordered more. The onigilly was ok. Not enough salmon in it for my liking. The reason why I only gave them 4 stars is because the noodles were a little bit more al dente then my liking. I'm sure if i just let it sit in my bowl of steaming hot broth a few minutes, it would have been fine, but I ate that ramen so fast, it didn't have a chance. If you love ramen, you must try this place.

I can see why a lot a people like Buvette ,the place is really cute .what didn't work for me was the menu (very small), the portions (very small) and price pretty high. the food is pretty good but leave you a something missing.

We live right around the corner and we make our own wine but for some reason had been completely overlooking/forgetting about this little BYOB. The other night we went for the first time, and I'm sure we'll go back again, although if there were another BYO as close as Robertos...  maybe not? The restaurant is small and really really pleasant. We were sitting on a two-top right next to another small table but it wasn't close enough to be uncomfortable. The servers were super attentive-- uncorked our bottle right away, refilled our glasses before we realized they were running low, and cleared just about every plate off the table in one quick scoop. I just really felt like they wanted us to enjoy ourselves; they weren't just going through the motions. The food was good but not magnificent. I would recommend it to others for sure, but I'd never say it was the best or a must-eat-there kinda place.  We ordered bruchetta & mussels for appetizers (both really good), followed by two small pasta dishes (I had whatever pasta comes with zucchini.. it was really mellow/light and an excellent small portion, just enough to get me ready for the main course. He ordered something with a red sauce... it was clearly a little bit forgettable). We had chicken & tilapia for entrees... both very good but not excellent. They were cooked well and neither was dry but they both had this same tangy flavor.. maybe it was a similar sauce? Too much tangy-ness, anyway, not enough of a variety of tastes. They both came with a plate of side veggies...   just some potatoes & zucchini, both seemed dry & bland.    For dessert, he got the cannoli (it's small, just be prepared for that and don't get too excited) and I got the tiramisu. oh my.... soooooooooooo good.     Now that I think of it, I think I'd like to just go back to bring my wine & eat more desserts.    Overall pretty pleased though!  The lobster ravioli that I saw on the menu is stuck in my mind to try next time.

Dining in the atmosphere is pleasant and the service is prompt. The staff is very friendly. Delivery is very fast. The pizza is excellent - BBQ chicken rules! If dining in, the sweet potato fries are great (they get soggy in the package when getting home delivery). I'd recommend Ziggy's over any other pizza place in the area.
Really good gnochi and pasta. Wine is great too. I had an amazing dinner with some friends here.
It's a good one!

Ate here last night, was able to get seated around 7pm immediately (there were 4 of us). I had a cappuccino with whipped cream and cinnamon which was delicious and warmed me up right away. The pizza was delicious as well! I forget the names, but I ordered a pizza with mushrooms, olives, ham, and artichokes - YUM! The crust was crunchy and I loved how I could really taste the smokey-ness from the brick oven. Would definitely come back/order takeout from them again!

I have been checking this place out on a regular basis over the past 6 months. It's got a very upscale, chic, and trendy look, and quite a nice feel. The food is genuinely good and surprised me by how much I liked it. In particular, the Gulf Shrimp w/ vidalia onions. The service has differed. During the happy hour it gets pretty full, so it should come as no surprise that the service deteriorates a little bit, but the serving staff is very likable and try. That leads me to the flip side of this 'restaurant'. It gets loud on Thursday and Friday due to a DJ at night. This is far from a bad thing. For once it's not some horrid DJ playing the same thing I hear on the radio 20 times a day. One day they play mostly house and older funky music, and the other has another guy playing a great mix of everything. The bar staff is also super friendly. Definitely shocks me we have a place this cool in Hartford. Usually have to go to NY to find a great food and equally great night scene too.
This was the perfect place for an evening drink and dessert. Loved the mojitos and molten lava cake. You can't beat the view or location either. We had a great time.

My wife and I like Greek food, so we tried this place. We really like the design of the restaurant. The service can be hit or miss, but I can tell the food is fresh. It is great for the location. Considering how long they have been in the neighborhood I think it is also a testament to the quality of food.
Really need to work on customer service.

I came here in September for my boyfriend's surprise dinner with a reservation. The restaurant was located in the South of Williamsburg, right across the Williamsburg bridge. The atmosphere was perfect- intimate, romantic, and casual. There was an open kitchen (fragrant aromas traveling around) , indoor seating, and an indoor garden patio. We were seated in the indoor garden patio, which was decorated with shimmering lights. Our waitress was very friendly and explicitly explained what each of the mouth-watering items on the menu entailed. We ordered several of the tapas, the local mozzarella with pomegranate and yogurt, crispy pork belly, seared scallops with butternut squash, crispy glazed confit wings,sweet potato fries with sliders and the amazing bacon donuts. Let's say all these dishes are to die for. The mozzarella infused with pomegranate and yogurt was a delicious twist on the conventional fruit and cheese dish, the seared scallops were tender and greatly accompanied by the sweet and subtle tastes of the squash. My boyfriend had the bacon donuts as his birthday cake. He loves bacon, so the thought of bacon and donuts harmoniously concocted into what's called the bacon donut was exciting enough. I recommend that those who are heavier eaters should eat something before or you might be still hungry. We ordered around 7 dishes and we still left a bit hungry, hence unless you're willing to pay the price, be prepared. It is on the expensive side, tapas ranging up to $17. However, it is definitely worth it, and is a MUST try list if you are ever in the South of Williamsburg.

I usually eat at Fornos. I wanted to try something new I read so many good reviews about Fernandez so I wanted to give it a try. For starters I ordered calamari as an appetizer that wasn't good it was very rubbery, and for my meal I ordered the tile ribeye and shrimp that was delicious. I have mixed review on this restaurant. If your looking for good steaks this is the place for you. The rodizio is ok the meats are little salty. Service was just ok could have been a lot better for the 500.00 bucks we spent on our meal. For me Fornos is a lot classier has better service and you get a lot more food portions for your money and their garlic shrimp and rice is to die for. So if your looking for an elegant restaurant this is not the place for you. But if your looking for steaks this is the place. So with that being said will go again only for the tile steak.

This is the first time I have ever written a review.  My husband and I were celebrating our 42nd anniversary.  It was also The Taste of Hartford.  We were served our drinks and then proceeded to wait 35 minutes to be served our appetizer.  Which I had to ask for.  We also had to ask for our entree.  The service was terrible.  Everyone around us were served.  It was such a disappointment.  Our waitress also brought out the wrong dessert.

Hola Amigo! That's what I like to hear at an "Italian" Pizzeria. "Quiero Pizza, por favor," I said to the all the Spanish speaking pizza makers that work here. This tourist trap is not exactly authentic but what can you expect in the heart of the theater district? Not good pizza, that's for sure. I knew something had to be up when I read so many great reviews for this place that was situated in such a heavy touristed area. It said open at 7am so i thought "Great. I can get a pizza early in the morning to conform to my odd work hours." I know there are tons of pizza places, some 24hrs, that flip pies round the clock. Nope. Not here. This joint was open early but there was no pizza to be had. Why call yourself a pizzeria if you aren't going to serve pizza during all your hours of operation? Why would anyone in their right mind buy a bagel or breakfast sandwich from a pizza place? Not somebody from around here, that's certain. I decided to come back later in the day to sample this four star pizza. Good things come to those who wait. Nope. Not here. I ordered a regular cheese slice, which they had to toss back into the oven. I couldn't put my finger on it but there was something not right about the cheese quality. It didn't really taste like mozzarella at all but rather a cheaper substitute. Que lastima! I'm not surprised. One thing tourists may not like is that ample seating, bathrooms, and climate control are pretty much non-existent in this tiny place. There's a few wobbly stools and counter about 5ft from the pizza oven, but that's about it. This pizza might be good for some if they happened to have spent most of their money on Porgy and Bess tickets, but if you are looking for real NY pizza, keep on walking.
I keep going back for the $2 sardine sandwiches & hear there may be an outdoor patio in the works.
Do Not order delivery. They claim they do delivery but they SUCK. an hour and 35 minutes to get food from 5 blocks away. ICE cold. Do not order delivery.

so when I first was taken here by my buddy, he said we are going to a panini spot and I was like really? I was hungry so i obliged. He sez to me its not your average sandwich spot- Anyway the crostinis are amazing - all of them really! I tried them all :) The paninis are toasty and heaven on a plate. The beer specials compliment any dish you order. Definitely check this place out- enjoy it.

What a delightful restaurant!  With its relationship to Dell'Anima, one expects superb service, fantastic food, and an excellent wine selection.  L'Artusi doesn't disappoint. Service seems very smooth considering how short a time they've been open.  The food was sublime.  There's an octopus appetizer that will suprise and please even unadventurous patrons.  The pasta dishes we tasted were excellent - the orrecchiette with sausage and bitter greens was delightfully spicy.  The spaghetti and meatballs is getting very popular, the server told us, and we could see why.  One dish - the tuna entree - included melt-in-your-mouth tuna, but an unidentifiable sauce.  Fortunately, there was no real need for the sauce.  The food on the plate was better off without it. Dessert is as you would expect.  Creative, delicious, with some incredibly delicate and some powerful flavors.  The Olive Oil Cake was to die for. Without wine, dinner was entirely reasonable; the addition of drinks would bring it to 'spendy!'

Pylos has become the benchmark for quality Greek cuisine in NYC.  All aspects of the dining experience are superlative: food, decor and service.  However, Pylos is still able to maintain an ambiance of casual elegance.  I cannot say enough about the wonderfully prepared meals that have been served on several visits, over a year's time.

The best gourmet diner / restaurant experience, with great food and great employees. The only downfall is you may become addicted and as a result will never settle for less and become overly critical of other diners. P.S. if you look like George Eads you get a free vanilla waffle.

If I could get a table here more often, I'd give it five stars but every time we try to drop in (we live close by) or even make a reservation a few days in advance they are booked. So they end up being a special occasion place when we are able to book far enough in advance.  Once we tried to get a table at 6pm. When we walked in we were told there was no room even though there were 8 open tables. I guess they were all imminent reservations.   That aside, it's some of the best Italian food in the city. I won't repeat what has been said here. But the food is outstanding.  It's also a great and reasonably priced place for a group party if you plan it ahead with them. We had far more food than we could have finished and everyone had a great time. Only other gripe is we can't even get take-out from there when they don't have tables because "the kitchen can't handle it." My husband and I joke that we'd pay good money to have a regular table there! Enjoy!

I don't know what self respecting establishment would be understaffed during a Friday night dinner service at peak hours.  Our party of 9 had reservations made for  6:45 PM. We placed our orders at 7:00 PM, but did not receive our appetizers until approximately 8:30 PM. Who knew that pouring salt, I MEAN, soup into a bowl took that long? We were there for a total of 3 hours, spending 80% of our time waiting...  AND it was not like there were a lot of people. Each of us made our selection for our three course meal from the prix fixe menu, priced at $30 per person. A deal you may think to yourself as you review the list; however, you should STOP and save yourself from the treacherous experience and long wait. (If you're on the way there now, turn around!!!! You'll thank me later.) Four people from our party (including myself) ordered the filet mignon medium well. We could not fathom the reasoning behind the inconsistency in each of our steaks. The side of spinach (or swamp goop)  tasted like I swallowed an entire pepper shaker. For dessert, I chose the chocolate "lava" cake which was more like an overcooked chocolate cookie. It was a mystery to all of us where the "lava" went. As previously mentioned by other reviewers, the owner was more concerned about his scarf rather than the satisfaction of his customers. He came to our table and asked our opinion regarding the service. We were all honest about how the food lacked quality in preparation and taste, but he was in disbelief and stated that WE probably did not order the steak correctly...  He can be in denial all he wants if his ultimate  plan is to lose his business. To sum it up: FOOD - 0 (Poor in quality unless your preference is burnt and salty.) ENVIRONMENT - 0  (Perhaps dark so you can't see other people's face of disgust or the piece of HAIR served with your steak.) SERVICE - 0 (I don't think I really have to explain myself again.)

Don't mix politics and food, we're here to eat, not be preached to.  Just left a bad flavor in my mouth.  Pat's may show less bling, but their welcoming personality was worth it for me... and their food tastes better at Pat's.

Kefi is awesome. I have been here twice: one time upstairs with a friend, and once downstairs with my parents. It almost feels like two restaurants, since upstairs the dining room is more sparsely decorated with light blue mosaics and downstairs is almost cave-like, with wooden tables and richer colors. The food, however, is overall great. First, the not-so-amazing: unlike most other reviewers, I'm not a huge fan of the sheep's milk dumplings. Something just seems 'off' to me, but maybe I just don't like heavy cheeses. The sauce is the same for the rabbit dish, which also just doesn't agree with me. Onto the amazing: The sampling of dips is the BOMB. Do not go to Kefi without ordering this. Seriously, plan to order more pita because you will want to finish each spread. The branzino is also delicious, as is the leg of lamb. The salads are also super fresh and distinctly Greek. I go to the UWS infrequently, but will make an effort to return to Kefi.
Bella Gourmet is the best pizza in the Central Ct area every one else is 2nd rate
best pizza in nyc

Mi wife and I love sugar freak. The deviled eggs are a must. Their Gumbo is delicious, and the hurricanes are sweet and tasty, but still pack a kick. I have also tried their chicken and waffles, it was good. The crawfish étouffée was outstanding! I recommend this restaurant to All my friends.

BEST pizza ever!! Great crust, solid sauce and well balanced between sauce and cheese.  I only go to Grimaldi's about once a year when I have guests in town- its followed by a trip to the ice cream shop and a walk over the Brooklyn Bridge. This place is totally a tourist trap and you have to wait in line for 45 minutes or so (on the weekends)... again, it is worth the wait but if you are a local, its pretty hard to convince yourself to wait in a line for pizza considering you like in a city of great pizza.

The rice and the lamb was so good that I went there twice in four days. The meat is tender and rice is fragrant. There was no line at 11 am. While you wait, there. Is a smoothie vendor who sells fresh fruit smoothies.

I went to Pies n Thighs a few weeks ago.  We were seated in the farthest-back room, which was pleasant and fairly quiet.  We were seated very close to our neighbors on each side, but it was during the dinner rush so it's understandable. I ordered the chicken biscuit, hush puppies, and a mimosa.  My friend ordered fried chicken with mac & cheese and beer. The chicken biscuit was divine, mostly due to the generous amounts of honey-butter and hot sauce that dressed the sandwich.  I am a wimp when it comes to spicy foods, but the honey butter made everything better.  The hush puppies were good, but the dipping sauce--a tartar  sauce, I think--was kind of carelessly splattered in one corner of the greasy basket instead of having its own dish, and the hushpuppies were kind of plain without it.  (They made an amazing drunk leftover later though).   I order the smores pie for dessert.  The taste was great, but it was very dense and very cold--as if it had just come out of the back of the fridge.  I would have enjoyed it much more if it had been room temperature or warmed up. Lastly, our server seemed very out of it.  She took our orders kind of lazily.  When she took the order of some people next to us, she sat down at the table with them to take the order.  Then she disappeared for a while and another server brought us our food and, later, the check.  Then our original server came back and gave us the check a second time.  Then we got up to pay at the register, and she came and gave us the check a third time.  Not sure what was going on with her but she seemed like she was either sick or high.   Overall, the food was pretty good but I think they need to focus a little bit more on service and presentation.
this is the place to go to relax while enjoying your drink. Excellent service. Really nice view, plus it's a restaurant! what else you're looking for? All in one place! Everything you're looking for.
I have been dying to try Lombardi's after I saw an episode on the food network channel. Well it did not disappoint!

People often ask what's so special about square shaped pizza. They're right, nothing's special about square shaped pizza, but an L & B's Sicilian pizza is mouth watering deliciousness sent from Italian pizza gods. I used to come here as a kid after soccer and I feel like this place is just 10X better as an adult. It's out near bensonhurst, so it's a trek for those living in the city, but well worth it.

This place is awesome. It doesn't get as much press as the other Garces joints (it seems like) but it deserves it. So European and relaxed, and the quality of the food and market items is high. We went for dinner recently and shared the deep-dish pizza and cheese plate (yes, we went on cheese overload). I've never been to Chicago but I love GTC's version of a deep dish pie. Not sure if it's authentic but I'll take it any day. And I love the extras that come with the cheese plate -- the honey, quince paste, yum!! We had a really awesome time here and think it's a great addition to the neighborhood. Hope it sticks around!

My husband and I went here spontaneously with another couple. We were seated immediately which was wonderful. It was slightly off that they don't give you the menus until they leave you sitting a while to review the wine and cocktails and you order something. We were hungry and not really there for cocktails. After a while I stopped someone to ask for a menu. We ordered wine with dinner. We went with the chef's meal for $65 per person. A little steep but it was being strongly recommended as worth it. Meh. The highlights were the bread with was actually too much bread (3times bread was brought out) a rustic Italian , a pumpernickel and then another white bread I didn't catch. It's not a basket but a presented plate with interesting butters like birch beer butter with the pumpernickel. Also excellent was the smoked pumpkin tortelloni. I could have curled up and purred. The food presentation on our appetizer and my companion's main course were questionable. The seafood salad looked like a picked over mess. Her  pork dish looked like an unappetizing heap of pink pork meat. She is pregnant so they were gracious and offered her the steak. Another highlight of excellence. Though another thing that was odd was when she voiced concern about the pork, they talked to us about how the creativity and inventive favors aren't for everyone. I was a little offended. We are all very experienced foodies. Bad presentation is bad. The skate was good, the Bronzino en croute was good though a little too heavy on the tarragon. And they brought out a kale salad so we had something to pick on while the late steak was served. It was nice though a little too heavy on the vinegar. Desserts? Also mixed. The chocolate cake and spicy fig ice cream was good. The apple pie was like potpourri. And the grape thing was like a melted grape Popsicle. The end thoughts are, I would go again for the pastas and a salad, but no chefs tasting. Way too much food that was also too random in taste and too expensive.   I miss Noble.

You can't judge this place by what you see on the outside cause until you eat a hot dog here, you don't know what a hot dog is! It's so greasy and good and genuine. I can feel it making it's way down to my tummy and I don't care how long it takes for it to digest, I LOVE THIS PLACE! Alot of people rag on Rutt's for not renovating or upgrading or changing up their appearance but these people don't even understand what it means to eat at Rutt's. You gotta judge for yourself. Good prices. Good food. It's just an overall chill place. Go with friends. Have a food fight. You won't regret it.

Paid a visit to Upstate last night on a quiet Christmas Eve Eve.  Overall, had a great time.  Service was prompt and spot on.  Great selection of craft beers...quite a few I haven't seen before.  Several tastes were brought out without hesitation.  Sadly all of the West Coast oysters were gone, but we enjoyed an assortment of East Coasts.  Scallop ceviche special was phenomenal.  Creamy, delicious sliced scallops with a nice crunchy topping of cucumber (i think).   Shrimp Caesar salad was solid...with 2 ginormous shrimp on top.  Linguine with clam sauce was excellent and loaded with garlic and very plump littlenecks.   Upstate will definitely become a regular spot for me...I look forward to returning!

First of all you must ready yourself to be eating in the lobby of the Circa Center. We ate under the escalator. It was a bit odd at first, but not a big deal. The idea of american tapas was very interesting. Between four people we had 10 dishes, even though the waiter recommended 4 for each person. I truly enjoyed how each dish came out by itself so that you could truly experience each dish at your own pace. I was not as impressed with some dishes as some others were (fondue, lobster cappuccino). But everything was interesting and quite enjoyable. Though it was a good thing they kept refllling the water glasses because the dished could be a bit salty. My palatte was really tired towards the end, but thats a good thing! Each dish was a great experience, but it would be a while until we go back unless the menu changed. I feel like I had the experience, it was great, but I am not itching to go back.
Taco Tuesday on Wednesday's for me!!! Taco's and all their sandwiches are amazing. Love the food and keep going back....

Osteria lived up to my expectations (which were high) and then some. I went there on a date and we both tremendously enjoyed our food. The only detractor was the proximity of other patrons. For example, when my meal was delivered my neighbor remarked on how good it looked. Friendly, yes, but not what I was hoping for during an intimate evening. If your goal is an intimate environment, I would look elsewhere. We ordered the fig pizza which was delicious. I read a previous review saying the pizza was sparsely topped, but I thought it still delivered on flavor. We shared an app of octopus which was very good and probably the best I've had in Philadelphia. For my main course, I ordered the roast suckling pig. It was very tender and juicy. On the whole the food was very good and what you would expect given the prices which are little on the pricier side. Another plus was the service. The wait staff was very knowledgeable and friendly. I would recommend this restaurant to anyone who is in the mood for something a little different and isn't afraid of going to north Philly to get it.

The food here is definitely fresh and delicious and while the service could have been better, it wasn't really bad.  We had to signal for the server's attention a bit, rather than being approached but when we signaled, the response was immediate. But what gives this place just two stars is that they don't turn on the AC.  I'm sorry, it's the dead of summer in NYC, the AC needs to be on.  They had the front windows open with two small fans on the sill blowing in.  The fans are the type you'd use at home.  All that did was blow the hot air into the restaurant and not even much of it.  There was another fan of the same type in the back facing the front.  If they are trying to save money by not using AC then they should at least have ceiling fans installed.  It was not even the hottest of evenings when we were there and it was still extremely uncomfortable.  Really blows the experience. We won't go back until the weather cools or perhaps if the front windows are closed we might step in to see if AC is on then.  The place only has the one exposure, the front, so there's no cross breeze.  Dog and Duck and Claret also open their windows and don't always use AC but at least they both have double exposures so if there's any breeze at all, it will be a bit better.  But even those places close up and run AC when it's very hot and humid. It's a shame about the heat because otherwise Venturo really is a unique little spot in the 'hood, nicer than most.  But being comfortable and not feeling like you're about to pass out in the NYC summer should be a no brainer.

I have nothing but love for PYT. Great food and drinks. Great Music. Great People. Great prices.  It's sort of like Cheers, where everyone knows your name. The staff is super-friendly, super-cool, and super-stylish. In the summer, it's the spot to BE because of the outdoor seating and the great location at the Piazza. The burgers of the week are PHENOMENAL, and it just has a great vibe. The grilled cheese is kind of amazing.  It's just the place to go for a drink, have a bite, and chill with friends. Who doesn't want to do that!

I work in the area and have lunch there at least twice a week. The steak is amazing and if you have gluten sensitivities there are plenty of options. I love all things Brazilian and this is defintitely the spot. I was so excited to see Guarana in NYC, I'm in heaven everytime I go. The place is clean and the staff is friendly. I recommend Copa to everyone.

Love love love Five Leaves. Great early in the morning for coffee/breakfast and in the evening for dinner. Everyone who works there is super friendly and the place is beautiful. Some of my favorite things to get are: the Sticky Date Pudding , Beet Ravioli and the Fried Oysters. So happy to have found it!

LOVE LOVE LOVE this place. The food, the service, the vibe, the place- everything is 5 stars. This is not a preppy place. There is line, you place your order and you pay. If you've ordered coffee you will wait near the counter and get it immediately. Then you're seating (they will mark your table with a headband) a d waiting for someone to shout your name and then you'll get the food. I love how casual is this place, make you feel totally welcome and home. The food, as I've said, amazing. Great sandwiches (take the arugula with cheese and pesto!!!) and the breakfast (Grey Dog Breakfast is massive and the waffle is the best) and their sweet potato fries are the best sweet potato fries I have ever had! And the coffee is also so good. The place is beautiful, looks like a cabin. The ambiance is great, full with hip-young people. Just go!!

I enjoyed my meal at Zento, but had trouble coming up with a reason to give a rating higher than 3-stars based on value.  Yes, the quality was good, but the portions were merely alright, and the prices didn't align with the overall package provided.  It should be noted, the friend who joined me for dinner was able to purchase a coupon deal on restaurant.com (while waiting to order) which saved him a small percentage off.  They have a good variety of specialty rolls and I have to give them credit for a tasty Sashimi Roll.  Unfortunately, while I can't speak for all their apps, the Rainbow Ceviche left a lot to be desired.  Again, overall the value didn't speak to me, but I could see myself back to give them another chance (with a restaurant.com coupon!).

This Vietnamese sandwich shop was the first I had gone to, and I'm still a devoted fan. Their selection is probably the widest out of all of the shops of its kind. Their price range is between $3.75 to about $6. And everything on the menu is worth it. If you go later in the day, the sandwiches though aren't nearly as fresh. Everything's already pre-bagged. And sometimes they definitely sell out. So watch out. It's also amusing that this shares space with a jewelry store.

Best of Philly is well deserved.  I'm going to cut right to the chase about other people's misdealings with this place as unfairly over-assessed.  Just because they can't take a credit card and the wait is a little long, doesn't mean the food, the staff, or the charm should be cast in a sub-4-star light. As some folks have very accurately described, weekends are tough on the hurried or ravenously hungry.  A 30-45 minute wait to sit at a table is perfectly possible, but in my opinion the spoils are worth the journey.  I suppose some folks show up without a smart phone, or without interesting enough company  to pass a short wait, and then flame the reviews without consideration for what it is that makes this place Philly's Best breakfast/brunch spot. The regular menu contains all your breakfast classics and a regular selection of frittata's that are loaded with fresh ingredients (and quite an untaking for even the hungriest patron).  The ketchup is a house recipe, so be sure to order a side of potatoes so you have something to put it on.  The biscuits and jam are a mainstay and we generally order 1 or 2 to go for the following morning. The specials change quite often, so its always worth swinging by to see what's new.  This past weekend I jumped on the Mango and Pineapple Belgian waffle with homemade  whip cream; it didn't even need syrup. A+ Jenny, who is the manager and responsible for most of the menu and specials assured me upon my request that she'd bring back the Pumpkin Brulee French Toast in the coming weeks.  I hadn't known the meaning of a good breakfast until I had it last year. Steak and Eggs is a good fall-back and their stuffed pancakes are heavenly.  The coffee is certainly worth a third cup ;) The lengthy wait is a function of the quality of the food.  The wait represents continued excellence and a very loyal and satisfied clientelle.

Some scumbag from Philly skimmed my debt card number and used it and this restaurant to the tune of $70. When I called to ask about the same, the manager basically told me to screw-off. What do you expect, this is philadelphia after all. If you use a debt or CC at this location, be sure to check your statement ASAP.
Great Soba. Possibly one of the best places to eat Noodles around St. Marks. Wait is almost always long but if you're a Japanese noodle fan you'll understand why.

All of the reviews and high praises have been given to Dom,  and his craft,  Been here a bunch of times,  living pretty close by...  and can sum it up like this..... AMERICA'S. BEST. PIZZA...    And it's not even close....

It's like the set of a college student film: heavy black curtains meant to evoke a sense of sophistication, but failing to cover the dorm furniture. There was a literal spotlight shining on our table so that we were required to shield our eyes. Molding has peeled off the wall, and everywhere you turn, the "sophisticated" atmosphere crumbles as quickly as a freshman-year romance. And don't be fooled by the prices--I think the servers must've run up the hill and loaded our plates at the UVM cafeteria. Not inedible, but not worth a dime.
Marc Forgione always surprises me. The food is really awesome and the service impeccable
Come here for brunch/dinner all the time. Order: avocado sandwich, veggie bibimbap, and bellini's. Photobooth downstairs is c00l too.
Hands down. This spot is the best place in steaks.  The location is off the beaten path but once you take your first taste you'll be dreaming about when you can get back there again. Believe it!

NEVER order take out from Red Barn Restaurant.  They simply get the order wrong.  It has happened multiple times.  I do not usually give reviews- good, bad or otherwise.  But, when I called to let them know, they hung up on me. Not how I'd run the business.

Love their curry! Every single person whom I've dragged in there loved it as well. Be prepared to get a bit disappointed though if you order shrimp curry. While shrimps are big, the small size portion only has 3 of them. I usually go with chicken, which they put a plenty of.
Excellent food with lots of choices - almost too many to choose from! Great for both group dinners or a date. Would definitely recommend to any of my friends.
Bomb! Hands down, 5 stars! The green tea ice cream is a must and the sushi is amaze balls. Deff going back again soon!!!

We had been shopping all day and forgot to eat dinner, so at 11pm, we hopped in a cab and asked him to take us somewhere nice for a nice snack before heading to bed.  This was it! Next time I'm in NYC I'll have to come here for dinner. Because it was so late we had the goat cheese appetizer as well as the beef tartar.  Yummy!   FYI-  I asked for the house cabernet and it wasn't that great, but everything else was.

I am absolutely obsessed with this place.  A friend of mine told me about it, and after I haven't been there for a month or two, it starts floating back to my mind. First of all, its location is gorgeous and picturesque.  The restaurant itself adds to this atmosphere - I usually can't stand small spaces, because I just feel like others' are on top of me and I can't even think straight.  Somehow, Gitane manages to keep it peaceful and cozy, as opposed to chaotic. And, of course, the food is to die for.  I have not eaten one even "okay" thing there yet.  It's my total go-to place for people visiting the city, and no one has ever complained!

I absolutely looooooved this place! The food was excellent and the drinks were fabulous. I had the salmon. It was flaky, buttery, and fresh! The portions were nice. I had this drink special with 3 different kinds of saki...Delicious. In my Arnold Schwarzenegger voice, "I'LL BE BAHCK!"

Came here because my friend loves this place. Environment is a clean diner, reasonable prices. Ordered a calamari salad - calamari was delicious with the lettuce and arugula. bananas were an interesting addition but were good. the only minus was paying an extra 1.50 for a very unripe avocado - was disappointed about this part, but otherwise good experience.
Goddammit!! Hands down the best pizza I ever had!! Fresh ingredients! Especially love the thin crust and the amazing cheese blend they're using.

I would agree with David T's assessment, and am giving Miles Table a 4 although I'd like to give it a 3.5. Our family went here a few weeks ago for brunch. The restaurant is clean and I really like how they fixed up the place; you can tell that there was a lot of thought to the decor and small details. The owner named the restaurant after his son and there are tasteful but adorable pictures of his kids around which gives you the sense that they take a lot of pride in their restaurant and that its a family affair. Coming from a family with dietary limitations, I think its great that they have gluten free options!
