This place is the absolute best. Great pub with great food and amazing people that make you feel like family. I highly recommend. Great place to bring friends and clients!
Love this place! The black sesame creme brulee is to die for, I loved the salmon toast as well, and the staff is friendly.

I love this place.  The all you can eat is a great deal ($20).  Unlike other places, where they make you feel like a criminal for getting all you can eat, here they treat you like a paying customer.  No stupid restrictions, stale food or long waits.   The sushi quality is good.  It's not exceptional or anything, but it's quite good.  The all you can eat selection is good as well.  You don't get everything on the menu, but you get a good selection of soup, appetizer, tempura and udon, most/all of the sushi and normal rolls, and a good number of special rolls.

cozy and awesome if you come early and get a seat at the bar. the artichoke salad is delectable and the chickpeas taste like bacon but fear not, vegetarians, it's the paprika!!!! (i asked!!) impress a foodie friend or date here.

If anyone is looking for homemade pizza with a great VT beer, Vermont Tap House is the answer!  We had the buffalo chicken pizza and it was absolutely delicious!  I highly recommend this restaurant and can't wait to have a second visit!

I love this place! Amazing food, prices and service. I live in the area and have come here many times for breakfast, lunch and dinner, and it's always been a pleasant experience. This place has to be one of the cleanest restaurants in manhattan, never seen dust cluttered in fans or vents like most other places. Great beer and wine selection. Highly recommend this cozy spot in the LES.

Oh, Midwood. There is not a single bar (trendy or otherwise) for me to go to here for an after-work drink... or ever. I can never go grocery shopping on fridays or saturdays because everything is closed for sabbath. And boys never talk to me here because I'm not orthodox, or even jewish. But all of that does not matter -- because midwood has DiFara's. I know it's been said but this seriously is the greatest pizza on the planet (of brooklyn). Since I live 10 minutes from here, I always take people to difara's and they are always really skeptical of the price/ambiance (or lack thereof)/and long wait. But after one bite, any doubts pertaining to my judgement of culinary establishments melt away from their endorphin-overloaded brains. The only thing that sucks is DiFara's close from 4:30-6 everyday, which is a pain in the ass when you're trying to get an early dinner during the week. But hey, i'm not gonna complain too much... I mean, Dom is fucking old, he needs a mid-day rest. I get it. Aaand, it was closed for a bit at the beg of the year because he was sick, so i'm glad he's feeling better.

I visited for my birthday with a few friends, they were skeptical about the idea of a southern restaurant, but i'm accustomed to southern food since I attended college in the south. I ordered the red velvet waffles and chicken and it was amazing. I love the atmosphere and the décor, I will definitely be having another birthday dinner here.

Great space, great atmosphere, and great potential all undermined by a pretentious, rude, unhelpful and just plain lousy waitstaff.  I don't understand, am I supposed to be glad that you're serving me?   I came here randomly to get a quick bite and wait for my friend before we went to see a movie.  When I sat at the bar, I asked the bartender if they have any special beers that they serve, and he just pointed at the menu and said "all our seasonal beers are here."  If I wanted to learn the menu of over 40 some odd beers, I wouldn't ask for your help in making a quick selection.  Anyway, I looked through the menu while he went to talk to his friend after his curt comment to me. Then I put in my order for food and a drink with him, during which he seemed, to say the least, indifferent if not inconvenienced.  After the minimal attention he gave me and my order, he of course went back to his conversation with his pal. This all makes me think of the beer that they drink on Futurama, LoBrau, except it seems as though the bartender think they serve HiBrau beer, which I suppose is their right seeing as they serve $13 sausages with it.  The sausage by the way was "aite."  The pretzel bun was way too small.  It was good enough for the sausage, but had no hope of holding the accompanying toppings together with it for a complete bite.  I would have expected more for $13. Finally, I asked for the check and the bartender literally, tossed the card on the bar, again, indifferently.   When I expressed my thoughts on this place to my friends who met me there, she also seemed to think the waiters were rude and snobbish, but I wouldn't take her seriously - she's a bit nutty. Well, now that I think about it, maybe it was my fault.  Maybe I hesitated in my selection.  Maybe I didn't wear the right clothes.  Maybe I'm not his friend.  Maybe I wasn't grateful or humble enough.  Maybe I'm Chinese and he's not.  Maybe I reminded him of his... dad?   To be fair, we only had the two bartenders at our bar - there are two bars - which was nearly empty compared to the bar on the other side.  The other bartenders might be angels, which would explain why the other one was full.  It could be that it was just our bald, hipster glasses wearing bartender that was unsavory. Wow, this review is getting long.  Anyway, I'll leave with this: I'm giving it two stars because of it's saving grace, the atmosphere.  I'm also giving the other bartenders the benefit of the doubt, otherwise I'd give it one star and steer you guys clear of it.  I also didn't come here with any expectations. If I came here for anything more than a quick bite, I would have been really pissed at the lack of attention and congeniality that I experienced.

From the friendly greeting to the delicious food, this was my favorite meal of the week.  I almost walked by, but the greeting was so friendly and warm, had to stop in.  I ordered the Jerk BBQ chicken and they adjusted the heat. Also ordered a side of vegetables, which at the time of ordering was advised that there is already rice/beans, cabbage and plantains. Should have listened. There was so much food. Couldn't even begin to finish it all, but made a pretty good dent as it was hard to stop eating.

We've become frequent fliers at Yama for their delicious Korean fare, which is a rarity in the Upper Valley. (We've never tried their Japanese offerings.) We love the Bulgoki, the Mandu dumpling soup and the hot stone Bi Bim Bap.

Great food, great atmosphere.  Really, the atmosphere is what sets this place apart.  You just have to go there to experience its funky vibe.  It's awesome. About the food. . . Getting one of their guacamole offerings is mandatory.  The guac is made fresh, and there are several different kinds.  We got some kind with heart of palms and some other stuff in it and we were licking the bowl.  The chips that come with it are fresh and thick. . . perfect for scooping up guacamole. As an entree we split the taco sampler plate.  Here's the low down, the chicken and pork tacos are very forgettable.  The chicken is relatively flavorless, and the pork has some major overkill on whatever is flavoring it. The mahi mahi taco is good.  The beef taco is better than average.  What really did it for us was the Chilean Sea Bass taco . . . SO GOOD!  We savored every bite of that taco. If I were going back, I would get any of their guacamole variations together with the Chilean Sea Bass tacos.

Delicious food...so many flavors and nuances. Balanced and beautiful. Did the tasting menu and really got to experience a good portion of the menu. Service was very good. Atmosphere was dark. Vibe was hip but not too hip. Going back to eat at bar near open kitchen when we return to phila.

Came here on a Saturday afternoon, right in between the lunch/dinner rush, and was sat promptly with no wait.  The bar area is beautiful, although tiny.  The boyfriend and I were sat somewhere way in the back near where they were baking the pies, I didn't mind, although it felt like it was last resort seating area. The service was nice and kept checking in on us to see if everything was ok.   Ok, the food; I ordered a pisco punch, and oh my goodness, did it pack a punch. I was happily tipsy after a few sips! So yay, for that since its always a disappointment  to get a weak mixed drink.  We started things off with a very tasty salad, I believe it was their house salad and it was very good. We followed it up with a small sized 1/2 margherita, 1/2 vodka pie.....very, very good.  Their pies are thin crust, and I think this was one of the thinnest i've come by, which I like because you get to really taste and enjoy the sause and toppings. They did not disappoint.  Both were good, but the vodka sauce half was definitely the winner for me.  The boyfriend, always hard to impress, thought the margherita was better. I will definitely be back again.

We got kicked out... Make sure you make reservations.  This was our first time going since we thought the reviews were pretty good.  We were a party of three that arrived around 7:15P.  With roughly only a handful of tables in this small restaurant, there was only one other table that was occupied.  We were pleasantly greeted by the waitress with an explanation of the restaurant and what their specials of the day were.  We were then given glasses of water, place settings and menus to look at.  However, after sitting there and chatting for about five-ten minutes, we were then asked by the waitress if we had made a reservation.  We said we didn't, and the waitress hesitated and went back to the kitchen.  She came back with whom I think was the owner and they asked us to leave! They tried to be polite and apologized and explained to us that because they are a small operation, they were all 'booked" for the night and they needed us to leave so that any of the arriving parties would have a table. I asked if this was a policy of theirs, and they never said "yes".  They only said that because they are small, people make reservations.  I recommended to them they should make that VERY CLEAR on their website--that reservations are highly recommended and that parties with reservations take priority over walk-ins NO MATTER WHAT. Despite the good reviews and the awesome pictures of their menu items, I will definitely not be going back.

Great place. Go. Like now. Right now. What are you waiting for? GO ! ! ! NOW! Celebrating my 1 year anniversary with my wife we visited Fogo De Chao for dinner. What an experience! ! Staff was so friendly and catered to every need. They paid attention to every detail of your meal. Try the house beer. It's great! !

The place looks nice and it's in a nice part of the city near a famous pizza place.  They play gangster movies in the background which is kind of funny for a place that looks as classy as it is.  The portion sizes also filled us. But I have to say though that it was a serious disappointment.  First of all, it's expensive.  This would be OK if the food tasted excellent.  However....their pork chop was breaded with something very strangely similar to Shake & Bake and it was "Garnished" (in reality the pork chop was totally hidden) with a fresh tomato and mozzarella salad.  The mashed potatoes that came with it were also strangely familiar to instant mashed potatoes.  And their NY Cheese cake they offer as desert?  Tasted exactly like the plain cheesecakes you can get at Sam's club.  To top it all off, the waiter took so long to get to us that we had to spend over an hour and a half in there before we could pay our check. I gave it 2 stars because even though we had a terrible experience there, we can't deny they have a cute place and at least the cheap food gave us all a lot to laugh about.  One of the few times that bad restaurant experiences actually put us in a good mood.

Awesome nachos!!! These things were SO good! And I really liked that you could "build your own".  We had jalapeño, tomatoes, onions, black beans, beef and LOTS of cheese (see posted picture)-they were out of this world! Our waitress was terrific! Super friendly, energetic, and attentive.  I really like the atmosphere, it felt authentic.  I'll definitely be back and I can't wait to try more of their menu.
The food here is outstanding. It's perfect for a nice relaxing dinner for two or a group. It's noisier than you'd expect, and seating is tight, but the food is to die for.

I've had good experiences at Sabrina's before, but the last time I was there was terrible. I ordered a breakfast burrito and the burrito came out with a large chunk of the tortilla missing.  I don't expect immaculate food at a brunch place, but I expect at least a little bit of pride in what is being sent out to the tables.  Whoever was in the kitchen that day obviously lacked any sort of pride about their food. Beyond that our waitress was some Hollywood Hipster who seemed too cool to talk to us any more than she had too.  She only spent enough time at our table to take our orders, and the one or two times she did show her face at the table she didn't care to look us in the eye as she talked to us.

We were up in Bayonne for thanksgiving and decided to give the place a try.  Overall we were happy with the experience. For appetizers we got the chicken satay and the pork dumplings.  The satay was decent but the dumplings were quite literally something I've bought in the frozen food section of the grocery store.   I'd expect a sit-down place to make their own or to at least have some of higher quality. For I our main courses she got the hibachi (shrimp and scallops), her "strip and scallops" was misheard.  That being said,  they're was plenty of food and she enjoyed it all.   I got the filet off of the "from the kitchen" menu.  It was slightly underdone "I ordered med rare", but not too rate for my taste.   It was a very tender and flavorful cut of meat.   I'm picky when it comes to steak and I would give that 5 stars. For dessert we were hoping for the mochi green tea and red bean ice cream but had to settle for the regular style of those flavors.   The green tea was pretty good but was more like a chocolate green tea.   The red bean was pretty chunky and did not have much sweetness to it. Our server was polite and attentive and the other employees were very nice (host not impolite but not friendly sorbet). The main dishes and service earned the rating.   Just avoid the dumplings.

Great place to go for happy hour. Max Fish has the best "happy hour" hours you can ask for! 4-6 PM and again at 10-midnight. This is everyday INCLUDING WEEKENDS! An endless sea of choices! A lot of food and a wonderful bar area. $1 oysters! Yes, $1 oysters during happy hour. I truly enjoy Max Fish over Max Oyster Bar because parking is better, service is better, and the overall atmosphere is much more soothing. We also ordered buffalo shrimp and fried calamari. Great place to catch a quick bite of food and few drinks!
Classic NJ diner. Great breakfast, attentive staff  Only place around that has grits or fish cakes. Lunch isn't bad either.

If you're looking for some pretty good authentic food, come to Cuba. We got the ceviche and the papas rellenas to start and each got sandwiches for entrees. Our appetizers were good, but I thought our sandwiches were pretty average. I really wish we had come for dinner on a Thursday or Friday night, because their dinner menu looks really amazing and sometimes they'll even have live music in the back.
The pizza was okay, but a little greasy. The service was fantastic. No bad if you in the mood for pizza.

Wow! Hands down to the best Mexican food I tried on the east coast. This place was recommended by a close friend and her husband. As we walked in the ambience and environment was filled with all types of people. It's the ambience that struck my eyes, the sweet workers, lighting of the restaurant, the interior designs and different types of seating arrangement, and most of all there bar area had what it looked to be a colorful bike going in circles with the various types of drinks showcased underneath of it. They even have a photo booth in the back if your waiting for your food long enough, go have some fun in the photo booth area and kill time!   I don't want to ramble, but this place deff was a hit and wouldn't mind going back more then two times during the day. I was so happy they even had my favorite type of corn on there menu that I usually eat back home- the east coast had it on their menus! Excellent tasty modern Mexican food and deff a go to when in the area, deff will be back one day and referring many of my friends to this amazing and delicious modern Mexican day cooking! Thanks Elvez [=

Love this bar! I haven't tried their food, but their drinks are delicious and masterfully concocted.  This place has one of the best happy hours in the city in terms of value for your dollar.  Also, the scene is ultra chill and hip but sophisticated.
Excellent food, Excellent ambiance. Had a great salad today.  Nader the owner,  treats all of his customer like family.  I most definitely recommend this establishment

Sat at the bar on a weeknight.  Funky beats on the sound system.  I had a pork tenderloin over grits.  Tasty.  Washed it down with a nice wine.  The bartender was attentive and friendly.  The food was excellent.  A little expensive.

I was really excited to hear this place was open. The food selection in university is pretty limited, I was tired of the same places. My friends and I went in on the Tuesday for their "soft opening day" around 5:30 and the place was packed. We waited around for half an hour for a table. We waited even longer for our ramen to come. Other people who came after us had their ramen before us. I guess it's understandable since they just opened. The ramen was alright. I think it's better than Nom Nom Ramen and Yakitori Boy. I had the Tonkatsu Ramen. It wasn't the type of harder stringy noodle that I liked more. We also ordered the agedashi tofu and gyoza. The adegashi tofu was piping hot, pretty sure I burnt my tongue. I don't know whether they were trying to compensate for the hotness, but the gyoza was kind of cold. Taste for both appetizers wasn't flavorful enough for me. Other people in my party had the tonkatsu chashumen and shoyu.They thought it was okay for Philly. My friend's chasu still had strings on there. The did apologize and gave us a discount. I was kind of surprised that you had to pay extra $1 to add an egg to the noodle. This place is alright. It's at an excellent location. Having such limited choices in University City, I would probably come back.I think the best ramen place in Philly is probably Terakawa Ramen in chinatown.

I love this place!! It is a very chill cute restaurant with really cheap prices. The ingredients are so fresh and I especially love their market sides. I have been to other locations but this one is the best. It is not very big so may have to wait but I would come back all the time if it was closer to my apt.

I was surprised how disappointed i was with this place. I assumed the good word and long lines would lead to something worthy of either. What I found was a cheeseburger that was too greasy, cooked incorrectly and lacking anything memorable. Bareburger is half the price and SIGNIFIGANTLY better in all seriousness. We also had a fish item which was as honestly as I could say, just fine. The seating is tight, the crowd is nerve-gratingly 'cool' but I can say the space has character, even if the food doesn't.  I could best describe this place like a Louis Vuitton hand bag.  Everyone (in certain circles) wants one, the price is too high, those people need to be seen with one, but at the end of the day, it is just a bag with a bunch of weird L and Vs all over it posing as a $2000 superbag without any of the merits to warrant it (not that the place is outrageously expensive, but my point should stand).... If you want a burger go to bareburger, if you want bbq go to bluesmoke, I guarantee you better food at either.  So, in conclusion, other than the 1 in 1000 shot of seeing Jay-Z, too much hype, not enough substance.
There mofongo's are to die for. I tried one on their opening day and been going back for one everyday since. It's honestly the best thing I've ever tasted with some chinola juice on the side

I like this place very much. The food was good. If do not consider budget, you can hv BBQ ribs pork steak or something on today's special. If you want to find some thing cheap, the phili cheese steak and burger is your good choice. I hv been there several times and it often full of people. My boyfried love the free bread they serve. He saids the hot bread let him feel very comfortable to begin with other dishes which always make me confusing. If you go there after 9pm for dinner, you usually need to wait for a table to eat. The service was good. But don't go there on weekday noon. At that time, usually very old waitress work there, and their service was just so so.

really bad service , food was good . We had a reservation at 8:00 , we were promptly seated . And that was the last time we had good service . Our server had no idea what he was doing or saying . It took forever to open our wines-it seems like he didn't know how to- and to get ice . Overall the food was good , but the bad service left a sour taste . Won't go back , rather spend my money somewhere else
Appaling customer service. When I called to make a reservation whoever answered the call told me they didn't take reservation and then just hung up, even before I said alright.

We received excellent service! Unfortunately the kitchen was closed already when we arrived and we were starving.....the waiter accommodated and went to the kitchen to see if there was anything they could feed us. They ended up rounding us up some oysters which were delicious and some sort of deep fried potatoes with a delicious dipping sauce.....we had a great time here and will surely be back to try some of the actual menu!

Very expensive and food isn't that great. Tried pork rib dish with hot pepper sauce was very chewy and tastless.   I tried this place 3 times with 5-6 different dishes and always felt that I waste money, definately I wont ever back this place again. very disappointed period!!!!

The sushi here is tasty.  And you can drink a can of Sapporo here.  And it will taste like Sapporo.  But really, the karaoke room upstairs is what amuses me most.  Get some drinks and try to operate the giant remote that has NO BUTTONS IN ENGLISH.  It's more fun than it sounds, honest.  The english selection of songs is lackluster, but the completely random videos that play in the background more than make up for it.

Cue 'Theme from Shaft' music.... What is the meal that's like a burrito with a Korean feel?  Ssam!  Right on.     They say a Korean Ssam is a bad Momofuku...shut your mouth.  But I'm talking about Ssams!  Then we can dig it.... Well I USED to dig it.  But David Change has changed the lunch menu for like the umpteenth time - going from 'make your own Ssam' (think Chipotle with Korean ingredients) to 'we make your Ssam' to 'no Ssam lunch deals'. As of my last visit, the lunch deals are around $12 and consist of (inc. a side and a soda): 1) Two steamed Berkshire pork buns -  These aren't very big but wow is the pork amazing.  Really, what are they doing to those pigs in the Berkshires? 2) Bahn Mi sandwich - Tasty but way too expensive and small for a Bahn Mi Sandwich.  Not recommended. 3) Rice bowl with Berkshire Pork, Organic Chicken, or Tofu - This is the recommended lunch deal as it packs the most value.  Good amount of delicious pork.  Tasty vegetables. The Ssams are still on the menu but are all north of $15 each (vs. the previous ~ $9).  I'm not sure if you can even get Berkshire Pork anymore.  Hangar Steak, Lemongrass Pork Sausage, and Organic Chicken are all I see on their online menu.  These Ssam wraps also include tasty Momofuku-selected fillings like pickled shitake and kimchi puree. There are some lunch menu additions - including some Country Ham sandwiches - but they are also north of $15.  Haven't tried them but imagine they are very tasty. For the 'sides', I've found the Kimchi Granny Smith Apples and the cold noodles to be just okay.  I like the cauliflower side dish best. Definitely try the spicy Korean sauce (Srichacha) that's at the tables - just add it in small doses so you don't overheat your meal. The decor is all modern with a long dark wood bar running along the whole left side and tables on the right side.  You have to go to the back to place your order.  Like most places in the area, it doesn't get too full for lunch but gets busier for dinner (the menu changes too...) This is a must-try if you're in the area but the creeping prices and absence of Ssam on the lunch menu moves this from 4.5/5 star territory down to 4 stars...

I don't know what it is about this place that makes me want to write reviews, but alas I'm back to talk about Nish Nush, and to say one final goodbye to a not-very-good restaurant. If you see an earlier review of mine, it was a matter or cleanliness that I assume they have resolved because I never witnessed it again. I've revisited a few times this year, wanting it to be everything I think it could be, and I always come away disappointed.  Today was the nail in the coffin. My Popeye falafel sandwich? Falafel was cold, perhaps stale. My pita was definitely STALE. Today I ordered French Fries, which I never get. They were perhaps they worst french fries I've ever eaten. They smelled of dark old oil, were incredibly soggy and were more like french fry pieces, most no longer than 3/4 inch. Simple rule, don't serve me nasty things. Disappointed that it had to end this way. I recommend looking somewhere else for lunch.

Not terrible, but very overrated.   We only had chicken things, which might explain the mediocrity.  The mole tastes like soy sauce.  There are several TV's playing daytime mexican gameshows.  Solid Horchata and salsa.

After years of passing this place on Rt.1, a friend and I came here for dinner and drinks on a Thursday night.  We were able to take advantage of  the 1/2 off martinis which was an added bonus. I ordered a pomegranate martini which was okay and the spaghetti squash & ricotta ravioli.  The ravioli was over cooked and the pasta skin was too chewy.  The best part of the meal was the corn, cherry tomato, kale and capers marmalade under the ravioli.We closed the meal by splitting a sorbet trio that was nothing special. Would probably spend my money elsewhere to get a better meal for my buck.
Great tasting falafel, but the guy behind the counter is a unfriendly mope. Try the frys.
Awesome!  I love this place.  Everything was really good, and everyone is very friendly.  Great attention to details.

Great food - terrible customer service. Estimated time of delivery was 35-50 minutes. 2 hours later still never got the food. Called twice and the person who I spoke with said they were short-staffed and couldn't find their delivery guy. How is that a proper way to run a business? I understand if people call out and you are short staffed. Then change your estimated delivery window so I can avoid ordering from you.

Sadly, this once great place is going downhill.  I've been a long time patron now after having brunch with friends their over 8 years ago.  I have even had the pleasure of seeing a few famous faces every so often when I dine there.  Each time I return, the service seems to go down a notch, the prices go up little, and the food stays about the same.  Now, I have no problem paying for overpriced pancakes and eggs as long as the service is decent, the food is up to par, and my overall experience is enjoyable. However, on my most recent experience, I had the unfortunate experience of having a server who had a "could give a crap less" attitude, which didn't make for the greatest start to the meal.  But that's fine, I was still going to enjoy my meal there. Luckily on this occasion I only had to wait 5-10 minutes for our table.  In the past, depending on how late you got there, a wait for a table of 2 could be over an hour. But I digress, I thought I made my order pretty clear asking for one of their signature dishes - my usual (Banana Walnut Pancakes) - without one main ingredient - nuts.  I'm deathly allergic and just ask for the order without walnuts.  Pretty simple, right?  Unfortunately not if your server isn't really paying attention.   After getting our food and knowing what the order is supposed to look like, I knew that the server had gotten my order wrong.  We tried to find the server, who seemed to have disappeared.  We finally tracked him down and waved him over, to which he assumed we wanted our check, since this was the first time he came in the vicinity of our table after taking our order.  Apparently, it would be too much to expect that he check-in to see how everything was after we received our food.   I explained to him that I wanted the Banana Walnut Pancakes, without walnuts.  To which he responded "So you just want sautéed bananas."  I agreed, not realizing what he actually entered my order as.  He was kind enough to come over after returning my order to the kitchen and said it would be out in about 3 minutes.   My order reappeared in about 1.  It seemed right, not taking a bite out of it initially.  However, it seemed that the raw, fully sliced banana that was sitting on my pancakes a few minutes ago had merely been replaced with sautéed bananas, about 3 slices to be exact - it usually comes with about 6 slices, as I could tell from the indentation made by the initial banana.  As a patron (and past employee) of any good restaurant, returned food should NEVER be merely replaced, if not thrown out all together.  It should be completely re-done and made to order as requested by a customer.  This would have been something that the server realized had he ever come over to actually see how our food was, especially after being returned to the kitchen.   I ate about half of my meal, since I didn't really enjoy it as much as I usually did, but I couldn't completely put my figure on why.  The pancakes just seemed different.  After receiving our check, I finally realized why my usual delicious order of Sautéed Banana Walnut Pancakes just didn't taste as good.  Instead of getting the Sautéed Banana Walnut Pancakes, I instead received sour dough pancakes with bananas added.  Interesting, since I didn't even know I could add-on fruit. My husband found the eggs to be a bit runny and the food overall just OK.  The biscuits were delicious as always, although smaller than they have been in the past. To say the least, we won't be returning to Bubby's any time soon, if ever.  I would love to give this place I once used to love another chance, but I find it difficult when it just seems like too much to ask for your food to be what you ordered and actually have servers who care and work for the gratuity that they are getting.  There are WAY too many good restaurants in this city to waste our time waiting in line for overpriced, mediocre food here.  Especially when our brunch for two of pancakes, eggs, juice, and soda, not one ounce of alcohol drank, ran us $65.  I can get much more bang for my buck somewhere else.  And their cash only policy seems quite shady.

Great neighborhood pub/cafeteria. Came here for Sunday late lunch. It's kid friendly, casual and comfy. I call it a cafeteria because you basically order all your food from a window, they give you a table number and they bring it to you when it's ready. It was a little confusing at first, but I like ordering at my own pace. A little grimy since it's a bar at night and they serve a lot of finger foods. I had the sir racha chicken wings which were really tasty. My husband had the shrimp burger and loved it. We'll be back!
I had lunch at the location and the food and service were both excellent and not a better value in Montpelier.

My husband and I love the spicy tuna rolls because they have a great texture- a little subtle crunch. Also the shrimp tempura rolls are delicious. We order very often and have not yet been disappointed.
Yay- yummy fusion of east & west!

Over the top chef salad, pizzas with fresh veggies and artisan mozzarella, drab interior, reasonable prices, fast service, friendly and familiar faces - this place is exactly what a small pizza shop ought to be.  A classic West Hartford hangout.  Memories of Uconn basketball games on TV, high school pizza parties.  In fact, I think I'll watch the Uconn sweet sixteen game there this Friday.

Love Meritage, this place is super cool. Food is awesome and the owners and waitstaff are amazing. Had dinner at the bar and I noticed two things: 1. the music is great, i felt like i was in a lounge in Soho and 2. you can watch the stupid hipsters across the street eating albeit good food while experiencing horrific service. Don't be intimidated by Meritage's formal appearance, check this place out.
Great food, nice atmosphere. Love this place.

I'm giving it a 5. I love everything about it the food the people the atmosphere and not to metion the Hucca. I been a regular there since they opened and will continue to be.  If you do go try the salmon with the chipotle mash potatos and bring a nice bottle of wine to go with it.

If you are interested in a very young, college crowd, this is the place to go. Me, not so much. Been there a few times to see my buddies band. Only reason why I would go. I have never eaten there so I am not sure what the food tastes like.

I like Butcher Bar as a restaurant and think it's an okay butcher shop. Their selection for meats is pretty small, with only one case that's not that full. That being said, it's really more of a restaurant (like 90/10) and if you want a wider selection of meat go to International Meat Market or K&T. Our server was friendly, and all over it with a big group of people in the back patio area. I got the beef platter 1/2 brisket, 1/2 burnt ends. The platter was good, definitely the best barbecue I've had in New York, but that's a really low standard. The meat was tender, but there wasn't a lot of flavor to it, not sure what kind of wood is used to smoke the brisket/burnt ends but it doesn't impart a lot of character.The gf's Philly Cheese was an interesting and recommended dish by our server. She was right to accept that recommendation because it was an interesting twist. Our server warned the lady friend that it wasn't what you think of as a Philly cheese sandwich but if it wasn't liked she would switch it out for something else. She definitely is what puts BB from an Ok place to a great place. We also got the mac and cheese, which was surprisingly tasty and well done. The food is pretty good, but the service is great and their Arnold Palmer's are fantastic.

There aren't a lot of ramen places in center city; so when I first heard of this place, I dragged my boyfriend here to try it out. Since then, I've been to Terakawa a few times and I do think it is pretty decent. It's definitely not the best ramen I've ever had, but it's not bad at all. The takoyaki was smaller than others I've had (they do give you 6 to compensate for the smaller size) but the flavor was right. The shoyu ramen was great the first time I had it, but was slightly off at my most recent visit. My friends really enjoyed their gyoza (I didn't try it so I can't judge for myself). All in all, I'm satisfied with their food and pricing and will certainly return many times in the future.
great place

Had to give 5 stars. Pretty perfect weather so we sat outside. Cucumber martini type drink was good. Good tap beer. We had black bean burgers...basically awesome veggie burgers. Really tasty; I'd recommend if you were vegetarian or not. Service was first class. We had a question about directions and so the manager came over and talked to us, very nice and pleasant. No complaints whatsoever.

The minimalist decor was too Ikea for me. It felt unfinished and I was underwhelmed. The service was very slow. We waited 15 minutes to place a drink order. And our appetizers came before our drinks. Getting attention was next to impossible for most of the meal. The food was excellent though. The poached egg with creme fraiche appetizer and miso cod entree rocked. The drinks were delightful, when they arrived. My friend said it was the best goat cheese omelette ever. The dessert was supposed to be a molten lava cake. However it was overcooked so there was nothing molten or lava like about it.  The center was barely moist and the outside was crisp.  the prices were great but I would be willing to pay more for better service. Given the location on the west side highway and the hike from the subway, I probably wouldn't venture back anytime soon. PS---The bathrooms felt unfinished like they were thrown together on a budget. I also requested a candle for my friend's birthday celebration on my open table reservation and they did not remember to do it.

Went there last night, had amazing food, our server had a great attitude. the amuse bouche was a small cup of pork broth, it was amazing, a small cup similar to a miso soup but soooo tasty. had the tuna tartare, it was great, i like tuna tartare in general but never had it served like this before on top of a crispy tempurad furniture, similar to a zucchini pancake. spicy rock shrimp was pretty good, not as good as nobu's but up there. the pork casserole, and in general i am not a big fan of pork, was amazing as well. very hearth and homely. the hot pot of seafood was great, full of various sea food and was in a great broth, we had to ask for bread so that we could soak them in and eat. sliders, they took a while to come out of the kitchen (like 40 minutes) but i was already wasted, so i didn't mind, and they were well worth the wait. they come w/ sweet potatoes that were fried and spiced to perfection. the desert was ok, but i think i made the wrong choice, maybe that's why i was no so impressed with it, but my gf seemed to love it.

WARNING: The pie here will turn you into a pizza snob for the rest of your life. From this point forward all other pizza will disappoint you in comparison. When I'm in the city, I still frequent the great ones like DiFara's, Totonno's, and Lucali. DeLoz somehow still remains my favorite. There is magic in the sauce here. MAGIC. Grab a bottle of wine and head here for a true experience. I went to the original joint on Hudson (not Hamilton) in Trenton mostly, but this new place is better setup and the pie is exactly the same. Being hungry is optional. You won't be able to stop. When it gets to your table, quickly grab whichever rectangular shaped slices have the most chunks of tomato showing.

Not a big fan of French food or flatbreads, however I was pleasantly surprised with what this place had to offer. Wide range of drinks from cappuccinos to bottomless mamosa specials makes this place an ideal spot for brunch. The size of the restaurant is on the smaller side, however is a prefect environment for a brunch date. Food was clean, fresh and full flavored. The goat cheese and bacon was a great combination on their classic "Traditionnelle" flatbread. The desserts are a must have! The Tartes Sucres with fruits and Nutella is exquisite and not too sweet. Reasonably priced. Service was great. Definitely a must try place if you are around the area.

While it's generally not my first choice on the list of what to eat, there is still something to be said about a good burger now and then. Royale surely hit the spot. Just. So. It's a bit out of the way for us, off the side street in Alphabet City, but still based on senior yelpers' reviews, off we went. It's a pub with a very local, no frills, neighborly spot and casual but friendly staff who come by often enough but not too often to make sure you are not in short supply of anything. Great burgers and very tasty drinks. I would say give it a shot!

Anella has a nice atmosphere and I admittedly went here on their opening night so I'm sure they have some kinks to work out still. I will give them a second chance for sure. But for now... I got the salmon which was really delicious, but if you get a $12-$16 entree, you are told that it doesn't come with a side. The sides are $5 extra. My friend pointed out that this would be fine if the sides were served family style so everyone can try, but I just felt as though I wasn't getting enough food for what I was paying. The incessant water-refilling was driving me nuts and interfering with conversation. The desserts were really great. When they get their liquor license this may be a go to place for a glass of wine and dessert.

One of the best pizzas I've ever had.. And I eat a lot of pizza!!! Eating Grimaldi's pizza, I sighed after every bite; cuz with every bite, I came closer and closer to not having anymore :( :( #oinker The line to the (one) restroom was long, but my friend (also female) and I got invited to use the employee restroom in the kitchen. However, afterwards we didn't see anyone else being allowed to use this one.. Sketchy much??? To answer the Grimaldi's vs Lombardi's million dollar question: they're both soooo good that you should just keep going back and forth to eat both and decide for yourself!! As for me, I don't want to make up my mind on this one; I'll glady visit both havens on my trips to NYC.GIVE PIZZA CHANCE!

Wow Wow Wow,  My girls finally dragged me out of the office to pop into this place for happy hour.  Now I finally get it! The food and cocktails here are ridiculous.  Well worth the wait in my opinion.  The agave is where it's at.  The Asian bites are amazing.  I will definitely return.

Great pastrami sandwich!!! Had Dinic's the other day and must say, this sandwich blows that place out of the water!! Wish Dinic's wasn't such a tourist trap that sucks you in...would have  preferred two Herschel's sandwiches instead...amazing.

Everything is great, but my personal favorites are Chicago mix popcorn, cheesy chili dip, mesquite kale chips, mac & cheese pancakes, and Jintana's chicken. The burger is also fantastic on Barrio Bakery focaccia. The atmosphere is classy and comfortable. Check out this unique spot in the Old North End!

I have to say I've been going here for a while, and when Boneshakers closed (tear!*)  This became the go-to brunch place.  I used to go just because it was close and easy to meet up with others, but since the renovations to make it a vegan diner I absolutely LOVE it!  The booths are a wonderful addition, the new menus are streamlined and easy to read, the paired-down baked good selection much fresher than before and more interesting without being overwhelming.  I love getting the Sag as an old standby, but everything I've had here has been delicious.  The only thing I would change is to organize the waitstaff a bit better with a designated host, and more prompt table service, but although they are a bit disorganized they are very friendly. Oh and add juice!  But this place is a great atmosphere - try the cinnamon rolls!

Coming here the day after a mild bout of food poisoning is not the wisest decision I've ever made, but reasoning is not my strong suit when the smell of Bratwurst is in the air. My friends and I all got the same thing: Viennese hot cocoa and the Bratwurst with potatoes and mustard. While we waited for our food we took in the opulent setting. It's all dark wood paneling and crystal light fixtures and the room is littered with tiny tables and booths shoved up against the wall. I think I even had a non-celebrity sighting here and saw one of the artists from that Bravo Project-Runway-knockoff-art-show. There was also a very adorable waiter that I kept having awkward eye contact with. He had very blonde hair and an innocent looking face so my table thusly dubbed him "sexy hitler youth boy," which may or may not be appropriate to write here, but whatever. The cocoa? Delicious! It was cocoa for adults for sure, not too sweet, very strongly cocoa-y, and pungent in a great way. After we'd finished eating a little girl at a nearby table had a cup of it delivered to her and she had to mellow it out with some of her water because it was too rough on her baby palate. This is yet another reason not to like kids. The Brats came and when I cut into mine for the first time I thought I heard angels sing. These were natural casings and they had that "pop" that only good old fashioned intestines impart. The meat inside had perfect texture and spice that was only made better with some of their killer mustard. This was seriously the best mustard of my life. I ate it on it's own until tears came to my eyes because it was so strong, which was a small price to pay for such condiment greatness. The bread that came in the little basket was also tasty, but I hope I didn't offend them by adding salt on top of the unsalted butter that they provided. Unsalted butter makes me really sad. They didn't rush us out at all either, which was nice on the back end of our meal, but we had to wait a while to get a table. I get that it's a fancy place and they don't want to rush you and that it's supposed to be a little cafe where you can hang out and all, but when you've got a line 12 people deep, maybe you can speed it up a little. I'd still go back and wait all over again, though. Unlike the German members of my family, this food was warm, pleasant, and very classy.

worst service, ever! went there and my dinner and table of 6 was rushed, the appetizer, soup and dinner came out all at once. the waitress was so darn rude. our orders were all messed up, if they didn't rush us so darn much maybe they could have gotten our order correct. My friend asked for her noodle dish not to be so spicy, and of course they made it extra spicy, no, not spicy, but piping hot! I came all the way from NYC to go meet with friends at this place and was not worth the trip at all, the food wasn't horrible, but it def wasn't good. I'm from Thailand, and the food was bland, not much flavor. Thai food is known around the world for it's abundant flavor and spices in which this establishment clearly lacked. Never will I ever eat at this place ever again, worst service ever.
Excellent food. Everything was delicious. Specially the pork. Small place, but fast service. Must go if you want great Cuban or Latin food in NY.
Lo mejor de lo mejor una atencion increible y la comida ni se diga

For Vigans like my friend Jill this is definitely the place to be for some coffee and a little treats. They have a wide variety of vigan goodies that even a carnivore like me would love. Their coffee's great too. Must try: Sticky Cinnamon Buns, Oatmel Raisin Cookies, and their Tofuttis

Came here after a show for the price fixe $30 menu.  The flavors of our meals were outstanding.  The lamb was so tender, and everything else we had no compliants about.  Even the mojito was good! Absolutely, a place to return to.
good spot but charging the tax after the fact on beer, etc. is lame!!!!
Food was bland and the vegetables taste like they were frozen previously..my plate was quite pricey for the fact that I couldn't even finish it all and threw it away.

I was here for restaurant week & I have to say the experience was very pleasant & professional. I'd def. recommand this place to my ppl & would love to come back for special occasion! Food-very delicious & beautiful.

Came here about a week ago after I had been recommended from a good family friend of mine. Service was very good and the waiters were very sweet. The food was ok but I felt that it could've been way better than it was. But hey, everyone has their bad days and good days.

Ok, here is the deal - I've never had anything but nice things to say about this place.  I have been a loyal customer for five years and recommended it to dozens of people.  The other day I was having lunch there and they made a cripplingly fatal mistake - they would not let me return a salad that was clearly prepared wrong and forced me to pay for it! Yes, I know what you are thinking - I was being picky and demanding and probably ate half the thing and sent it back expecting it wiped from my check - but no, that's not at all what happened. I arrived mid afternoon on a Thursday and they were having a rare slow moment (which is a treat) - My servers as well as the manager all recognized me as I am a regular and everyone smiled and welcomed me (I'm gonna miss this place!). I ordered a papaya salad along with an entrée of string beans and chicken in chili paste (I forget the name of the entree) and sticky rice.  I got my salad and a few bites in noticed a bad grittiness - I tried to continue as overall it was delicious as usual but the grit continued.  I sent it back requesting my entrée only.  Both the servers apologized and I replied that it was "no big deal" and continued my lunch. When it was time for the check, instead of one of the servers, the manager (who I recognized and who recognized me) came over with the check - she placed it in front of me with everything listed including my $7 salad.  She immediately began to explain (she's apparently been down this road before) that because the papaya salad has little shrimp it is impossible to clean them thoroughly and occasionally there is a little grit - while this is, of course, plausible I found it remarkably rude that this explanation came AFTER my meal along with a full check.  I replied that I have had hundreds of papaya salads and dozens at SriPraPhai, adding that they are usually delicious but this one was inedible and that's why I returned it.  She just shook her head and stubbornly explained the same thing again (not for a second realizing that it wasn't a debate worth having).  I then found myself defending myself as a good and regular customer who has NEVER sent anything back and finally she agreed to take "50%" off the price of the salad. Well, I found this even more offensive because now we are in a negotiation rather than her simply showing difference to me as a good customer - it was ALL about getting paid and my years of loyalty, my praise of their food and my 20% tips meant NOTHING. I told her that I would gladly pay full price and would never return.  She ignored this, shook her head again, took my money and came back with change less a 50% discount for my salad.  I couldn't even look at her. While the food is certainly delicious, the management at SriPraPhai clearly see their customers as cattle to be herded in, fed and herded back out - and are not aware that they are in a "service business".  Such a shame.  I almost gave them one star but Ive had too many good meals there over the years!
Love this restaurant. We frequently visit this for team lunches. May be I like this place so much is because they give abundant guacamole. The food is great and so is the service and ambiance.

Got hooked onto this place a few years back & now Im a regular. The food is outstanding & reasonably priced. All of the soups are homemade & are outstanding also especially the Pea Soup. The hamburgers are made fresh  not hockey puck frozen patties & the onion rings are to die for. If you want something thats not on the menu & John has the ingredients he will make it for you. One of the best places I've been to for a long time

Worst Pizza ever, The grinders suck as well. They advertise " Tom and Pat's Subs are filled with what you order not filled with lettuce and tomato's etc as a filler like other places! We won't say who. Tom and Pat's is where the beef is." Totally false claim!!! Tom and Pat's use as little meat and cheese as possible, no idea who they compaired their grinders to! I got a grinder there, the server's seem stuck up, hardly any meat and cheese, loaded with brown, wilted lettuce and thinly sliced moldy, rotten tomato's, not fit for human consumption! Stay away!!! Want a really great sub or sandwhich? Try Food Fair right next door, their subs are LOADED with meats etc, they are now serving hot foods as well!!! I would give them no stars!

Love love love. A simple roti wrapped in a whole lot of goodness. unda aloo roll is by far my favorite roll here. The shami kabab roll is pretty good too. I can easily eat 2 of these yummy rolls when Im not even hungry. That should tell you something. :D We have visitors from out of town tell us that they definitely need to visit this place once before they leave. A must must try.

This is as good as it gets. Best bang for the buck in New York City. We love to order all the antipasti and have a pasta as our main course. Wine list is extensive and so fairly priced that you won't see such deals anywhere else in Manhattan. Staff is always knowledgeable and friendly. Reservations can be difficult and the wait can be long if you don't have any. But everything is so fresh and yummy, it's worth the wait. Can be loud.

I'm a sucker for a good ceviche and this places delivers that! The lobster ceviche was on point. The waiters are super nice, great decor, the only thing lacking was the ambiance. Fair enough, it was a Monday night, but it was empty and there was no mood lighting or music, so didn't really get a "vibe" for the place. But it's definitely tasty!

As far as the pizza, it wasn't bad.. I mean i did eat half the pie. Although wasnt the best I ever had.But i loved the atmosphere. So rustic looking with their wooden tables and wooden chairs. loved that. Wine wasn't that great. Their gelato was fantastic :) and so was the music playing. All around great place.

Went to this place after seeing the good reviews at Yelp but came out hungry from this place. I went there with a co-worker during lunch hours and literally waited 45 mins for the food to get out. We ordered the Tom-Yum soup which came out about 15 mins after we ordered, was good but cold. I thought must be busy so whatever. Then the food took another 30 mins to arrive after the soup. We ordered two dishes, the first one came out (cold again) and then the second entree arrived 10 mins later. At that point both of us did not have time to sit there and eat so just had to leave after sharing entree number 1. Still had to pay for the second entree (lunch box special). We had asked for potstickers (reason behind getting the lunch box instead of regular entree) and it came out with a spring roll. Highly disappointed!! Avoid if you do not have time during lunch hour. I haven't tried dinner there and don't think I will but could be a better experience during dinner.

ABSOLUTELY DELICIOUS!  Very creative menu that is always updated with new additions.  Very friendly and attentive staff.  High-energy atmosphere but not too loud...great place to have conversation and catch up with a friend or have dinner with a spouse/significant other. I have been back several times and Perilla definitely goes down as one of my most favorite NYC restaurants.   Very nicely done!
The sandwiches here are super super fresh.  They are the pro's of the catering service.  Their portions are very generous and the staff very friendly.  Thumbs up!

All I have to say is AMAZING! OMG! No matter what dish you order, you will be satisfied! A must to order is their Salmon Panini. I was in awe while I bit into it and I told the waitress how great it was and she told me the paper wrote them up just on that panini alone! They loved it so much that an article was written up about it. Simply amazing! I go as often as I can!

As a once a weeker at Wazu, I feel like Norm at Cheers. Most of the time it's the usual Great Wazu sandwich. I have been eating them for 20+ years. On my Great Wazu off days, its the Tuna (which I never get anywhere else but the Wazu) always fresh and tasty. So, see ya next week guys and I'll be Yelping. I'm still debating whether or not East Hanover or Parsippany make a better Wazu, they both rule.

Went to Scarpetta last night for a birthday celebration. We started off with a bottle of wine. When we ordered our wine, it was served within 60 seconds of ordering!!  That was the fastest service I have ever seen!  Then the bread basket came out and I agree with other reviewers that the bread is pretty good.  The stromboli bread roll with cheese and salami reminded me of my dad's homemade calzones.  For appetizers, we ordered the yellowtail and the seared sea scallops.  For entrees, we ordered the Black Tagliolini with lobster and I ordered the spaghetti.  Everything was fresh and flavorful.  The spaghetti was simple and very tasty but definitely overpriced ($24)  For dessert we ordered the cheese plate and the chocolate cake.  The chocolate cake was a little too much chocolate for my liking but still very good.   I highly recommend this restaurant for a special evening out in NYC.

A chic bar with an upscale restaurant taste. -Great flavored margaritas are really good. But most of the time, they could be 'weak', since I am no lite weight.  If you request them to be made w/ a bit more liquor and less iced, they will obliged. -Fantastic Guacamole - we ordered a second serving of it. -Delicious Pan seared scallops with roasted sweet potato puree - I WANT MORE OF BOTH. Ok here comes the downside of my visit: the service   We celebrated a coworkers birthday dinner back in January.  Making a reservation was no problem.  But when we needed to adjust the time, they made it clear that we need to be up from the table by certain time. Since they are expecting another party.  I am no fool..I used to work at a restaurant....albeit it was not a fancy bar like this. But I am sure they can accommodate that 'another party' at another table.  Unless every table in the restaurant was all booked for that same time!!!  So, we arrived and were still missing two people to join our party.  I will admit that some of it was lost in translation btw my other friend and the hostess.  Although we would order drinks, they rather have us sitting at the bar until 'the table was ready', coincidentally, which was ready when another person arrived.   The check found it's way onto our table right after the busboy removed the last plate from the table.   When they want you OUT-- they want you OUT!
I eat here all the time. Nice people, decent food, always fresh. For a "truck stop" diner, its a good place to eat and reasonably priced as well.
Service was atrocious

Saigon Shack has the distinct honor of being my first-ever banh mi experience. As I'm a complete newbie to the sandwich side of Vietnamese cuisine, I thought I should probably go with the classic.  The classic consists of Vietnamese ham, bacon, pate, pickled carrots, cucumber, mayo and cilantro (not a cilantro fan so I removed that**) on a crusty roll for only $5, and it's pretty darn tasty. My only issue with the sandwich was that, when the waitress asked if I wanted it spicy or non-spicy, I asked if I could go with medium spice; she said yes, but when the sandwich came out, there was absolutely no spiciness to it whatsoever. Don't make the same mistake that I did if you want your sandwich to be spicy at all because apparently not spicy, medium spicy and spicy actually means: not at all spicy, not at all spicy, and spicy. Anyway, my bf got the Peking Duck banh mi, and it was soooo good: Tender, juicy duck with a complementary sweet sauce. $5 more than my classic but totally worth it. We also had the sesame cold noodle salad, which was a tasty appetizer. The place itself is small, but on a Wednesday evening in November we only had about a 3 minute wait. The service was great, even though we were being (unintentionally) obnoxious to them, doing things like sitting down without being seated because we didn't know and changing our order after we already put it in. They put up with us very nicely. I'd definitely be back to try another banh mi variety and to give the pho a go! **Dislike, but don't hate, cilantro. But for those who truly despise the herb, there's apparently a website called ihatecilantro.com where you can do things like post to the community forum and submit cilantro haikus.

3 and a half stars is right.. a little too generous, for me. Like many of the other tourist-wrenching joins down in the historic fidi, this place is about the scenery, not the food. So, be sure you order the basics...but even then, you may be disappointed. I just heard about Fraunces Tavern today but it is the oldest structure in the area- it was George Washington's go-to joint back in his day. And the decor certainly shows that- lots of creeky wood, tavern-esque furniture (well the side I saw on had a modern twist, you count cow printed, mildly uncomfortable banquettes- there are two entrances.). The upstairs is a musuem, and the bar seems big so there's something for everyone. I came here for a business lunch. My host made a reservation for three at 12 on a Wed and NO ONE was there. Firstly, the first rule of thumb is that these touristy places are mad expensive. That rings very true here. FT offers lunch, brunch and dinner. For lunch, you can expect apps at $12, and entrees at 16-25. Wowza for lunch. Despite being a red blooded American place (after all, the place salutes GW!), there are sure lots of British things on the menu. So if you like gasto-pub fare, never fear.  They got bangers and mashed. My two lunch buddies got the shepard's pie. It looks pretty- nice presentation and gourmet. A medium portion. It was made of lamb, which I don't eat. The mashed p atop did actually look kind of perfect. I was sure to order pub fare, so I got the fish and chips. There are very few things on the menu that come wtih sides, and this is one of them- the chips! Unfortunately, my favorite thing about fish and chips are the chips (fries) and these sucked. They were borderline...stale? There did not have any good fry quality.. not crispy, not seasoned, not even greasy... just very frozen tasting. Boo for no handmade chips. For $16,  I expected more. The fries were better than the fish though. The fish meat itself was a bit.. fishy. I'm not sure what they used; probably haddock or cod? It was a bit flavorless. I will say that I liked how the fish batter was not very greasy at all, but it was a flavorless shell- there was no beer in the batter. The tartar sauce was even a bit mild.. but this I didn't mind because I'm a huge fan of tartar. I got my standard store bought malt vinegar (the menu suggests it's not generic) and tabasco. The service is fine- nothing overbearing, but the food came out fast enough and the waitress may have checked up once. She was a little hard to get a hold of, so we instead, got someone else to take care of the bill Very blah. Would only return for the museum; the brunch menu is pretty much the same as lunch with the exception of perhaps oatmeal, and pancakes. The dinner items somewhat expand on the lunch- i.e. a bigger portion of the duck confit, etc.. some of the fancier dishes (duck, skate) actually sounded good so maybe this isn't a pub place after all. Guess I won't find out..

Great food. Great service. Great location. My family and I went to Park Avenue Tavern new years eve for lunch, arriving just two minutes before their kitchen closed. Most places would turn people away so close to closing the kitchen, however they were very inviting and we had a great time. The food, service and atmosphere were so fantastic, we returned later that evening, cancelling our previous new years plans and had a great evening.

when we saw they serve fake syrup, and charge an extra $2.50 for real syrup...we left! hello, this IS a pancake house, right? just not right!  Why come here then when you can have the wonderful pancakes at Perkins right up the road in E. Windsor?

Went there last night with another couple for a night at a DDD restaurant. this is not a diner, drive in or dive but okay.   their menu is seasonal so you are going to see different things there.  We had the peanut brittle (which is pretty much peanuts with some sweet bacon flavoring on them), the squash appetizer (nice crust and flavor) the pork belly and roasted grape app (SO GOOD) the friend chicken (eh - moist chicken, okay waffle, GREAT KALE) and a ricotta dumpling dish (no flavor, needed salt). the drinks were alright.  not my favorite but we each left with a prepackaged cookie without even ordering dessert- so you could say i left happy. if i came back i would get a burger.

My boyfriend and I went to Acacia this past weekend for a date. The atmosphere was very quiet and relaxed. We were seated immediately at a nice corner table and our waitress was very attentive. There was some music playing, but not enough to disrupt conversation. For an appetizer, we ordered the sweet potato eggrolls. They were fantastic! We both agreed that they were unique, tasty, and some of the best eggrolls we'd ever had. I ordered the salmon for dinner. It was well cooked, and while there was not enough sauce for my taste, it was very good. My favorite part was the crab and apple risotto that it was served with- outstanding! My boyfriend had the filet which was perfectly cooked and very tender. He was a big fan of the mashed potatoes. We did not stay for dessert - I would like to go back and try some. My only qualm is that they don't list prices for desserts, which makes me think they are quite pricey. On our way out we saw the menu for the power lunch, which looks like a great deal. I will definitely try that out sometime! Overall, we thoroughly enjoyed this restaurant. While it's too pricey for us to frequent regularly, we will return for special occasions.
Chicken parm. was pretty good. Restaurant has a sport-bar feel to it.
This place is fantastic! Food and service are always on point. It's right in my neighborhood so I like to swing by sometimes and grab a hotdog from the truck in their courtyard. Never disappoints.

Ugh! What went wrong here?? This place used to be good! Our party of 8 was seated at a 'private' table in its own little room. We were asked to remove our shoes. SURPRISE! Food debris on the floor -- lovely on the bare feet and socks! Sticky, dusty table added to the ambiance. The service was excruciatingly slow and it was definitely not crowded. After waiting over an hour our meals came one at a time over a period of about 20 minutes. We wanted to complain but the only staff around were very young (middle school?) girls who were frantically trying to stay on top of things. Never going back here!

I am a Better Gourmet Kitchen addict.  Please help me! lol I eat here every day.  its the only place on Staten Island that I feel like I'm getting a healthy balanced meal.  There are other health food places but the food was so dry. Plus the workers are so happy and helpful.  its such a nice atmosphere.  the music is cool and the decor is great too.  i feel like im in soho.

Out of the way and tiny, but it's the home of the best desert in NYC. The Warm Date Cake.  Worth a late night trip just for that. And go late, because otherwise you'll be waiting for one of the 10 seats to open up. But totally worth the hassle.
We waited way too long to try this place.  Great food, good service, kid friendly.  Definitely one of my favorites in South Orange / Maplewood.  We'll be back.

i made a yelp profile just to give this place 5 stars. i live a block away, but for whatever reason i've been putting off trying it out for a couple months now. first of all, i didnt notice it for awhile because it's intentionally nondescript. secondly, i'm usually broke. and on top of all that, gentrification is weird. but, i'm so glad i finally stopped by! MOMO's fulfills the 3 prongs of my dining standards, which i so rarely encounter in new york...where pretty much everything new is overrated and overwrought and overpriced (am i sounding bitter?) anyways, back to the three prongs: 1) good food - the food is great. like...interesting and crazy tasty. there are about 20 other reviews with the proper foodie word bank here to tell you that. 2) fair pricing - the thing that really irks me about this neighborhood is the lack of middle-of-the-price-spectrum establishments . you're either grocery shopping at overpriced millenium (where they refuse to accept food stamps even though upwards of half of the people who live in this neighborhood use them) or at suspiciously affordable bravo (where the tomatoes are generally more yellowish than red). you're either dining at no name chinese food or roberta's. So to have a restaurant where the food is prepared with such great care yet offered so affordably is such a relief! kudo's momo! 3) AMBIANCE!!! - the most illusive prong of all. Usually in new york, you can find the first two, but the third suffers. but my friend and i opened the sturdy door to MOMO's on a quiet, chilly night in this partially industrial-wastelandish neighborhood (which still has a hunger for these little oases) to find bob dylan greeting us over the speakers in a warmly lit cozy-but-not-cramped mountain cabin of sushi. who knew bbq eel would taste better while listening to don't think twice, it's alright. The staff was friendly and personable but not at all shmoozy....when it comes down to it, i guess momos just manages the balancing act of a great neighborhood spot with ease and aplomb. can't wait til they get that liquor license! ps. phil? the owner? what a gem treasure with his little butterfly t shirt and genuine demeanor.

EXCELLENT! I just looked in -- nice lighting, the little cafe look. You open the door, there's the bar. Good sign. Antiques and sisal ropes decorate the place. Big windows, comfortable seats along side. The tables have a tiled look. We sat down, the menu was Brazilian. OKbyme. In their eagerness to serve I got the impression that they were new and that the restaurant is family-owned. There are the old man joking around with his grandson in the place, but the drinks and the food are top-of-the-line professional. What a hidden gem! When I asked for a caipirinha, the waitress asked me, "what kind?" I got the "traditional" lime, my girlfriend got the mango. Both delicious. We ordered a dish that was like fajitias -- beef strips came on a sizzling hot cast-iron plate with peppers and collard greens. Tender and delicious. We also ordered fried yukka. Perfect. Be careful -- that little jar with hot sauce is REALLY HOT. The wallet was not crying at the end of the meal. She was ok with it. Definitely we will go again. We're lighting a candle for the saint-of-good-restaurants that this place stays open with the quality food and service! Fingers crossed. Toes crossed. Eyes crossed.
Their "brown rice' was white rice soaked in margarine to turn it yellow, and then there was plenty of oil from the wok.  Yech!    They know that's not brown rice, it's plainly dishonest.

Sometimes, you find truly amazing food in place you least expected. I admit, I judged book by it's cover. How very wrong of me! It's a simple place, reminded me of a deli somewhat, simple decor, easy-going atmosphere. But the food that comes out of their kitchen in nothing less than five-star, rave-worthy masterpieces. From presentation to taste, it's all extraordinary. Truly homemade, and delicious to very last bite. I had seared scallops with homemade gnocchi - those gnocchi was best ones I ever ate. Deserts are outstanding. Chocolate molten cake was more of the soufflé, imo, but regardless, it was yummmmyyy! Homemade vanilla ice cream that accompanied it was perfect pairing. Chef and staff very friendly and welcoming. Theresa's place deserves all the raves and some more!

I am a bit of a pizza nut, and this place is freaking amazing!  The most inventive pizzas I've ever seen anywhere.  Skip the salads and dessert and focus on the pizzas, come with a big group and sample a couple.  Try the Honey Jones pizza if they have it that night!!!

New owners are wonderful people and keep the PJ's of Princeton tradition alive with great food at reasonable prices. Most recently had delicious silver-dollar pancakes with ham and good coffee. Can't wait to return for some of the non-breakfast items!
Good food.  Average service

Mediocre food with good services. However, I had to wait over 20 minute for my food since appetizer and it kills my appetite. It would speed up the process more if the chefs in the open kitchen would get down to cooking instead of checking their phones for texts from grandma.

Bomb A$# Polish Food I'm a big fan of Russian food and knew that Polish food was similar but with a twist and a greater focus on sausage and pierogies. This was my first Polish food experience and this was the right place to pop my (Polish food) cherry. The menu options are great and since I wanted to try a few things, I went for the Polish Platter (3 pierogies, kielbasa, stuffed cabbage, bigos and potatoes). I also got the White Borscht to kick things off. All of the food was delicious with the beef pierogie and stuffed cabbage being my favorite. Can't wait to come back for more. Other notes: customer service was good and cash only.

As with Steph C., I'm writing this review mainly to big up Bruegger's from its current low rating -- it's really a 3-star place, but I'm giving it a 4.  I spent a lot of time at Brueggers while I was living in New Haven.  The bagels definitely are not up to New York standards, but what is, in New Haven?  The bagels here are nonetheless the best in town -- fresh, satisfying, and chewy.  There's free wireless, and you can stay here all day working and no one minds (I wrote large parts of my execrable third-year paper here).  I don't remember the service being either particularly good or particularly bad, so I'd say it was fine for the price I was paying (I should note that because I was a student at the time I was never really in much of a rush).
I reached there at 2:00 pm. Waiting for 15minutes because I just need one seat. Very very good food!
Salads are great.  Service at times, slow.

i've been going to govinda's for three years now, but have only been a vegetarian for one year.  before i went veg, i ate meat almost every single meal and swore by it, but govinda's was the only place i'd eat fake meat.  i've only ever gotten the "chicken" quesadilla, but every time i go it is amazing. large portion, delicious, and definitely worth the price.  i cannot comment on any other dish they serve but judging from my friends' reactions, the "chicken" cheesesteak is also to die for. AWESOME vegetarian comfort food in a city that sometimes thinks "vegetarian" means quinoa and vegetables only. however, i do refuse to give a full five stars to govinda's because from working in the industry for six years, i can tell that the main man himself (the owner) is a little bit of a jerk.  being a veg for the past year has made me well aware of the high price of fake meat, so i don't even contest govinda's considerably inflated prices.  what i DO contest is their lack of staff.  i honestly feel bad for the people who work here, because almost every time i go they are SO busy, and i've never seen more than one cashier and one cook working at a time.  this makes the very long line move extremely slowly, and probably somewhat affects business.  the staff always seems so overworked, it is no wonder that other reviews have mentioned their attitudes or unwillingness to smile.  they have no time to be nice!  mr. govinda, whoever you are, you are clearly making lots of money off of this very busy place.  try to come off of your high horse and share some of your profits by hiring/scheduling a few more people on busy nights.  remember that it is these cooks and cashiers, not you, that ultimately make the food delicious.  also remember that if you do spend some of your precious profits on scheduling an extra person or two, it will make the line move faster, please customers better, and will ultimately be more lucrative for you in the end.
I had the brunch buffet and it was absolutely divine. Quite pricey but delicious. Top quality coffee and tea and well stocked tables with great dessert as well.

Hearth is a must! The salad with white anchovies is the perfect summer appetizer. The Duck breast with confit is delicious! The fois gras dish provides the perfect balance of tart, sweet, buttery, and bitter, between all its accouterments. And the pork loin is truly satisfying, served with yummy sweetbreads. The deserts are good. But nothing out of this world. Overall I would say that Hearth is a master at combining flavors and textures. Everything is a joy to eat.

Okay was here last weekend with some friends and tried to get in for lunch but was to busy and the line was to long to get in (yes a line to get in all day long) so we went back for dinner.. Now the place is packed so it is a bit confusing to understand at first but once you get the idea it's not so bad.. There is so much to choose from all over the store, we decided just to get a few things to try. Prices are okay maybe a bit on the high side, but I feel you are paying for the experience too. We waited for about ten minutes for a table which you just have to be quick to grab one when available. We were in the meat and cheese dept., so there is only standing room tables. We ordered a meat and cheese platter with a bottle of wine, which I thought it was all a bit pricey for the portion they gave us but, and it's the experience to.. Coffee was very good, and the Gelatto was very close to the real deal. So if your in the city a must look at least, but I would probably keep away from there during the Holidays, I want to go back after the newness wares off to get a better experience.

This is the best place for Cuban food.  I usually try to get there before twelve to get a table.  The place is very small and very uncomfortable but the food is fantastic.  Everything I have is delicious including the Cuban sandwich, chicken diablo sandwich, fish taco and the corn.

Went to Moshulu with my wife and two other couples on a visit to Philadelphia. We all had different items and all agreed that this was one of the best meals any of us had had anywhere in ages. To be clear, we 6 have dined together around the world and around the US so while we're not gourmets, we do know a great meal and excellent service when we see it. The lobster bisque was outstanding as were the mussels. I had off-the-bone spareribs that were tender, juicy and very flavorful surround by a yummy vegetable puree. The wine list was as complete as I needed though I'm not an oenophile. The service was impeccable - polite, prompt, efficient, unobtrusive. Being on a sailing barque was neat too which permitted a stroll on the deck for a breath of fresh air after dinner. Highly recommended to our Philly friends. Overall, an excellent conclusion to our visit.

I have been to this special Thai restaurant twice, and the only reason I'm giving it four stars is because of my relative disappointment with the first dish I ordered. The first time around, I ordered tilapia sauteed in a spicy (hell yes!) chili sauce with eggplant. Though overal it was ok, I was disappointed at the excessive oiliness with this particular dish, as well as what ended up being a rather tough bunch of eggplant half the time. The second time (a.k.a today), I ordered Chinese broccoli sauteed with saltfish with a side of brown rice. At $8.50 all together, I found this to be a filling financial freebee, with plenty of spice (and saltiness) to make me finish the whole damn thing!
