Awesome. I remember I took one of my 1st girlfriends here on a date here 15-16 years ago, it's BYOB so we didn't get carded.  I got laid that night in my Gram-mom's car afterwards. Bangin, son!!

Welcome to Brooklandia, a not very funny parody of an uptight locavorian nightmare. Arrived on a recent Saturday evening to find the place empty, despite the Saturday Night ribs special. Problem was you had to order a full rack, enough to feed a family of four, for $50. Apparently the kitchen lacks knives sharp enough to cut the ribs into human-sized portions. So much for the special. So I ordered a burger and shortly received a glistening slab of ground beef with melted cheese, a bun, and some pickles. No lettuce or tomato. I asked the waitress whether they might happen to have a tomato in the kitchen, whereupon she flushed and said, No, we have no tomatoes in the kitchen. That's a shame, I said. Might they have a bit of lettuce to liven up the extra boring burger? No, no lettuce. But wait, I countered, you serve salads don't you? And didn't you just describe the beautiful local bib lettuce purchased from the farmers market that very morning? Would you mind asking the chef if he could spare a single piece of lettuce, pretty please? She flushed a bit more and said she would ask, but she wasn't promising success. A short time later she returned and said that the chef would consent to give me some lettuce, but that he was going to have to cut it for me. Hurray, he does have a knife after all! Seconds later, a plate appeared bearing four stately leaves. Joy! After we had finished eating, a fellow at the next table asked if he might also have some lettuce on his burger. No, the waitress said, we don't put lettuce on our burgers. But _they_ got lettuce, he pointed out, as she tried to justify the refusal of basic burger garnish. Eager to help, we passed the remaining two leaves across the table. Don't worry dude, we've got you covered. Nothing worse than a badly dressed burger.

We've eaten here at least ten times. Every time, food, service & ambience are great. I get chicken rostivados (sp); my partner, steak or salmon. Always great. The staff are always attentive but not on top of you. We love the place! Best restaurant on this side of the Q. And one of the best on both sides.

this is my favorite thai in the city. if there is better i don't know about it. i love this place because i have asked on several occasions if there is fish sauce or whatever in the curry and i always get a very clear answer as though my question was understood. the answer is always "oh no we don't use fish sauce, we use vinegar [or maybe salt, i forget now], and it's totally vegan if you get it with tofu." that's what i like to hear. no bewildered stare. no awkward pause and "let me go ask the chef" as though the question has never been posed before. plus it's fucking good. the red curry with tofu and the basil with mock duck are my favorites.
The skirt steak, mussels, and shrimp tamales are INSANE.

Not sure how the food is but based on my phone experience they fail.   Mothers 82 birthday with her fraternal twin.  Made reservations for 18 two weeks prior.  Told them we need  handicap access around tables. The morning of the dinner they called me telling me the upstairs may be too tight and if I prefer the basement room.  I asked if they had elevators.  They said no but would use four personnel to carry anyone in a wheel chair down 12 stairs!  Are you kidding me!   I told them we would stay upstairs.  I thought I better ask about bathroom access and yes it was downstairs as well. So much for making my life easy and avoiding trying to find a place for 18 on a Saturday but I prevailed.  I always thought if you want the best Spanish/Portuguese food you need to go to the Iron Bound  of Newark.   Please see my review of Don Pepe 2 in Pine Brook.  It may save you a trip to newark.hht
It's still hard to find good Mexican food in NYC. This place is a rare exception to that fact.
i love to get there hazelnut ice cream there. can't seem to find it anywhere else. i also get crepes there but it's nothing special.

This was not our first time at Jane and will most certainly not be our last! For starters we got the gnocchi and goat cheese flat bread. Let's just say the gnocchi was truly a mound of gooey cheesy soft fluffy pillows that were absolutely heavenly. Have never had a better plate of gnocchi and cannot wait to go back for more! The goat cheese flat bread was also delicious, covered in sauteed onions and a TON of goat cheese. Warning: the portion size is pretty big and definitely has plenty of goat cheese on it. Good thing we love goat cheese but we were also glad that we decided to share our entree after we ordered this! As if these two apps. weren't enough the waiter was nice enough to bring us out a sample of the scallop special and a taste of the meatball appetizer. The hash which came under the scallop was delicious and the pine nuts mixed in with the meatballs were a nice touch. While these were great, the goat cheese flat bread and gnocchi appetizers still stole the show. For our entree, we shared the Jane Burger. The burger was done just right with a crusty bun and absolutely delicious crispy fries. Once again the portion size was very nice and we really enjoyed the rosemary that was mixed in with the fries. While everything was delicious, make sure you save room for dessert! The milk and cookies was by far the best thing of the night. We were served  3 LARGE warm chocolate chip cookies which were sweet and perfect. Next to the cookies was a tall glass of cold milk with a scoop of vanilla ice cream inside. Truly a match made in foodie heaven!! Overall, this place gets a 5! The service was wonderful and food was just divine! We can't wait to go back!
Fun atmosphere. And hmmm that smell of chocolate is so inviting. Friendly and knowledgeable staff. Will definitely go back and recommend!!

It's not the best Singaporean/Malaysian joint in town (that honor goes to Taste Good Malaysian), but it's still very dependable. My first issue - they don't serve true Singapore laksa here.  That's just heresy!  Asam laksa is okay, but unless you like a sour/fish-based broth, Singapore laksa is just better.  They have a similar substitute in the form of Curry Mee, but it's just not the same.  However, at least the CM has good flavor and will satisfy most folks looking for a rich, savory broth to go with their noodles. The Hainan chicken rice here is fine, but note the portions aren't that big.  You'll probably need to add another side like their solid roti, statay tofu or satay chicken/beef skewers to feel satisfied.  Other notables include the beef rendang, which is fairly good.  Their nasi lemak is also pretty good, and does remind me of the ones I used to eat when I was living in SE Asia.   If you're in the city, this is a great place to consider.  But if you're serious about Singaporean/Malaysian food, definitely consider Taste Good in Elmhurst.

I Love this place!  Every time I visit Slate it just gets better and better.  I always have an Old Fashion - it is the best in the city, make that my entire life.  The burger was perfection.  The Owner and all staff are fabulous.  This is my go to place when I have friends visiting Philadelphia.

This is my go-to place for dinner in Princeton! Dining in Princeton is not exactly a foodie mecca but this place does not disappoint. Online booking is super easy and they have always been ready to seat us when we arrive. This is the little sister restaurant of Elements, which is a super fancy fine dining restaurant on 206. I much prefer Mistral because of the atmosphere, price and small plates options. I've tried almost every dish on the menu and nothing has disappointed; however, my absolute favorites are the foie gras, Korean bar-b-q octopus and the pork belly salad. The combinations are different and very tasty. Desserts also are amazing. The brown butter cake is phenomenal! They usually switch it up a bit but this is one of the consistent dessert offerings I believe. It's BYOB which I love so bring a bottle of your favorite wine to enjoy.

All I can say about this place is that the Pizza, especially the Sicilian is just awesome.  Everything I've ever ordered from here is always delicious!  My mouth is watering just writing this review and thinking about all the great food they have! I can't wait until my next visit !

This is one of the best places to eat in Astoria. I've never had a bad experience here and I go at least once every other month. If you can catch it, get the tomato soup. I recommend Il Bambino to all my friends.

This place is pretty good for a must trafficked tourist cheesesteak joint. Also waaay better than Geno's. They serve it chopped style, and a "whiz wit" style is chopped steak, onions, and wiz slathered all on top of it. Delicious, but more oily and less flavor in the meat than other cheesesteak joints I liked (like Jim's). Still, very decent and worth a visit if you are in the area. If you are a visitor and have time for cheesesteak-touring, you should give Pat's/Geno's a try but DEFINITELY try the other highly rated steak places. Service is really nice, friendly, and they look like they are having fun here. My friend had to order a 'steak with provolone for a friend and he got hassled, but it was all in good humor.

I live one block from Double Windsor so I hang out there at least once a week.  Yesterday I had a bad experience. I was with my husband and 4 friends, we were sitting at the bar.  Three of my friends went to smoke outside. I was at the bar with my friend.  When my others friends came back they realized that the drinks were taken away and some money too.  We ask the bartender what happened with the drinks that were almost full and she told us that we shouldn't leave drinks at the bar.  So where else can we leave the drinks if we are sitting there and we just want to smoke?? She didn't even apologize for taking the drinks, she  made fun about my friend's accent, putting a nasty smile saying "I can't understand you" when she spoke to her perfect english. I am sad that DB hired somebody like her when they have such an amazing bartenders like John and Kate.

My wife and I had the opportunity to have lunch at Whiskey Village on a recent trip, who could pass on a burger with glazed cippolini onions, and foie gras? The Village Burger did not disappoint. Juicy, thick and well seasoned, this is a delicious bit of ground beef heaven. The duck fat fries were decadent and perfectly crisp and salted. My hot brown was equally tasty with just enough smoky bacon and creamy mornay sauce to turn roast turkey into a sublime morsel. We ate at the bar, made new friends and savored a delectable lunch. A couple of pints of a local IPA complemented the meal perfectly. Chef Garces has a hit...keep up the good work!

I just really had a great time here for happy hour. Mind you, I almost always eat alone so when I say I had a great time I am having it by myself. I didn't talk to anyone (except the servers) but it was so enjoyable. The service was amazing, and the happy hour food was fantastic. I had oysters and salt cod. I will make the trek from Brooklyn to Manhattan regularly for this happy hour.

FYI this is an _Austrian_ place. Not German. Similar, but different! I came with a friend at 8:30 on a Sunday night and got a table almost immediately. This had me pretty thrilled as it is usually not the case at Katja. We started by sharing the beet salad with caraway, goat cheese, and pumpkinseed oil--all in all it was pretty fantastic though I wished the taste of the pumpkinseed oil came through a little more, and that the caraway seeds were integrated a little better. They were just sprinkled raw on a hunk of goat cheese. We both had a liptauer sandwich (my favorite, and ridiculously inexpensive at $6), which is a fresh cream-like cheese with paprika over a slice of toasted bread, sprinkled with fresh diced radish and served with a pickled veggie garnish. We lingered with a glass of wine for a while and eventually settled on the warm chocolate cake with cherry compote. This was not really the highlight of the meal. The cake was too densely chocolate for my taste, not very hot, the accompanying whipped cream was kind of sour (?) and the cherry compote was also a little sour and didn't seem very fresh. I wish we would've tried the fig and almond tart. If I come back soon, I'll definitely give that a whirl. We payed a little over $30 a piece and stayed for over 3 hours. The waitress was a teeny bit obsequious but didn't seem hostile after we stayed for so long. All in all a great meal, and I'll be back a bunch more.

Good, solid neighborhood spot. I've been coming here on and off through the years. The pancakes are delightful and the eggs are cooked just right. But.... the service doesn't come with a smile. On a recent visit in November 2011, our server had an attitude that was as cold as ice. S/he was pissy dispite the fact we had no special orders or requests. Oh, s/he was nice to some folks, just not us. A little too clique-y for my taste.
I come here for their Gelatos and Pizzas, pretty much what they're known for.
This an amazing place. Normally i dont like vegetarian sushi as the taste does not make sense. But here, the vegetarian Sushi are amazing.. unimaginable and super tasty!

The atmosphere here is kind of dark and romantic, so don't bring someone here when trying to keep them in the friend zone. Just saying. Overall: love the curry, pad thai is not great. Hate that they only take cash. Not my favorite Thai in the world, but I've yet to a find a favorite Thai place in Philly.
A new pizza joint? This city's a one trick town But worth trying here.
Not vegan friendly.  Just wanted a fresh salad of raw veggies and the staff had difficulty accommodating.

Awesome place, amazingly affordable. We just stumbled upon the place when visiting New York, and loved the place. Their affordable appetizers ($2.90-$3.90 each) provides a great selection and variety. We had a great tofu dish, never loved tofu as much. On Saturday, the beer was half price.
The sicilian slice at L&B is ridiculously good.  The traditional pie is mediocre.  Definitely worth a trip to experience the ultimate sicilian slice.

When did this place open up?  WOW!!!  This has become my new favorite restaurant in Newark!! The food is incredible!  SO FLAVORFUL  The portion sizes are out of this world!  .. and the people that work there are SO friendly!! They seem to always have some different selecitons on their menu, but I highly recommend the Tilapia filet or the Charcoal Chicken entree.  As for the sides, they have GREAT yams, spinach, rice/beans, just to name a few... The homemade yogurt is DELICIOUS as well, but make sure to ask what desserts they have that day, because the Brownie Sundae is OUT OF THIS WORLD!!! *PS - they have a lunch special for only $6.99 that includes a meat or fish, 2 sides and a drink!!! I'M IN LOVE!!!!!  : )

This place is beautiful and delicious, a great spot for a late meal on a weekend night.  No matter what ramen you get, make sure you get the kakuni (pork belly) it'll make it taste that much better.  Also, I love the calpico cocktail they make- anything with Calpico is delicious!  One caveat, of course, is the wait- you can wait anywhere from 45min-1-1/2hours for a table of 2.  It's always packed here, for good reason.  It's still worth it, though, because once you sit down and get your noodles, you'll forget all about how long you waited for it...

Absolutely the BEST dining experience since going gluten free!  My husband later told me he didn't think I was that happy on our wedding day!  (Sorry, babe.)  Gluten free bread sticks are AMAZING, the risotto was awesome, and the carrot cake rivaled my grandmother's.  My entire Gluten eating family enjoyed the menu too! This is the first time in almost 3 years I have ordered from a menu and not worried about getting sick later.  THANK YOU Risotteria- you are a God send.

Heidi's House always come up when searching for a good place to eat on the UES, but for some reason I always passed over it. However, it is certainly worth a try. The restaurant is tiny, maybe seats 25 people between small tables and the bar. The ambiance is cozy. It is usually crowded and they don't take reservations. Although, they will take your phone number and call you when a table is ready, since there is absolutely no place to wait other than the sidewalk. If you don't want to wait, I recommend trying it on the early or late side and maybe you'll get lucky! The service is good. The server never rushes you even with people waiting for tables. They have both a good wine and beer list. Everything I've had from here is simple, good, comfort food. They usually have a pasta of the day. The crab dip and mac n cheese are definite winners.
This place is iconic and for good reason. The food is outstanding and as much as I hate crowds, I'm willing to deal with it here for the food. Yum

If Michael Jackson were still alive, he would probably eat here with his kids. If they were open on Sundays, I would try and figure out how to give them six stars. I need those breakfast sandwiches on the weekends!!!

Very very good food . The menu is not extensive but interesting.  You can have everything from pork belly to seafood to bone marrow , duck salad or steak . They also have Sunday Italian specials which is not my thing but worth mentioning . I had the octopus salad for appetizers , and Florida grouper with beat salad and mushroom custard . Nice ! Hoping they don't move the location to metropolitan ave and fall of the map because this little spot is perfect

So passed El Vez almost everyday on my way to work, but only made it last week for dinner finally! Before i get to food, let me talk about the Restroom first. I like me some fancy-fun restrooms, and El Vez provided. Totally made me want to just hang out downstairs and chill [no i dint do that]. We got a pitcher of the Pineapple Margarita. It was good, but im not a big fan of cinnamon nor sugar on the rim for my Margarita. So that was a bit sad, but im smart enough to know its a great Margarita. Next comes the guac! My brown self can make some killer guac folks, so I'm hard to please when it some to it. When we saw the "Indian Red" Lopez Guacamole with spicy crab, cilantro, salsa roja, it was a no brainer. It was delicious, and i love the fact they use flour tortillas for their chips! The lump of crabs in every bite with a tad bit of salsa roja was a nice balance and good way to play up your everyday guacamole. There is probably not enough taco for me on this earth. We split the Shrimp taco and the Mahi Mahi Tacos. They looked adorable, the Mahi Mahi tacos look like little bundles of joy tied like a gift. Never thought breaded fish would work inside a taco, sounds redundant since its sitting inside a tortilla, but it was SUPERB with the little slaw inside. Shrimp tacos with the sweet bits of pineapple was spot on. Neither of them not dry at all, neither soggy. Loved it No complaints here, I just needed more Margaritas. Hehe.

This place was great! I had no reservation, the host made special arrangements for us because the place was packed full of people. Sat right in the garden, and even enjoyed a special shot of chocolate grappa on the house. They made us feel so special, the food was great, atmosphere was very intimate. We went downstairs to enjoy jazz music after the meal. Great night, great place! Highly recommend

I really enjoy the miso braised beef sandwich. The beef is so tender and the miso sauce is delicious! Had the so a noodles once and they had promise, but didn't have as much of a flavor kick as I would have liked. Overall, this is a great place for a quick and delicious sandwich!

its small but the food is good! They're always open, service is quick. I went straight for the Mac & Cheese, didn't realize it was such a popular item but OMG, I savored every bite, I just wish it was bigger it's a small plate but it was delicioussss. Fun, hip, friendly staff. Open 24Hrs?? Will I come back again?  possibly.  especially for brunch!

I get out here about once a month give or take. The burgers are good, not really $8 good, but they have interesting combinations so between that and their fries I enjoy stopping by on occasion. I've had both good experiences here and bad. Last night I had the Koreatown burger which was quite good, they even fried the egg on it for me. The last time I had a burger with an egg here they refused to do so. I understand Bobby thinks all eggs should be sunny side up but a half raw egg is going to make me puke, end of story. I had tried to get them to put my egg back on the grill for the whole 20-30 seconds it would take to finish cooking but apparently that was too much trouble. The fries and onion rings here are great, which is an interesting contrast to their burger and fry sauce which are both universally vile. The horseradish sauce that comes with the sweet potato fries is pretty good though. I also like their shakes. I usually go with the black & white but their vanilla caramel bourbon is pretty good as well.

Definitely the best vegetarian pho in the city. The pho comes packed with vegetables like broccoli, bok chuy, green beans, carrots, potatoes, bean sprouts, etc. And is served so flavorful you don't even need to add any extra sauce. A delight.

Best fries ever, seriously. The hamburgers are also very good, I always go for a double-cheeseburger (or two) rather than the normal cheeseburger because the patties are of the thin variety.  The shakes are decent, and in the summer the ice cream goes down really well.
delicious! pork chop stuffed with crayfish is amazing!

Chicken liver wrapped in bacon, I shall come back for you!!! I never knew what Serbian food was about until I randomly passed by Kafana one winter night and gave it a shot.  The place is cozy, candlelit and very charming. Now I dont remember exactly all the dishes we ordered but I do remember liking most of them. With the meat-laden food selection [insert huge grin here] portioned generously and reasonably priced, how can one go wrong?   It was a wonderful experience. Note: Cash Only

This is my number one pick for Italian food in the New Haven area. In my experience, it has always been consistent and stays true to those tastes I will always long for, like rigatoni vodka,etc. IMO if you havn't tried it, then you are missing out on one of those little gems New haven has to offer.

I like to come to this restaurant in the spring and summer.  The patio is wonderful.  Feeding the fish is fun to do while waiting for a great meal.  I ususally order a salad with grilled salmon. The bread is great here, too.

This is a fantastic place for lunch or mini break. Hidden on Audubon Street it is worse any walk to get to Pure Health Lounge. The salads are great and the Power Punch- a fresh squeezed juice (carrots, orange and apples) tastes great. The Mango Madness taste is delicious as well. Wait time very short and the service is excellent!

I'm still dreaming of chicken and rice and lamb swimming in delicious white sauce with a sprinkling of hot sauce.  Over 600 reviews and 4.5 stars?  'Nuff said, this is the epitome of good street food so I won't bother you with the details.   We were starving and while I thought the 15 minute wait would be interminable, I think it enhanced the experience.  Once my friends and I had commandeered our wares, we copped a squat at a nearby bench that unfortunately was surrounded by pigeons (my friend has issues with them).  Those bastard pigeons were eyeing our food ferociously, and for good reason because it was just plain ol delicious.  I can't even go into detail about how and why it was so good.  I got chicken but should have gotten a half and half or gone for the lamb because my friend's lamb and rice was orgasmic!   Good for lunch, great for drunk nights after the club. Quick, efficient service and yea the guy taking my order does get points for handing me my change, looking down my shirt, and saying "Nice, baby."  That's exactly the kind of thing I was waiting for when I went to NYC and he didn't disappoint.

HEAVEN ON EARTH FOR FOODIES, COOKS, VISITORS & PEOPLE WATCHERS: No matter how many times we visit Philadelphia, Reading Terminal Market is a MUST for us. On this visit, we employed a new strategy...head straight to the restaurant vendors and eat! (Beck's Cajun Café can go head-to-head with New Orleans eateries any day). With our bellies full of exceptionally good food, we could then wander among the multi-sensory seduction of meats, seafood, candy, coffee, pastries, breads, cheeses, olive oils, and more without buying everything within our reach. It's not a fool-proof strategy but it did reduce the urge to splurge. When our feet got tired, sitting down with a cup of Old City Coffee rejuvenated us for more browsing. Once we declared our visit complete, we were delighted to relax with a glass of wine and draft beer right in the heart of the action at Molly Malloy's. By-the-way, don't miss The Tubby Olive with 30 olive oils and balsamic vinegars "on tap" for tasting and take home. The next morning we ditched our free hotel breakfast buffet and headed back to the Market for breakfast and a few more goodies!

Pat's has always been the better between the two rivals.  The best cheesesteak to get is Wit Wiz classic philly food here and a great place to go late a night especially on the weekend when the most interesting crowds of people come

I can't understand why people don't like this Place. This is honestly the best Tex Mex I've eaten. Great Food with fresh homemade tortillas, cheap prices, fast friendly service.. Seriously? What is to complain about. Yeah, its a quick service restaurant, with no waiters and no table cloths, but who cares? I go here at least once a week. I used to go 3 to 5 times when I worked closer. Annie and her gang are the sweetest people around.

Ate at Geno's on a recent trip to Philadelphia. The sandwich was good, but I liked Pat s best. Everyone in my group seemed to have a different take on the Pat's vs Geno's debate, so I guess it's just a matter of personal preference. Try em both and decide for yourself!

The food was descent. and the margaritas had enough tequila but were lacking something. The prices were appropriate. I think this is probably a better happy hour spot rather than somewhere you should expect to get the best food. And the service was very slow. It took 30 min to get our bill and it was difficult to order more drink and chips! I would go back if invited, but wouldn't choose it over other mexican food in the area.

Mind blowingly delicious. Had the oxtail which was so rich, so many different textures and flavors, and we had the shrimp with coconut. So so good. Small place so not the quickest but it's fresh and amazing! Good prices too!

This place is great!! I'm a huge fan of bricl oven pizza. Every pizza i've had here is amazing. Someone ordered a pastat with sausage and broccoli rabe which was also amazing! Even the bread is fresh from their own bakery. The vibe is great for a date night or a family dinner. Everyone is friendly and this place has nice history to it. I grew up the street from here and would smell the pizza and bread every day while I swam in my pool. I would crave it all the time. NIce to be a grown up and go whenever I want!

I'm a big fan of Garces - a number of his restaurants are some of my favorites in Philadelphia. GTC is definitely another addition to this list. The service here is great - they give you just the right amount of attentiveness. Their complimentary bread basket is decent, but it's their extra virgin olive oil that's the star of this dish. It's very fruity and fragrant, which is a nice alternative to your normal bread and butter. We shared the house-made mozzarella as an appetizer - it's an exceedingly simple dish. Just quality mozzarella, olive oil, salt, and pepper. I had the pappardelle with lamb ragu for my entree. They're very generous with how much meat they give you. The tender English peas really brightened up the heavy pasta. I thought my plate could have used more of the Sunchoke purée though. The pasta was perfectly cooked but it did start to stick together and became somewhat of a doughy mess by the end of my meal. My friend had the vichyssoise chaude and a side of their famous house duck fat fries. The warm potato leek soup was poured and presented at the table, which was a nice bit of unexpected dinner entertainment. The fries were delicious and lived up to the hype. I'm definitely going to come back to try their lyonnaise duck salad - it sounds AMAZING.

I miss my MSG! OK, make that salt. The touchscreens are a nice idea, though I can imagine the line they can form during rush hours. I ordered a stir-fry and a smoothie, and the thing that struck me wired, was that my smoothie was served at one end of the counter, and the stir-fry ended showing up at the other side of the counter.  Seriously now, why can't they just be served together, don't really care where on the counter- left side- right side or middle, but I found this a little bit confusing.
Took my father here - for Fathers Day! Great food, Great atomsphere! Loved it! Our server was great! Would highly reccomend!

Our friend told us about Bohemia and we were amazed at the great experience. The food, the service were all first rate. The food was superb, each dish served by itself having perfect presentation, taste and aroma. The flavors were outstanding. Our server was very personable but not intrusive. We will not forget our experience. Bravo Bohemian!

theres a lot of hype for this place but for some reason i thought it was just ok. the line to get in is totally ridiculous. we waited for about an hour wc is totally fine with me. the line of people waiting outside was crazy! and when they call out someones number people jump up and cheer like they just won the lottery. hahaha. it was funny. inside, its a typical chinese restaurant. lazy susans galore. the pork and crab soup dumplings were good but not like oh emm gee amazing. tasted like any other dumpling ive had. and the other dishes we had like gen tsaos chicken and i think sweet and sour chicken were also alright. same as any chinese place. so overall i thought it was a pretty average chinese restaurant. idk if its wortht he long line outside.

After passing Pylos' beautiful dining area and reading so many fantastic reviews, this spot jumped to the top of my destination list.  The restaurant denoted its culinary point of view as "rustic Greek home cooking", which it truly personified.  The elegant, yet homey space included several intimate tables and a large wooden block island for large groups.  This party space overlooked a massive wine showcase, which gave off the impression that you were eating in someone's kitchen.  The ceiling was adorned with clay pots, also accentuating this country-style theme. My friend and I were blessed with a fantastic server that enlightened us on the Greek wine list and provided friendly recommendations on the food menu as well.  We placed our order and chatted over a large complimentary plate stacked high with warm pita points and a savory red pepper hummus spread. We began our meal with the Htapothi Scharas - slices of grilled, marinated octopus with capers and a balsamic reduction glaze.  The octopus was expertly crisp and devoid of any chewiness, but the balsamic reduction had sadly been over-cooked, giving the dish a subtly charred flavor. My entree of Poached Salmon was perfectly cooked.  As is typical with poached preparations, my fish was on the bland side, but I knew that would be the case when I ordered it.  However, it was served over an unbelievable spinach-rice pilaf.  The topping sauce of sun-dried tomatoes and olives was briny, tart, and hearty all at once.  The dish was very rustic and possessed a Mediterranean flare. My friend's Organic, Boned Chicken Farci was beyond tender.  A lightly crisped skin added texture to the juicy meat within.  The chicken was stuffed with sweet raisins, rosemary, thyme and Kasseri cheese.  It was served with Briam, which was a marinaded mixture of zucchini, eggplant, and potatoes.  The large portion was comforting and fantastic.   Pylos provided us with a complete meal in a dazzling environment.  It was a great way to begin our evening out on the town.

loved it! Was so in love with the juicy chicken. I also was blown away by the pumpkin pie. Yum!  was worth the travel and 40 minute wait. if you want that pecan donut, you should call in and order at opening time. they go quick. I loved the home fries and biscuit. everything was a home run. Can't wait to go back.

I went here for restaurant week. I took my date there and it was a nice atmosphere within the spot. The fish tacos were good. Just what I expected. The service was fine nothing over the top and nothing awful. My complaint was that it was getting cold and they had the door and the air on, we asked for them to fix either and they did not. Now no one likes to be uncomfortable while eating. That defiantly made me want to leave quicker. Other than that, the margaritas were delicious and so was the make your own guacamole. I would have preferred to sit in a booth since we made a reservation instead of a high table. I would have actually waited had I known I was going to sit with a draft on me. I would go back for happy hour. I think I can do without for an actual meal.
I have been here a couple of times for Sunday lunch buffet. Food is amazing with the right amount of spice. The food is mostly South Indian style and buffet comes with unlimited idlis and dosas!

My favourite ramen-ya in NYC! Although the wait-line is ridiculous, if you go there around the time they open, you don't have to wait too long. Just fill in your name and wait until you've been called. Totto Chicken Paitan Ramen (3/5) To be honest, I thought it was just okay...the broth was like chicken soup. Not what I wanted in a Japanese ramen-ya. Totto Miso Ramen (5/5) This is what I always get whenever I come here. I prefer the char-siu pork over the chicken to be honest. It also has a bit of an alcohol taste to it, although that is probably due to the miso (fermentation?). Totto Spicy Ramen (1/5) I realized that I don't like the rayu. It tastes too oily and very....artificial flavoured. Atmosphere: (3/5) Way too cramped. Extremely dark as well.

Little Owl, I want to love you. I really do. We've had a few nice evenings together and honestly, I think if things were different, it could work out between us. The problem is that none of my friends like you. Every time I bring my friends around, you make them mad. You sometimes serve a sub par piece of fish or kill your tuna lettuce wrap appetizer with salad dressing. Every once in a while you run out of an entree. You are always so friendly and they expect things to be great, but then something goes awry and I have to defend you. They tell me I should be spending my time somewhere else. They say there are better places in the West Village to spend my money. They say I am too good for you. I know I should just take their advice and walk away, but you have such a sweet, sweet pork chop. If you only served pork chops and meatball sliders, I would give you a 9.0 rating and we would move in together and have game night every Thursday. Think about it. We would be so happy. I made you a mix tape. immaculateinfatuation.com

Oh man, this place is really good! We came here for a late lunch, around 3:00pm on a dreary Saturday.  It was today in fact.  Rushing in before us was a crowd of about eight middle school kids with no manners.  There was pushing and shoving going on until everyone is situated.  Looking at the establishment from the outside, it appears to be hospitable.   That is, until you meet the really sweet lady at the counter that will kindly take your order.   We had the Fried Pork Dumplings and there are four per order for $1.50.  The Meat Sauce Noodles (Jajang Mein) was the perfect portion for me, since I am not much a soup eater and prefer the amazing taste of these noodles just by themselves.   For my husband, I ordered the Beef Stew Noodle soup.  The broth was not very heavy and had a mild five spice flavor and tender bites of beef.  You want to eat this quick because the noodles will get a tad soggy from sitting in the broth.   The noodles are springy to the bite and the perfect texture.  I would love to eat them with just scallion and chili oil.  It is fun to watch the cook hand pull the noodles to order and throw them in the pot.  He makes it look so easy, but you know it is not. Out total was only $12 for the entire meal including two cans of soda. I love that the food here does not have much oil or preservatives, my stomach thanks them.  Much better than my past experience at Tasty Hand Pulled Noodle in Manhattan Chinatown, that place made me sick immediately.  If I lived in the area, I would be getting take-out from here daily. I read somewhere that they also own the Hotpot place around the corner on Broadway, hope it get to try it before I move.

The service we received at the door by one of the bouncers was sub par. Questions asked were met without explanation or consideration. Our money given willingly for cover was given back to us when we asked for clarification. We are from out of town and didn't know the policies of Friday and Saturday night cover and only saw all others before us not paying cover and wondered aloud why we were being treated differently. Apparently there were several private parties. I wish the bouncer had taken the few seconds to explain that to us. This may have been an isolated incident and as I am not a mind reader I can only speak to how I felt and not the bouncers actual motivations, but I did feel disrespected at the door. After my previous review the leadership of this restaurant was very responsive. They have assured me they will make efforts to ensure no future experience like this occurs again. I believe them. I hope to have a better future experience here next time I'm in NYC because their passion for making their restaurant welcoming to all is clear from their follow up.

O MY GOD Immm sooo in love ... (Ok thats my intro, lol) I have been coming to Ishakabibble since I can remember with my Dad.... The best Chicken Cheese Steaks in the WORLD!!! as far as I know of.... Even try the Spinach chicken cheese steaks Please get a GREMLIN..... for those who don't know a GREMLIN is lemonade and grape juice mixed (5 stars) Now they serve sweet potato fries which are the best I really like them mixed with regular fries.

one of the best, if not the best BBQ place I've eaten at in the city. Also, they have great take out options for those nights you want good food and don't feel like cooking. Their ribs are delicous, and their pulled pork and beef brisket are the best I've ever had. Mac and cheese was definitely very good.

Classy!.... for a diner that is. Heck the food is way better than some other places that pass for high-end and the portions are generous. I found the best pancakes in the city here, and I'm a serious pancake critic. The staff are on it and the atmosphere is welcoming.  Yum!

These sliders are so money and they don't even know it. The regular slider $2 (cheese and onions only) is out of this world, and the bacon slider for $2.75 beats any regular burger period. Bold statement, I know. The meat is so perfectly done and seasoned, with the bacon mixed in so you almost don't notice it's there... caramelized onions and melted cheese... the bun is soft and buttered. Fries are fresh cut, crispy and shareable. I slightly considered stealing the jalapeno sauce. Great beers (including Sixpoint, Hoegaarden) all for $4, wine for $5. The place is small and easily missed just in from the corner of 2nd and St. Mark's. (across from Khyber Pass) Overall, it's clean and has a good vibe ... and the food's so good you won't notice or care.
The chefs are excellent and accommodating. The wait staff is outstanding. The bartenders are amazing.

Excellent meal and experience. Very knowledgable staff- our server and the bartender were able to describe and recommend cocktails with ease. I really, really appreciate it when a 'what does prickly pear taste like?' question is met with a legit and thoughtful answer. The mushrooms and salmon appetizer were awesome, and for the love of god, order the duck. That duck was perfect. The 'dirt' dessert was so unexpected but so good. This place definitely rivals any place in Montclair, and it was BUSY on a Thursday night. I can see why.

I had the wonderful pleasure of hosting my future sister-in-law's bridal shower at Luca's Ristorante in Somerset, NJ.  If I could give the restaurant 100+ stars I would.  It was impeccable service and attention from start to finish. I booked this bridal shower in advance two months ago from Florida.  Yes, I live in Florida.  This restaurant was suggested by my brother, the future groom.  When I called for information one evening they were very busy but Candice spent over half an hour with me on the phone giving me detailed information about the packages/prices they offered for private parties.  I called back a few days later and spoke to the owner, Chef Andrea DiMeglio and we were able to come to a menu and package that suited our needs and budget. Planning this bridal shower from Florida was quite stressful but Chef Andea was exceptionally accommodating and he knew the vision I wanted to create! I visited Luca's the day before the shower and Chef Andrea was there to show me the private room and go over the setup and menu.  I walked in the restaurant and my jaw dropped.  I felt like I was transported to Italy.  The décor in the restaurant is stunning.  The hand made ceramics from Italy were breathtaking. I knew in my heart that this was the place for the bridal shower.  Chef Andrea opened the restaurant an hour early for me the day of the shower.  Nick was my server and he was so attentive to the details from the lighting, the music, the temperature of the room, etc.  Everything was carefully planned.  I was calm because I knew that my party was in good hands. As the guests arrived I can see their expression and look of awe at the restaurant.  They could not believe their eyes!  Many of them said, "I feel like I am in Italy"!  There were 28 women at this bridal shower.  The guests arrived at 12:30pm and warm bread was immediately offered to them.  Luca's is a BYOB and the guests had their wine poured for them.  There is no drink table- very nice touch.  (Unless you want a drink table).  Each of the guests felt so important.  The bread alone was a meal in itself.  There were several different types of bread that just melted in your mouth.  The Rosemary bread was my favorite.  All the bread was served with seasonings drenched in extra virgin olive oil. The guest of honor arrived at 1pm and I could tell she was just amazed.  The tears in her eyes were enough that I knew that Luca's was the place!  We had a champagne toast.  Appetizers and salads came out promptly.  Food was generous.  Salad was fresh and plentiful and the Italian dressing was delightful.  We had fried calamari and fried zucchini as appetizers.  There was so much on the plate!  These were prepared fresh.  The zucchini was divine!  The best fried zucchini I have ever had.  My niece commented that it was the best fried calamari she has ever eaten! Our server Nick as well as the other servers who helped were so professional.  They dressed profession and addressed everyone by their names.  They were attentive to everyone's needs from drinks to simple things like food allergies.  They knew who were the vegetarians in the group, as well as paying special attention the children in the party.  I cannot say enough about them!!!! They are wonderful!!!  They kept eye contact with me and knew what I was thinking.  Everything was perfect.  Just perfect. Our entrees consisted of a choice of chicken marsala, chicken monte bianco or eggplant rollatini.  The presentation of each entrée was a work of art.  The guest of honor commented that the Chicken Marsala was "amazing" and "the best" she has had!  Chef Andrea made a special meal for my two nieces and my little 5 year old niece commented "these chicken fingers are the best ever"!  They were fresh chicken strips made from chicken breasts.  Truly impressive! After the main meal we opened presents.  We brought our own cake and Luca's did not charge a cutting or plate fee.  Dessert and coffee was served.  The coffee was so smooth....love it! The staff coffee was so smooth....love it! The staff at Luca's helped us carry all the heavy gifts out to our car.  They also wrapped up the food that the guests could not finish.  They provided these extraordinary heavy duty take out brown bags with handles for the guests.  Their take out containers were so fancy! This place is heaven.  It is a gem!  I highly highly, highly recommend this restaurant.  The food is incredible.  I visit Las Vegas 2-3 times a year for conferences and this restaurant and their food surpasses the quality of food at the high end Italian restaurants in Vegas. I will definitely return every time I am in NJ.  Chef Andrea does what he does best....creating wonderful food and atmosphere with love and passion.  The prices are reasonable and fair.  It is family here.  I had the wonderful opportunity to meet Chef Andrea's father and brother.  It is a piece of heaven!

Cute little place with delicious food!   It's cash only and it's VERY small inside so be prepared to wait if you come during peak hours. The waitlist system is kind of confusing.  There's no real hostess so you just walk in and write your name on a clipboard.  When I went, one group had taken someone else's spot or crossed their name off.   The prices are better than nearby Ippudo, but they don't have as many other dishes.  If you're in the mood for ramen at an off hour, definitely go here.  If you have a big group who want to eat a variety of dishes, go somewhere else.
It's like a slice of japan on 38th street! Delicious curry with all the proper toppings. A little cheesey with the "55" thing, and getting a seat can be hard but this is still my favorite lunch

since Hurricane Sandy I am really enthusiastic about  shopping local and eating at local restaurants since NJ got hit rather hard, I often check the deals on Groupon or Living Social deal to try new locations, I had seen Lalibela numerous times when I used to go to the gas station across the street I was happy to see an offer & purchased it immediately.   I was so pleased by the atmosphere when I walked in, a quaint little place with very attractive decor and several couples sitting at tables.  I walked up to the counter where a very pleasant young man stood I explained I'd never had Ethiopian.  I told him I'd need his help, he was more than happy to offer suggestions and ask my preferences.  Everything I selected was excellent.  I did not sit to eat I carried out, and there was so much food that I shared and still had plenty of left overs.  I plan to return today to try something else and plan to eat in.     Check it out I don't think you'll be disappointed!

This is one of my favorite chinese restaurants. I love their soft shell crab seasonal dish. I like that they fry it whole so all the insides (greenish yellowish gunk) of the crab is still in it to eat. The batter is also not too think, which is a plus. I also like their roast duck. It's very tasty! I also like their wonton noodle soup. I like the texture of the noodles here. They don't overcook their noodles, which is definitely a great thing. I also like their wontons here because it has good flavor and texture. Their soup here has good flavor too. If you order noodle soup for take out, tell them to separate the soup so the noodles don't become soggy.

On day we spontaneously got inside this place and had the Italian meat & cheese. it was so fresh and  authentic, and the Italian meat was the best that i've ever had in new york city so far.   I don't mind tiny table and standing for eating as long as food is that delicious.
I had the perfect evening here.  The food was superb and the service was just what I wanted.  This place is charming.  I would go back in a heartbeat.
The food and service has always been topnotch at Westville.  I like that they change the daily specials and it snot the same ol' thing.

I've been to Saxon + Parole twice - once for brunch and the other time for dinner. There were different aspects I liked from each of the meals. Brunch: really enjoyed the DIY bloody mary station. This was the highlight of the meal. The food was alright, nothing outstanding. In addition, the table next to us received their food before we did even though we were sat much earlier than them. Dinner: I ordered the diver scallops which were pretty good, however, pretty small in portion. We got sat in the back of the restaurant where there's more of a private seating area. It was much quieter than sitting in the main dining area, which was nice. I've also been to their sister restaurant, Public, which I overall like the food and dining experience better.
Great bar with great staff! Generous to the community and offer an inviting atmosphere! Go!!!!
The food is okay, service is slow and the ambience is terrible. For groups larger than four, they stick you in this dirty basement.

First time here. Went for Philly science week. Place is pretty large and has a nice outdoor area with fire pits. They also have a pingpong table and a ton of Jenga brick sets. They have large tables for 8-10 and smaller ones for 4. I saw a lot of people playing boardgames and having a blast. The beers are 7/14 for a half/liter for the most part. Good selection of beer and pretty solid food choices. I was surprised on how full this place was on an early Saturday afternoon, but its got the space for it. Food came out fast, I ordered a the frankfurt sausage? (beef one) it came with a good portion of sauerkraut and really good mustard. Got a Hofbrau and had a solid meal. Really want to come back for a happy hour and see what that's like. Hopefully on a less full stomach to try some more beers and food out.

WOW - the cheesecake was excellent.   Aside from the cheesecake, this review is about the BBQ food and customer service.  Let me take you through the chain of events: -I called to order delivery.  They said about 30 minutes. -One hour later they called me back and said "we cannot find our delivery guy, he is not answering his phone, can you come pick up your order, we will give you a discount, sorry" -My husband picked up the food and they did not include the delivery charge (thank you so much given we had to drive to pick up our order).   -When my husband arrived home, the food was ICE COLD, they forgot my sauce for my sandwich AND they also forgot the red velvet cake we ordered.   -If you understand the BBQ process of slow and low cooking and take the time to come up with a special sauce to compliment the slowly cooked meat, don't eat here.  They provide a la carte sauces that have no flavor.  The meat is most likely boiled.   WAIT!  THERE IS MORE! -I called to complain and when their employer put me on hold........she forgot about me.  I had to call back again. -Finally, I connected with the manager and explained what happened.  He hung up on me.  Yes, ladies and gentleman, the manager of the restaurant hung up on a customer. Did I mention the cheesecake is really good?

This place is an interesting one to review. We went there based on Yelp reviews and they have Open Table to get a res. When we got there at 8:00 on a Saturday night, it was kind of quite. That concerned us all. But we forged ahead.  We were seated upstairs which was fine, but too warm. Ambiance was ok, but nothing great. Good selection of beers and drinks. Then came the food. Wow! Everything was great. Definitely a surprise based on our experience up to that point. All 6 of us had something different and everything was awesome. Go for the food. Not much else.

Stopped by for lunch and got the Coco Cabana Vegetales lunch special with shrimp, black beans and salad. The salad was fine but the curry and beans were absolutely delicious. Additionally, the lunch special price brought the meal in at an affordable $27 (no liquor for me although there was a full bar - had a club soda). I will return because there were other dishes on the menu that I'd like to try.

I was really excited about going to Calle Ocho last night for a Restaurant Week dinner.  My husband and I went with another couple who had gone to the old location on their first date.  With the exception of the delicious bread basket, this is probably the worst meal I have had in NYC.  My husband and our friends all did the restaurant week menu, but I did not, as I had read reviews that the calamari frito and puerco (neither of which are on the unpublished Restaurant Week menu) were excellent.  I ordered both.  The calamari was heavily battered and fried and covered in a sweet and sour type sauce that was not good. My husband ordered the ceviche which had a strange mealy texture that made us wonder how old the fish was.  Our friends ordered the empanadas, which they liked, and may have been the only positive element to our meal.  The puerco I ordered for my entree tasted like airplane food, hardly any flavor and lukewarm. The rest of the group ordered steak, all cooked to medium.  When my husband cut into his, it was raw on the inside. The others cut theirs and it turns out that none of them were even cooked to rare. The server took them all back to have them cooked further. They were returned still undercooked.  Beyond that, they were doused on an A1-like steak sauce. Even the vegetables they came with were all covered in the sauce to a point that everything on the plate was unappetizing.  For dessert, we had the apple tart and the flan.  Flan is supposed to be light and delicate, this flan was overcooked and dense with a gel-like consistency. The apple tart was served cold with ice cream on top. The $1 apple pies at McDonalds are WAY better than this tart from Calle Ocho.  Our bill was $240 with drinks., which I felt really bad about considering how terrible the meal was.  I am at a loss as to how this restaurant could receive such great reviews. I think 1 star is generous.

5 stars for the crab or pork dumplings. You must try these dumplings when you are there. Other dishes are very good too, just the service is not that great but it's understandable because it's always busy at this restaurant.

I was actually really excited that my terminal at Newark had an Earl of Sandwich. I had been up for about 20 hours on my flight home from Europe. I was traveling by myself and really wanted to sit down and have a meal while I waited the hour for my last flight. I've been to two other Earl of Sandwiches, Vegas and Orlando, at each of these locations you order at the Counter then grab a seat until your pager lets you know your sandwich is ready and grab the sandwich at the pick-up counter and return to your seat. Well, this Earl of Sandwich had no signs explaining that in order to sit at their tables you had to sit down and place an order with the one waiter that was servicing all the tables. I ordered at the counter and paid at the counter, as I always do at Earl of Sandwich, only to learn that I would have to eat my sandwich somewhere else. As I waited for my sandwich, I noticed in my opinion the complete lack of organization and cleanliness in the kitchen that was fully viewable. I had already paid for my sandwich, and did not want to ask for a refund. If any of my friends or family had been with me, they would have made me throw out the sandwich, but I guess it was all the stress of traveling and the smell of the hot sandwich that made me eat some of the sandwich. (I've eaten street food in the Caribbean that had flies buzzing all around the stall and survived, which makes me take some risks with food) The sandwich was still good, but I really couldn't enjoy it or finish it after seeing the conditions it was made in. I really like the Newark airport and wish I had grabbed a meal before entering my tiny terminal.  I also hope that Earl of Sandwich corporation comes and rescues this location!

Amazing amazing!   Loved the steak tacos and the taco burritos.  The carnitas need a little work, but loved everything we tried. This place is super small and very popular so be prepared to have to eat what your order elsewhere.  The line moves quickly despite being literally out the door.
This place is the best! Great food and service!

Robust and stylish Roman cuisine served in a bustling dining room fashioned after an authentic trattoria experience. Located on the first floor of the Gramercy Park Hotel, this Danny Meyer restaurant has attentive service and beautiful floral arrangements. Fettucine Bolognese, Spaghettini alle Vongole, and the Scottadita lamb chop dishes were highlights. The funghi trifolati was delicious as well. Not particularly haute or creative cuisine (as the prices would suggest), but very good and fun.
Delicious and always fresh Falafel. In my opinion it's the best Falafel place in Forest Hills. Ask Wafa which food is fresh that day and go with her recommendations.

So far in Chinatown, I have not tried a Vietnamese Pork Sandwich as good as this place!  I usually order a whole bunch of sandwiches for my family and friends during social gatherings and they all love them as much as I do.  If you haven't tried the sandwiches here, then you must do so!

Heaven.  I've lived in Spain twice and miss it so much that it hurts.  My new job is located in SoHo, so of course one of the first things I did was check out Yelp for lunch recommendations.  Once again, you all delivered! I had gazpacho from Despana yesterday that was brilliant.  Seriously, I could live on that stuff.  Also, their bocadillos are fantastic - my favorite is the Despana, but the Chorizo and Quijote also get two thumbs up.  I can't wait to try the tortilla...

I live around the corner from Cookshop and it is really one of the best restaurants in the neighborhood. Very consistent and very seasonal. The menu changes almost daily as many of the ingredients are sourced from local farmers/suppliers. I will say that my only complaint is that the price makes it hard to make it a true regular spot. Even so, my girlfriend and I are always looking for an excuse to go! "Friends in town? Let's go to Cookshop!" "Out of milk? Let's go to Cookshop!" "What? Today's Wednesday? Let's go to Cookshop!"

This place is really great. They open really late for a bite. A little pricey but its worth a try. They have an oyster bar, which I really crave for. Most entrees comes with sides dishes, which makes it really filling. This place is crowded as hell even after hours. No reservations taken for party under six. The service is really nice, and friendly. Another great place for late night munch.

Awesome Brazilian spot! I just got back from there - Sunday, November 23, 2014.  They had live Sertanejo (Brazilian country music) and the duo was amazing.  It wasn't overwhelmingly packed when I went, but I left earlier in the evening. They also had soccer on.  My vote is to go on Sunday for Brazilian soccer, sertanejo and a great time! Decor is very nice also. Love it! My official favorite spot in Ironbound.

Our family LOVES Brothers Pizza! We've tried everybody in the area. Papa Johns is too sweet. Dominos has become too garlicky. Aljon's and several others are ok but Brothers is the best. Just the right blend of crust, sauce and cheese. Sometimes I do think they should leave the pie in the oven for an extra minute and I've asked them to do so. That way the pie is a little more "set". But as far as flavor goes - it's always great.

These sandwiches remind of the Vietnamese banh mi, but definitely with a kick.  I've had the tiger shrimp sandwich and also the pork belly sandwich, both of which are extremely good (the pork belly being a little but better).  There is so much flavor in these sandwiches!  They are a bit expensive ($8-10 for a 6-8" sandwich).  There are a couple locations in Manhattan, so go try one!

So we have been anticipating a trip to A. Kitchen as we were looking to enjoy Bryan Sikora's food once again.  We were wholly disappointed that while his name is still listed on the website, he apparently hasn't been employed there for 2 months.  Sadly, the food did show the lack of his direction, it was one dimensional at best, no depth.  The Mushroom tart was much too peppery.  We also found the restaurant much too loud with too many hard surfaces.  When I asked for another glass of the same wine I already had, by name, I was given the wrong wine, twice.

It's times like these that I wonder how I managed to score my boyfriend. For my birthday gift, he planned out an entire weekend just for the two of us, and Saturday began with lunch at Alma de Cuba. His family are fans of the Starr restaurants, and after my birthday dinner last year at Morimoto, I too have become a convert and the two of us are determined to try each and every Starr restaurant. A birthday lunch at Alma was therefore the perfect way to begin our day. The interior is really nice, modern decor with clean lines. My boyfriend preferred the warm lounge on the first floor, but I enjoyed the second floor's more light and airy feel. Our waiter was clearly new, but he was very nice and extremely attentive. The menu is fusion Cuban cuisine, and damn is it good! We didn't have drinks, but their mojito seems to be popular. We shared their ceviche sampler (which everyone should definitely try), that was a tasting of each of their ceviches: Vuelve La Vida: shrimp, scallops and calamari tossed in a an aji amarillo sauce with cherry tomatoes; Hamachi Tiradito: yellowtail with red onion, cilantro, lime juice and a touch of aji; and Ecuadorian Shrimp: shrimp with roasted tomatoes, chives, avocado and corn nuts. The ceviches were incredible, each one spiced perfectly to accompany the seafood, although I wish that the hamachi had a lighter sauce because I really couldn't taste the fish (which I personally prefer), only the lime juice. We also shared two entrees, a special halibut one with both smoked and grilled halibut over a salad of mesclun, yellow beets and cherry tomatoes, and a cuban-sounding dish that was spinach and cheese layered with plantains and wrapped with zucchini with tomato sauce on top, served over a black bean and pesto spread with an onion-jicama slaw. Damn, damn good, but the plantain dish was waaaay too heavy for me. The halibut was perfect (except for the fact that I don't care for smoked fish EVER), a nice light dish for the hot summer. We both loved the food, but unfortunately didn't have enough (or any) room for dessert, which just means that we'll have to go back again in the near future!!

Food is awesome-- overall management and service is terrible. We were eating dinner outside when the rain started to pour.  We asked 3 times, to hostess, manager, and our waiter, to move inside and they said "sorry we have no room inside".  Meanwhile, they have empty tables with "Reserved" signs on them.  The manager ( I am assuming it was him, but he never introduced himself) came out and was inconvenienced because we were eating under our umbrellas. He said we were" troopers", and left.  Jacob's Pickles-- your food is great, but you need to learn your paying customers are important. Bottom line- don't go here if you want to impress someone. I brought my friend from out of town and she thought we were being video taped because it was so ridiculous.

This place is for someone who loooooves oysters... like my sister. Me, on the other hand, can't eat oysters like I used to because of a oyster-food-poisoning incident. Tragic. So, while my sisters slurped down oysters, I was chomping down on the various cheeses, salmon/tuna tar tar and our main entree, which was a fish, cooked with the most amazing tasting butter ever. Top that with some pumpkin craft beer and man... it was great.

For the longest time I've had people tell me about how great the Black label burger is so a couple of friends and I finally decided to make a reservation. Upon entering the restaurant we were greeted by a snooty hostess who did not seem like she cared for our business. We were told to come back when all of our party has arrived without even asking if we would like to wait at the bar for a drink but instead kicking us out into the cold weather. The seating for a 6 person group was less than ideal. My arms have never been bumped so many times and a friend of my had butter spilled on her hair due to the clashing waiters and patrons squeezing through behind us. Our waitress was  very judgmental of the things we ordered. She made some jokes of drink choices I made but I took it as a joke but when we all ordered the burger her attitude became a little pompous. Her words exactly "While I understand everyone wants the burger I want to let everyone know that we are a Michelin starred restaurant and I'd recommend you to try other things such as our steak." It took a second for me to realize that the waitress had just dropped the almighty michelin star on us but luckily for us we couldn't care less if the restaurant had 3 stars. We were there for a burger and that is what we ordered. Following the order I did notice the waitresses whispering in the corner and looking in our direction but I'll give them benefit of the doubt and think that they were trying to see how they can make our experience better. Finally, the burger was delicious but not as much as most made it out to be. The fries were some of the best I've tasted but I guess all this hyping up just brought the expectation so high that the reality could never attain hype. The burger meat was one of the best I've ever had but I'm not a fan of the bun and for $28 I was hoping for a lot more justification compared to other burgers in NYC. The foie gras and bone marrow  were amazing and the souffle was perfect as well. All in all i think the burger and food is great at Minetta Tavern but the service and the high price of a marginally better burger puts the rating low for me. May your experience be better than mine.
i have been to this place 3 times its very pricey the quality of his cheeses, solami, prosciutto are nothing to write home about. not worth the price he should change his importer.
Amazing restaurant.  The food, the service, and the ambiance are perfect for this west village gem!

The place was full on a friday night, but they did not even acknowledge me when i entered. then seeing the wait, i told one of the waiters that i just wanted to order out since i was craving filipino food. it took them over 15 minutes to come back. i looked around the restaurant and so many people were waiting to be served and the other half were waiting for their checks and get their table cleaned. there was a table of "regulars" that obviously got way more attention then anyone else. never again. i went to maharlika in the east village right after. and they were great. don't come here. poor service.
I love everything here. They are known for their square slices, but don't skip the round pizza, it might be the best I've have in brooklyn other than Jean Danet in Bay Ridge.
There's a fight first thing when I came in. Halloween weekend. Maybe it was a fight club theme. Either way, pretty ghetto. The music was upbeat though!

Wonderful, amazing, incredible... every positive descriptor imaginable belongs in this spot. We got there just as they were opening at 5:30pm on a Thursday, which was good because this place fills up really quickly.  We sat at the counter so we could chat and watch the chefs in action.  I think this should be pretty obvious, but either way, I'll say it: the centerpiece here is clearly the grilled meats, especially the chicken, and more specifically, the unusual cuts, and if you skip that you're probably cheating yourself out of a great meal. We started off the meal with an icy cold Sapporo Draft, good compliment to the grilled chicken, and watched as the chef tended the skewers on the grill.  We got a really incredible variety, bonchiri/bonjiri (chicken 'butt'/'tail', delicious and hard to describe,) seseri (neck), sori (chicken oyster), kawa (skin), tebasaki (wing), negima (breast meat with scallions), hiza nankotsu (cartilage) and nankotsu tsukune (a chicken meatball with scallions and cartilage interspersed), liver, ton toro (pork neck with onion, I think), grilled eggplant miso dengaku and grilled onigiri (rice balls.)   Absolutely everything was delicious.  Out of all those items, the only one I don't think I'd order again was the onigiri, because I prefer the sauce-coated kind and this had a dipping sauce instead.  That said, I liked that most everything was only really salt grilled because it let the delicious fats of the meat speak for itself.  Everything was so good but the things I would absolutely want to get again right away were the bonchiri, ton toro and the nankotsu tsukune.  Those were my surprise favorites, while the kawa, tebasaki, liver, chicken oyster, and negima were all reliably delicious. For the amount we ate, the bill was certainly large but not crazy, I didn't think at least.  The service was good.  Due to the bottleneck being the fact that each skewer needs a specific time to cook, I could see this place not being as great during either the middle of dinner rush/on weekends and such.  However, when you get there right away, not only do they still have the rarer cuts left but they also they are able to take the fully appropriate amount of time on each.

There are so many Irish bars on this stretch of 3rd Ave and yet Molly stands out from the pack.  The floor is covered with sawdust (where it comes from, I've never been able to figure out).  The crowd is usually close to 50/50 male/female and is a little less rowdy (better able to handle their drinks) which is rather unique for any drinking establishment around this area.  In addition, food here is actually good.  Now, it's not a culinary destination but they have a rather extensive menu ranging from Fried Calamari to Sheperds' Pie to their burgers so at least, you don't have to drink on an empty stomach.   I don't know what it is about Molly's but all in all, it invites you in to make yourself comfortable and spend the evening getting to know everyone else.  And it's always with a little regret that I stepped back into the cold..

Don't go to this restaurant unless you are willing to be taken advantage of. I ordered a Veal Cutlet sandwich off the lunch menu. The price was clearly stated as $9.50. When the bill arrived, the amount on the check was $11.50 which I pointed out to our waitress. She went to check out the problem, and upon her return, informed me that "it did state $9.50 on the menu but the manager said prices are subject to change".  She also mentioned that they are printing new menu's and that would be the price on the new menu. I was floored!!. Told her "they should honor the prices printed", her response was "I asked the mgr. and was told that is the price". Nobody came over, so I paid the bill and will not go back there. In my years of eating in restaurants, I have never encountered a situation such as that.
Neat place with good food, cool staff, all in all, not a bad spot :)
Love the relaxed friendly vibe and great food. Try the artichoke dip - much better than you might expect. Lamb burgers top notch. Music very retro and awesome. Listening to Elvis Costello as we type.

I've been dining at little fish since it was a secret.  unfortunately, such a good thing was bound to catch on some time.  although i think over the last decade the portions have gotten a little smaller and the prices a little higher - its still one of my favorite places to eat. BYOB makes it more reasonable.  the new location is great - hasn't lost the feeling that you are in someone's home and they are cooking dinner just for you (which they basically are).  i even took my husband while we were dating who "did not do fish" and its now one of his favorites too!  we spend so many special occasions at little fish, its like the staff knows us.  its perfectly intimate and romantic.  service is always friendly and efficient.  best mussles in the world.  so grateful for this place!

This is probably the best food $2.50 can buy, especially during a long night out. I usually grab two and take them to Washington Square Park when I have some time to kill -- beats the hell out of eating it in their crowded little shop.
Pretty good indeed!  The store does not have place to sit down so you can only buy the macarons and find another place to snjoy.
Love this place. The food is plentiful, delicious, and relatively cheap. Try the catfish, it's really interesting.

Don't think you can really call this a panini if it's not even warm or hot ... it tasted like a subway sandwich.  It was HUGE ... like a mini-sized baby.  I don't think that one person can finish an entire one.  It was definitely filling, but the ingredients didn't really excite me much.  I'd rather pay for the better quality than just large quantity. Won't come back here unless I am beasting hungry.
Amazing experience! Excellent food and service!

Came here a few times and definitely enjoyed the meals. I haven't tried much but the Jerk Chicken and Lamb Chops are my favorites so far! My cousin really loved the cheesesteak. The portions are pretty big so there's plenty to share (or take home if need be). Good for groups of 2-4!

Went with a large group and had a multi course dinner. Started with salad...the dressing was a simple vinegar and oil, but it was delicious. Large plates of anti pasta was also pretty good with a lot of variety. Huge plates of fried zucchini were fried to perfection. 2 different  pastas...a basic marinara and a red sauce with broccoli and peas. We didn't have the basic marinara, but the one we had was good. Main courses were eggplant parm-ok, although I'm not a huge fan of that dish, veal marsala...I though it was only ok, thought the sauce was too rich, but my girlfriend really liked it, and finally chicken parts in a lite sweet sauce...very good and even the white meat was tender and delicious! Desert was fruit and a fudge square with whipped cream. The fudge was way too rich for us. Overall, a great meal...really enjoyed it, highly recommend this restaurant!

We love Eataly. Even though this place is not exactly cheap, we always love the experience here, and all the variety of goods and services you can get from Eataly. It's like stepping into a magical Italian market - and you can get any type of Italian product that you can imagine (I may have a shallow imagination when it comes to Italian culture though). We love the gelato and think it's a very good deal. They have some changing varieties of flavours, so you might get something new each time! They also offer services such as a wine bar, two sit-down restaurants, and a beer patio! Haven't tried each of them yet, but it's on our bucket list!

This place is the best place I've found for take-out pasta. Really good presentation, portions and service. Dude that runs it is a lot of fun to interact with and knows how to move quickly. If you want pasta for lunch in SoHo, look no further.

If your all about Thai food this is the best place! It may not be as flashy as Sea or Spice, but the food more than makes up for it. I definitely think this is the best Thai spot in NYC (and one of the cheapest). Expect a wait at night and a very loud surrounding. I love coming here for lunch in the summer when they open up the back. Truly one of the hidden gems in the area (with no 'joya' sign, just a sheet of paper with the name in the window). The bar in front is also fun on nighttime, filled with a mixed and fun crowd. The service isn't amazing but isn't bad. They do get the food out very quickly (so fast that its annoying) because its so cheap and they try to turn over the max amt of tables. Overall, I come here monthly because of the great price and excellent food (and am not the only one). I'm quite sure that if you go once you'll also come back very soon again.
Rude employees and overpriced food. No thanks, I'll stick to George's.

Best jambalaya this side of New Orleans, and the beignets are simply out of this world. (UNDERSTATEMENT!) Charming staff, friendly management, and an adorably eclectic environment to share with friends and family.
Pretty cool. Ramen is amazing!

Very reliable food and good service, great for meeting friends for brunch or on a dinner date.  The front area is smaller than the back area, where it gets pretty crowded at night.  The whole place has a rustic feel which I love.  The pasta dishes are really delicious and they have all the brunch staples.  The bloody mary is solid and they have Peroni on tap.  It's very reliable so drop by for a date/drink/catch up meal.

i always appreciate the warm towels. place was packed on a friday night. my friends and i were seated at the best table by the window. win! the service was a little skimpy, but that was probably a product of how busy it was... but the cozy atmosphere more than made up for the empty tea cups we ordered too many dishes to remember... but a couple that stood out: deep fried small silver fish appetizer, chicken oyster yakitori and... regarding the APRICOT KERNEL TOFU PUDDING... i still remember you oh so fondly

Really enjoyed our dining here. Had less to eat and more to drink though. . . . we had an assortment of Sake tasting with side dishes. Service was good, atmosphere great . . .  was a little cold and breezy though . . . perhaps uncomfortably so. Perhaps it was an off day with the air/heating system? I recommend!
I've dined at Surfish Peruvian Bistro 3 times now and absolutely love their parihuela! Yum! Surfish is a small cozy restaurant with good food and friendly staff.

This is not authentic indian food, all the flavors are dumbed down. I came with my wife the other day and the owner and the waitress wer very rude to us. They were very impatient. Service was slow. When the food came it, it was cold.

Pickle backs, Caesar salad, grilled cheese, pickle plate and the newly added beef jerky...enough said. Everything is amazing. Have been going here since they opened last year and wish I could go everyday. The cocktail menu is one of my favorites as well. Some of my favorite drinks are the pick-me up, auntie rose, sage cucumber julep, and they used to have this one drink with oolong tea that was a must try. Depending on what I am ordering I always ask them to substitute gin for whiskey and they never have a problem with it.

I've been living in Philadelphia for the past four years and have lived in South Jersey and New York City before that. (so I've had alot of different sandwiches).  I've been getting bored with your typical cheesesteaks, heroes, subs, hoagies, bagel sandwiches, etc... so I wanted to try something a little different. Paesano's, by far, has the most unique sandwiches while not overloading them with tons of different items and condiments to simply try and make a "fat boy sandwich".  The rolls are perfect and the portions are more than filling.  I had a Turkey sandwich that was a special and they used hand carved turkey, with pepper shooters, spicy cheeses, and a spicy chipotle mayo spread.
