If you're looking for a lunch to really grab the attention of your taste buds, please check out Paesano's II -- I guarantee you won't regret it.
OVER PRICED TO OIL'Y  no real meat flavor and over rated i prefer PAT'S cheesestakes

The Spotted Pig utterly swept my tummy off its proverbial feet.  Everything I placed in my mouth was amazing from this restaurant, and I can't begin to tell you the glee I felt  from each chew and bite I took from the food on offer here.   To start we had the deviled eggs (creamy, custardy and light, packed with flavor and a salty kick) were one of the many highlights of the dinner, along with the equally delicious ricotta and prosciutto tart (flaky tart, with the rich ricotta and fresh, salty  prosciutto).  For our entrees, we had the Chargrilled Burger with Roquefort and Shoestring Fries, along with one of the specials of the night, The Chicken Stew.  Both the bf and I were completely surprised by the burger and fries.  We've had plenty of burgers in our day, but this was by far one of the best.  The chargrilled treatment of the burger created a phenomenal tasting slab of meat in all its rustic, moist, and natural goodness.  Marry these winsome elements with the soft and toasted bun, and that amazing Roquefort cheese (French blue cheese), and you have yourself a top-notch burger.  The shoestring fries were Mt. Everest on a plate, just unnecessarily massive, yet utterly outstanding.  These fries were thin and crispy, salty and the perfect crunchy accessory to that amazing burger.  The Chicken Stew was quite sophisticated as well, and definitely very hearty.  The chicken was really tender and we really enjoyed the flavor profile of the dish.   Dessert was The Flourless Chocolate Cake as well as the Hazelnut Ice Cream with Shortbread cookies.  I wouldn't recommend the cake, it was extremely dense and rich, and way too much dessert after such a heavy meal.  On the other hand, the delectable ice cream along with the crunchy shortbread cookies, was a nice way to cap off our impressive meal. Too bad our friends visiting from Cali couldn't hack another burger night since that's all they had been eating before coming to New York, because I was planning to take them here.  Instead they went with pizza (which is never a bad idea in NYC), but I tell you, I really wanted them to try The Spotted Pig and have something else to really brag about when they made their way back to the west coast.  Next time, I'll get them and so will TSP.   The Spotted Pig delivers incredibly hearty, and tasty food, in a cozy and chilled out setting.  One dinner here is a meal you will not likely forget, and for all the best reasons imaginable.  Amazing food, great service, fun atmosphere... did I mention amazing food?  Mmm that burger, Lord have mercy!!!

I had brunch here a while back with two friends. It's a great, cozy little brunch spot. We came on Sunday around noon and it was pretty quiet, only one more table was filled. The brunch deals are pretty good, entrees are about $13 and come with coffee, tea or juice. I ordered an egg sandwich, which is fairly hard to mess up, but I liked it a lot, and moreso, I liked the chill atmosphere. I'm not in the neighborhood very often, but I'd definitely come back here for a relaxed not all-you-can-drink brunch.

Get atmosphere and superior service. I was not rushed out after our meal which is unusual in today's restaurants. I was welcomed by the owner and seated immediately. The food was above average and the drinks were not watered down. I highly recommend this restaurant to all visitors and native New Yorkers alike. Bravo!
eh not bad, food was quick and easy  but hey ya get what ya pay for

Go and you will not regret! In my opinion, their appetizers are more interesting / tastier than their entries. Here are the must-haves: mushroom pizza with farm egg, organic pear and apple salad (may be seasonal), crab cake toast, and chocolate cake

It's a Saturday night and I am driving down route 46 west from Caldwell for dinner and drinks.  All of the "standard" restaurants are packed so we drive further to Red Stone Tavern. I've been to this place many times so far and I love the food.  Plus it is extremely inexpensive in relation to its competition. When I arrive at 7:00 PM I am surprised by the number of available parking spots.  When I walk into the bar, it's practically empty.  Now I do not care since I am at Red Stone to eat dinner, but I was a little depressed by the lack of energy this place has on a saturday night. By the end my meal I felt the same as I did the first time I ate dinner at this establishment.  Because I love the food and think the bar is extremely nice I wanted to provide this feedback. 1) If this place does not do something quick to differentiate itself from Houlihans or other standard fare places, it will fail.   2) The bar is boring and has no energy or pizzazz. 3) The beer choices have barely changed in a year.  Even though I have suggested some new beers to this place, my requests have been ignored. (See below) 4) The staff, while very nice, is slow and dull.  No one smiles and most staff seem depressed to be working on a Saturday night because they are not making money. Here is my first thought: A dedicated, creative, Craft beer bar is what's drawing the crowds these days.  Red Stone is well positioned in-between two, known, Craft Beer Bars (Poor Henry's and Nicole's 10).   Red Stone has more of an upscale feel to it than a "local pub."  Between craft beer and the beautiful bar, this place should attract a decent clientele on a Saturday night. IMHO Red Stone cannot compete on food alone.  Nor is it a food factory like Houlihans, Buffalo Wild Wings or Tiffany's.  Maybe Red Stone can create a niche by adding more beer taps and more craft beers or by running more drink specials or even adding live music on the weekends. Whatever Red Stone does, it can only be an improvement over the drab, boring product it is currently offering.  Of course this is just one man's opinion.  However, this is one man who actually took the time to write this review.
my favorite restaurant in the west village.  I feel like I am in France again when eating here!

I feel that I need to update my review for 116 Crown because I frequent this establishment and it never fails me. During their busiest nights, and even if their is a wait, the service is always superb.  The staff is always friendly and attentive and the quality of the drinks and the food are never compromised.  The menu always seems to have a drink that I haven't tried or a small plate that seems to entice my palate.  The music is always good, the people here are always happy. Still my favorite bar in Connecticut, no questions asked.

Variety & abundance of common & unique Filipino dishes w takeout & buffet choices. Besides Leos BBQ in Plainfield, they know how to cook kambing well. Thirty plus filipino dishes to choose from the common stuff stuff like Adobo to stingray will please anyone trying Filipino food for first time. They also have one of my favorites Taho (Tofu dessert), which seems to hard to find in the Filipino restaurants nearby. Parking can frustrating but the food is worth the walk from the next block.

i was at El Camino today and had a great time.  The female bartender was busy but still gave us great service.  we ordered a pitcher of strawberry margaritas and they were awesome! my boyfriend and I aren't from this area but we will definitely be back.
This place is legit. Pretty empty at 7:30 on a weekday. Food was good....Skate was amazing! I would be more inclined to go back for a drink at the bar then for a sit down dinner.

Having worked in restaurants in Philadelphia and knowing some of the crew responsible for this restaurant I will try to be as objective as possible, and in turn knowing that you shouldn't visit a restaurant in it's first week before they've gotten all the kinks worked out, my wife and I couldn't resist checking it out on day 4.  We'll of course go back and see the progression in a few weeks if not sooner, especially when we can go back for lunch in the future (inevitable), but I have to say that we thought this restaurant was solid from the minute we walked in the door.  To be totally honest this is not a 5 star restaurant, the five stars are there because it wildly exceeded my expectations for the place 4 days in and for the concept as a whole.  Host staff was on it from the get go getting us seated right away and most importantly acknowledging our existence before we even crossed the doorway.  The decor is somewhat of a cross between a futuristic diner and a starkly minimal Momofuku-esque food bar.  Not sure why there aren't more restaurants with open kitchen bars, seeing as in this world full of new "foodies" stuck to their tv sets watching every cooking show in existence, wouldn't they want to recreate that experience live in the restaurants they actually eat in? Maybe this is the future? While we didn't sit at the bar we will in the future and were disappointed that we didn't make that decision this time.  Michael Shulson was on hand in the kitchen and despite the place being somewhat empty at 6:30 when we arrived, by 7pm the place was getting packed and the open kitchen was bustling. The LED backlit forest is a very inviting sight from the sidewalk and surely an "open" sign for all those passing by.  Anyway, we noticed many familiar staff from stalwart restaurants such as Buddakan and Morimoto surely attributing to the casual, efficient and unobtrusive service style.  The menu is set up in an approachable small plate style with great pricing.  You could probably get out of here for $25 a person, but it's hard to resist (especially on a first visit) not ordering everything to try and walk out having spent much more(but isn't that the point of the small plate movement:).  First things first, Michael Shulson is famous for his edamame dumplings to which he made famous at Buddakan but you won't find the same delicate petite dumplings here but more of a authentic chinese style soft dumpling (read: thicker doughier skin, and in my experience working with Chinese chefs this is the real thing).  Many people may dismiss the dumplings as less refined than those of the style he created at Buddakan but it certainly pleased my wife and I to see this style in such a restaurant in Philadelphia and we hope others can appreciate it as well. I also hate to say it but the Philly cheese steak (yet another restaurant twisting Philly's namesake food) with Sriracha was fantastic.  AND the Pork Bahn Mi.  At $9 I predict this being my lunch on many days headed to work.  For what you would pay to eat a sandwich (and I mean this is a cheesesteak sized roll) for almost the same price anywhere in Center City, you can have this instead.  We had the lobster gyoza, which wasn't our favorite but was solid with a great presentation and the inclusion of what looked like some sort of dehydrated chili balanced with the sweet and acidic 1-2 combo of apples and miso.  Finally we had the shrimp & egg fried rice with Virginia ham, and I have to say that Shulson wins the prize of having the most delicate but fully seasoned fried rice in town.  Light but full of flavor!  The wine prices are approachable and we had the Jovly Vouvray at $40 (a deal considering it is real Loire Chenin), perfect for the food we had.  It arrived less than cold, but possibly had just arrived that day considering how soon after the open we came. Overall a great experience for a concept which we had our eyes on because we are fans of David Chang's Momofuku restaurants in the East Village and wanted something similar in our neighborhood.  Next time we'll be hitting up the Ramen and making the comparison. Great new restaurant for Center City.

The service was outstanding,  Anthony, the owner, spent time at each table and was so gracious and warm. The space was quiet and intimate and welcoming. The food was incredible not simply for being gluten free but on its own was amazing the pizza was perfect :chewy, amazing sauce, fresh basil. and dessert was the best gluten free cake I have ever had all made with fresh ingredients. I will return many, many times. Highly recommend.

The food is okay. Service is what I really appreciate and it was great here. The servings are pretty average in size. Not tiny but by no means generous. The drinks are not special either. Overall everything was pretty generic and straight forward. Not sure why all the hype and waiting in line on brunch days is all about? This is NYC and there are thousands of places to go. I would not wait in any line unless I was getting sex-good-quality food. On service alone, I would have rated 5 stars. The food just lacks passion and excitement.

The bibimbap here is great, and the staff are really friendly!  I was really happy to see that they serve small kim chi and radish dishes before the main dish, even though it's just a small, informal restaurant.  I'm not Korean so I can't judge its authenticity, but the bibimbap came in a big hot stone pot with tons of meat and delicious sauce for a totally reasonable price.

The quintessential neighborhood bar for this part of Brooklyn. All the bartenders live around the area and are super accommodating. Sometimes the bar is a bit understaffed. In my book, this is all the more reason to tip well and be polite, because, like most locals in the area, they are trying their hardest to pursue a career in the arts while working another job. The drink selection is excellent: they rotate it out on a pretty regular basis, and can always boast 1-2 seasonal brews and at least one interesting, more specialized ale. They also have a good happy hour and good shot-and-beer specials. The cocktails, with names ranging from the Pearl Necklace to the Morning After Pill, are like their names: strong and unique. They also have growlers. The burgers--I can't stress this enough--are excellent. They are maybe the best bar burger I've had in New York. All the other food is good too, but if you are going to try one thing, get the burger: especially considering that during Happy Hour, you get a burger with fries and a beer for $12. A really good deal. As for the ambience: I love it, personally. The paintings on the walls are all from the personal collection of the owner's wife, and they have a full diving suit suspended from the ceiling. Heavy metal/loud music has been playing every time I go there. There's a venue that specializes in heavy metal bands right next door, so this choice makes sense. Personally, I like this about this place: I like knowing what to expect, and I like being able to unwind to music that's harder than the day I had. Overall, just an awesome place that locals love, and lacks all the pretense, but none of the quality, of other Brooklyn bars.

We went there for dinner last night.  Here is what we ordered last night. Tom yum soup----very nice herbal taste to it. Sushi pizza-----the best of the dinner. Sushi & sashimi combo-----so fresh & nicely presented. Fried ice cream for desert.  Overall it was a really good dinner for 2. We enjoyed it.

Before reading up on Montclair, I had no clue there were any Ethiopian restaurants anywhere in New Jersey within an hour of my home.  It's been about a year since I last had Ethiopian food, so when the time came to choose a dinner spot during my recent visit Mesob won hands down.  It also helped that it was mentioned in a couple online articles I had read about the town. When you walk into Mesob, you feel transported.  You're not on busy Bloomfield avenue.  You're inside a comfortable, warm (and well decorated) zone.  The furniture and seats are all nice wood colors.  The walls have a warm white and orange color combination.  Paintings hang on the walls and in the center host island are tall lambs with (what I was told) a foreign alphabet printed onto them.  The appearance is striking and it immediately draws you in.  The smell of delicious spices and food help too! The staff was super nice.  Every server was fast, efficient and sweet.  They genuinely want to please and they do a great job.  We were seated, our orders taken, water provided and food on the table within a twenty minute stretch.  It helped that we knew what we wanted, but keep in mind some dishes require about 15 minutes to prepare since they're made fresh. All the food is served on Injera bread, a spongy, slightly sour bread served in a round shape on a round platter.  The foods you order are generally scooped on top of this bread when you are served, making for a delicious and dramatic presentation!  So here's the verdict on the food I had with my girlfriend: INJERA BREAD Let's start with the basics.  The Injera bread was soft, spongy and had the slightly sour taste you want with this bread.  This also serves as your "utensil" to eat with (you rip pieces off and scoop the food up in it) and it held together perfectly. LEGA TIBS Cubed boneless leg of lamb marinated & sautéed with onions, garlic, jalapenos, fresh tomato, herbs & spices.  This can be spicy, but we had it at "medium".  It was very tasty and all the spices were just right, not too heavy, not too light.  A couple of meat chunks were tougher than I would've liked, but that was only a couple and not a majority of them. DORO TIBS Scalloped chicken breast marinated & sautéed with red onions, garlic, jalapeno pepper, fresh tomato, herbs & spices.  We also had this medium, but it wound up coming out a bit spicier than the Lega Tibs, but that was fine by me since I like spicy!  The chicken had a nice texture and tasted wonderful. TIKIL GOMEN (Side) Cabbage and potatoes simmered in mild sauce.  I've had this dish in other restaurants before, and it was generally mild.  This version however was packed with flavor and hit me with an unexpected (but pleasant) punch of flavor.  It was also wonderfully tender. KIK ALETCH (Side) Yellow split peas simmered in a mild and flavorful onion and herb sauce.  This is normally a very mild dish, but this version had a sweetness that I really appreciated given the sea of spicy foods on the platter. GOMEN (Side) Fresh collard green simmered in mild sauce seasoned with spice and herbs.  This had a mild flavor.  The greens had a nice chew and I recommend it as a good palette balancer for all the spicy food you might get. MISIR WAT (Side) Split lentils simmered in spicy hot sauce.  This was a lentil dish with some fire!  It didn't burn but it definitely had a flavor that will wake up your taste buds! Overall I loved my experience at Mesob and look forward to my next trip!

I used to come here back when I was in Middle School, which was approximately... 6 years ago. It was hard not to come here to get my Chinese Food fix, as it was right across the street. But then I came here a couple more times in high school, actually once in senior year. I have no idea what I was thinking. This place is straight up greasy and NOT ballin'. Not off the hook. Not.. straight up gangstah. Actually, maybe it's a little gantstah. It's just grease, with chicken thrown in. And maybe some rice and I don't know, a vegetable? But once it hits your lips, it's so good. So. Good. I'm glad I live on the other side of town and am somewhat intrigued by the Nasty Woman at Hunan Wok because otherwise I'd be all up in HK Kitchen's grill. I have a thing for fat, especially during the lunch day. Oh and I've sat down here each time, because who doesn't like to eat in unsanitary conditions? But still, we all know that Chinese food leads to a most filling and affordable lunch. And sometimes that's all a girl really needs. That and a big ass quart of Hot and Sour Soup.

The food was okay My dad ordered a pastrami sandwich an they forgot the pastrami. How does one do that..?! The tables are too close together it makes it harder to get up without hitting the person in the next table. My waitress only came over once and a while to ask how we are doing. Other then that the price for the food is way to expensive for lunch. Didn't  expect to pay 50 dollars for two people during lunch.

Best pizza I've ever had!  Heard from numerious survey's and people that this was the place to go to try NY style pizza, so of course my friend and I had to try it.  Everyone was right, this pizza is soooo good.  The crust is perfectly thin and has just enough crisp, the sauce is sweet but not to sweet, and the fresh mozerrella on top is mouth-watering.  I had them add pepperoni to mine and that was great too.  We only had to wait about 10 minutes to get a table around 6pm on a Saturday which was great.  The pizza came pretty fast after ordering and the prices are decent.  You can only order whole pizzas but that's okay because we ate the entire thing.  The only negative thing is they don't take credit cards, so just make sure you have cash on you.  Next time I'm in NYC, I'm definately coming here again!

Ate here a couple times and just had take out. I think I need to stay for a little while if I know what's good for me (I don't) because this place is LEGIT! The cheese steaks are very authentic, and served piled high with meat. Rost pork special and Italian fries are pretty much the perfect meal. If you work or live in the neighborhood, and haven't been here yet, just what are you waiting for?

We were looking for an upscale establishment and Gramercy came highly recommended ... and this place did not disappoint. There were 3 of us ordering different dishes. I ordered the lamb it was over seasoned a bit on the salty side. I write this because this is one of the things that still sticks out in my experience. But I still give this place a 5 because the service was absolutely exceptional and they offered to replace the dish ..but I ate it so did not feel they should have. They brought us free desert to make up for the lamb. Hit this place up!
Great pizza, but they seem to have delivery problems lately. Tonight, my order took about 90 minutes to arrive, and they forgot my soda.

After being recommended this place by many friends my husband and I were very much looking forward to it, on our honeymoon from Scotland. The service is appalling, 45 minutes for our main/only course, hadn't even ordered a starter. I had the calamari starter as my main, it was cremated, black solid and cold, utterly inedible with a side of freezing cold tasteless watery kale/broccolli. None of the wait staff seemed to notice we hadn't been served after 45 mins nor did they ask how our meal was on bringing the bill.Can't believe how bad this food was considering how much people rave about it. Hipster nonsense, the emperors new clothes!

What a great find! We were visiting friends in Brooklyn and checked this place out for a Saturday evening meal. Together we ordered several small plates to share, all of which were quite fantastic: the ham and cheese grits, anchovy toasts, sauteed kale, and fried green tomatoes. The anchovy toasts especially were something special. We tried several of their house cocktails and muddles as well, which were mm mm tasty. Our server was laid back and friendly yet attentive and accommodating. I would definitely recommend this place! One note: it would be easy to rack up a pretty hefty bill since the cocktails aren't cheap, so go during happy hour (5-7pm I think) and you can get a few dollars off each drink.

Came here with a friend after I saw pics of their infamous red velvet waffles. We ordered the chicken and red velvet waffles with Mojitos. The food and drinks were good; I guess I was expecting the food to taste better though.

I was very excited to try Sorella after hearing only positive things about it.  I was underwhelmed, to say the least. We went on a Tuesday during the Taste of Hartford, as well as opening night of a show at The Bushnell.  Although the restaurant was busy, it was not understaffed from what we could tell visually.  It took about 10 minutes for someone to come to our table for our drink order, at which time we'd been there for so long that we were ready to order everything...yet, she seemed ill-prepared to take a full order.   I had: - Veal/Ricotta meatballs - Bland!!! No flavor.  The crostini was burnt. - Gnocchi with Roasted Chicken in a brown butter sauce - bland, greasy, & absolutely no other flavor than almost burnt butter My mother had: - Kale Caesar salad - the highlight of the meal.  Very good & unique - Rigatoni Saltanbocca- Salty, but potentially could have decent flavor We both ordered tiramisu for dessert but because it took 30 minutes to have this served, we requested it to go because of our theater tickets. The process of getting the dessert (after the second request), our check, and departure took 15+ minutes. We did have the tiramisu at home later and it was ok.  Just ok.   General atmosphere:  Average... but LOUD!!!  No way to have a conversation in this restaurant.  Be prepared to yell at your dinner guest. It was ironic that the service was so slow as multiple managers (I assume that's who they were) kept coming to check on us at our table. It was overkill.  Once is enough....4 times is too much.   Also, a glass of HOUSE wine was $10... there were items on the per glass less than that.  Side note:  The wine list was extensive, but very overpriced.   I really wanted to like Sorella and my expectations were definitely not met.

Not very friendly service but you still feel like you found a secret place in the city that no one knows. Walking down the alley feels a little illegal. The food is pretty good and I like the bar in the back although try not to sit near the bathroom or you'll have people bumping you every two seconds. Still a good experience and worth the try.

I just ordered from Blu Orchid, and I could not believe how fasty m food arrived!! I have to admit that I was a bit skeptical when my food arrived, because it only been 10 minutes earlier.. I had the chicken Pad Thai, papaya salad and the naan and hummus. They were all amazing. The entree was hot and the vegetables were cooked to perfection.

I'm really excited about our new neighborhood bistro. We've had dinner there twice since it opened, and it's great.  Best ratatouille I've ever had, excellent hanger steak, delicious linguine vongole, fine salmon.  It reminds me of Bar Pitti, one of the comfortable best, and makes you realize how rare casual French restaurants there are here. They're waiting for a BYOB license and when that arrives, it'll be perfect.

There's something about this space. This is where I used to buy my newspaper. I looked forward to it each day. The owners were/are kind and beautiful people. The kind that says hi, how are you and actually means it. It's no wonder the restaurant kept the name. I stopped by earlier this week to grab a much needed coffee and was greeted by a friendly face. Today I am here for brunch for the first time. Sitting outside, of course. The macchiato was presented exactly the way it is should be: like an art piece. The breakfast gnocchi was #delicious #different and #divine. Well done, guys! #namaste #krupa #karma

Max's Oyster Bar is one of my favorite special occasion spots to dine out. Everything about the place screams quality and attention to detail, from the freshness of the raw seafood to the bread baskets provided for the tables. The menu changes seasonally, drawing upon the different ingredients the restaurant can procure from the local area, and the food has always been top-notch. I have had mostly positive but mixed results with the waitstaff, with most of the servers providing attentive and knowledgeable service, though one time the server seemed to tune out after our initial order; I got the feeling that  she was disappointed because we didn't meet some sort of threshold for the final tip, and for the rest of the dinner I felt like I was being hurried but this has been the exception, not the rule. Max's Oyster Bar is certainly pricey, but usually worth it. The restaurant is certainly lively and can get noisy at times but the host should be able to accomodate you if you would like to have a quieter corner for a romantic dinner.

Paesano's gets a lot of press, and in this case, it deserves all the accolades. The reviews speak for themselves. I had the Paesano, the Diavlo, and the potatoes. The Paesano is an amazing sandwich. Don't expect to eat cleanly though, the juices, oils, and beautiful fried egg give it plenty of give and soon you'll find yourself licking your elbows. The beef brisket is tender and flavorful, the seeded roll is crispy but doesn't cut through the roof of the mouth. The Diavlo was also very good, I found that it paled in comparison to the Paesano though. The chicken was also seasoned well with a little kick, but the meat was on the dry side. The potatoes were garlicky, cheesy, and nice too. Dare I say in this town, Paesano's is better than cheesesteak?

Wow. It sure has been a long time since I could say this - the food here was fantastic. The waitstaff could have done horrible, awful things to me & I still would have given this place 5 stars. THAT is how good the food is. The dates...oh, how I loved the dates. I will definitely come back again... and next time I'm ordering the bacon doughnuts for dessert.

Everything that came out of this kitchen was better than anticipated. The falvors, textures and visiual appeal of Mr Forgione's creations will thrill you. The service is thoughtful, attentive and I felt I actually got sincere answers to all my menu questions. The waiter even recommended a less expensive bottle of wine when I asked for some help with the lengthy and quirky wine list. Really nice place to dine, thanks Marc.

Philly Cheesesteaks are one of the best sandwiches you can eat. Pat's understands that and represents Philly proudly. As far as who makes the best cheesesteak in Philly? I am still in the process of researching them all, but Pat's is one of the best for certain.

We ended up at Xochitl almost by accident. It was a very pleasant surprise. Good food, great menu, great service. It might a little on the pricey side, but not too expansive. If you are into tequila and/or margarita they have an amazing selection.

Their main dishes were very delicious! One of my friends had the Sea Bass, which was their special for that day, and it was cooked perfectly. Seemed like it was melting in your mouth, in a good way. I also got to try the Pork Belly - this was really good too, right amount of crispness in the skin, and the meat was just amazing. My dish was the much recommended Hanger Steak - and I can see why! The spinach that came along with it and the steak - cooked to my idea of perfection. For the appetizer, we had the Duck Meatballs - juicy and great combination with the quail egg! Finally, for the dessert, we shared a Take Five Sudae. You have got to try it, it's all my favorite ingredients in one dish - peanut butter ice cream, praline, pretzel pieces etc. I think my only complaint would be the bread, that's why am holding back a star. It was cold and seemed old. Ambiance is like the right amount of casual comfort. The staff is very friendly, and the waiter got a good tip for that! Definitely will come back!

I went to grab a bite based on some recommendations.  I have to say I was a little disappointed in the food. But the atmosphere was great.  I can here for a great burger and ended up getting a decent burger. My favorite item on the menu was the steak eminadas. They were really good. All in all I would say that it is a really cool bar but I will need to go back and try a few other meals before I give it a better rating.

Undeniably, the best veggie burger goodness in town. High quality beans with cole slaw somehow make up this great concoction. Topped off with crispy fries. Oh yes. I will be back again. The brews are really good too.

Awful experience. Really, really, unbelievably bad, atrocious and utterly indifferent service. The worst service I experienced since eating in Communist China in the 1980s. I order four items: hiya yako (cold tofu with a sauce), oshinko maki (pickled radish roll) , kampyo maki and kappa maki (cucumber roll). These are all standard dishes. I lived in Japan, they are always, ALWAYS made the exact same way. They are one of the most predictable dishes ever. When they arrived, the kappa maki (the cucumber) had some really awful disgusting plum paste smeared all over the inside of the roll moreover, it was rolled inside out. No idea why for either of these. That it was inside out was not so bad, but the vile plum paste made it inedible. I took one bite and had to spit it out, it was absolutely awful. I wondered what would possess the chef to create such an abomination. The waiter came over and ask "how is everything?" I told him, and asked him to change the cucumber. He said he could not, I asked "well why then did you come over to ask how everything was?" He seemed confused by the question. I called a second waiter over, asked if he could change it as it was terrible and bore no resemblance to the thousands of other cucumber rolls I'd eaten in the past in Japan, Hong Kong, Korea, New York and Los Angeles. He said "ok, i'll see what I can do." He returned to say "the manager says you ordered it, so you can't change it." I explained I ordered cucumber roll, not this abomination, and insisted he change it. The second waiter came over, bleating that if a customer complains, he gets into trouble, etc etc. I asked to speak to the manager. Suddenly, she was not there, although the woman who greeted us at the door seemed suspiciously like the manager. The first waiter returned and said he took it off the bill, he would pay for it himself out of his own pocket. I assured him this was not necessary, and asked him not to do that, but he insisted. I could not believe it, any of it! That they would not consider changing it, that the manager refused to appear to deal with it but send her low-paid waiters to do her bidding, but mainly the sheer indifference, the 'you don't like the horrible version of a classic dish I've served you, tough twinkies!" I advise anyone with even a modest understanding of REAL Japanese cuisine to avoid this place.

Wonderful went for my birthday last week.Blood Orange margarita pitcher is good and better pricing than just ordering one ;-)..Also got complimentary churros for my birthday.The waiter we had wasss soooo nice and super cute and explained everything clearly.I got the Pasilla Braised Pork..delcious..no complaints!!
The food here isn't terrible, but if you want some good Korean food it's better to make the thirty minute drive to Palisades Park or Fort Lee.

Nice bar! Came here for beer. Nice customer service, good crowd, music. Will come back for those bar hopping nights. Oh, and owner gave my party and I a free round of beer and shots. I mean, too awesome!

Woohoo! As good as it gets! Evidently that's what my five star rating equates to in the minds of those who developed yelp; a homer simpson sortve outburst followed by something my mom would say should she reference my spelling bee performance in the fifth grade. Anyway. I liked this place. The food was fresh, savory, and while mildly pricey, worth it. I'll definitely be back.

Yum. Want some now I had a white pizza which I loved. Others had a more traditional and I took a few bites and it was good too. Like thin crust and the sauce is good. Had the Italian wings and I and the kids gobbled them right up We had it delivered so can't comment on dine in service.

Second-best after Nomad pizza in Hopewell, but this one is right near where I work, so it's always slices for lunch. I particularly enjoy their delicious sausage, although sometimes they do put a bit too much sauce on for my liking. Takeout only, unless you sit at one of the two stools at the little counter in the window. (tip: you can take food over and sit outside Blue Point Grill a few doors away (at LUNCH time only) although I have heard they have recently begun enforcing a "please only eat food from Nassau Seafood here at the tables" rule).

Ive been to this café some times, the food is good, especially the date cake, the staff is nice and smiling. The atmosphere is really amazing it feels like a transition into another world, they have the most wonderful musicians coming in to play old jazz etc. I really really like this place and want come here every time Im in the city!

Price: fairly high for the neighborhood with limited specials Quality: excellent !!! Since their grand opening me and my boyfriend have been here atleast five times, and we've brought other people with us every single time and every experience was great! The service is whatever, they don't really talk much but that doesn't really bother me. The food is awesome though. Black dragon roll, shrimp tempura roll, eel avocado roll, kabuki roll, spicy crabmeat roll, spicy shrimp roll. I can't remember all of the other specialty sushi entrees that we tried but this place is a hidden gem! However, I did try their chicken katsu - sauce is a no bueno. However, if you stick with their sushi/sashimi - you will not be disappointed! Also, they deliver.

I love this place.  EVERY BIT as good as Ippudo with out the WAIT!!! I think their version of shishito peppers are better than Ippudo.  And their Short Rib buns are out of this world.  I think I could gorge on these alone. Their ramen has more depth of flavor than Ippudo's and I didn't get that buzz that I normally do from MSG as I did at Ippudo.   Both places are great, but Zutto has NO LINES.   I would go here if I had a lot people joining me, but I like ippudo only because of the scene.

A great breakfast sandwich to go is so hard to find in Montclair. I'm a native New Yorker and miss the ability to grab a sausage, egg, and cheese from places that don't expect you to stay.  I have had several menu items from Mac Attack so I was already a fan. Then I found out they do breakfast 7 days/week.  Finally satisfied my desire to try one this morning. Loved it!  They can work a little faster but this isn't NYC after all so I'm spoiled. But the sandwich was delicious!  Hit the spot and let me do what I do best, move on to the next thing.  A great breakfast sandwich to go has finally arrived in Montclair.

Yelp don't lie. Those brussels sprouts are ridiculous. We came here and sat in the bar area after leaving another restaurant that was crazed. Ilili was an oasis of tranquility after that. There were five of us and we split several small dishes. Kofta was delicious, and the hummus, and the moussaka. Brussels sprouts won it all. Pretty good service considering it was the bar area and we had just walked in. Beautiful interior deco.

A lot more space now that they have renovated and I love Sunday brunch with live music. The food came out pretty fast and the food was good. I have noticed a lot of the items tend to taste the same but are still delicious and there are some unique choices on the menu.
Super food. Simple but elegant choices, very classy menu, reasonably priced, great Bloody Mary and a nice iced coffee in a mason jar.

Came here with my friend for a post work out drinky drink. We had blueberry martinis, bruschetta and house salads w/chicken. DELISH. Im still adamant that Rizzutos has the best house Salad in CT. Their bruschetta was also super delish. So far I have been here 2x and have yet to be disappointed. They're still on my list!

I'M VENEZUELAN, THEREFORE I SHOULD KNOW WHAT'S GOOD SO READ ON... Ok this place is good, it's tiny but pretty. Sometime they have live music, it's fun, but at times a little too loud because the place is very small.   The cook unfortunately is not Venezuelan, therefore not everything tastes Venezuelan... so, what's good there?  Almost everything on the Appetizer menu.. or as the menu says "Antojitos" to be more specific the items below are delicious: MIni Cachapas: Sweet fresh corn pancake with Venezuelan melted cheese Tequeños: Deep fried white cheese sticks wrapped in wheat flour dough MY FAVORITE: Mini Empanadas:Cheese, shredded beef, chicken, baby shark House Salad Mini Arepas con Nata: bite-size crispy arepas with venezuelan sour cream. The rest of the stuff (rice, steak and other dishes) are not all that, some don't even taste Venezuelan, so not worth it. The big arepas are ok, they take out the extra inner "dough" so you feel like you are eating a crunchy tortilla and that's not traditional of Venezuela.  But they are ok... just don't think that's how it's done in Venezuela. The traditional Venezuelan drinks are good, like the Chicha, a little bit too thick for my taste but not bad in flavor. I'd recommended to my friends, but only if they've got the munchies, not for dinner or anything like that.

I went for my 35th birthday dinner - and they truly made it a night to remember. The food and ambiance were exquisite. The staff were of course courteous but also caring and very mindful. Thank you Bouley for a lovely evening ... and delicious cake!

I decided to go here for my anniversary since a waiter who use to work here, still recommended it. Parking on the street was much harder than i thought. I did the parking lot thing ($30)suv. My first mistake was not  making reservations,  thinking I'm getting there early, wont be busy! But it was. The girl working the door and the host were extremely nice. It was packed, but they turned tables over really quick, 15min wait, with a glass of Duvel Green;). So now the actual review- Service- extremely nice but very slow. the manager had to take my order after she saw me looking around,  sooo inattentive to empty glasses off drinks(refills), and empty plate's pasta) Food-  bread(good), breaded mozzarella), breaded shrimp(good), calamari(bad), ceacer salad(good), 3 pastas- spaghetti(good), boar ragu(good), pesto(good), pollo limone(good), steak- (overcooked but good), cheescake(good), zabaglione(good)

My friends and I love going to Taste Good.  It should be called Taste GREAT!  I always order their Malaysian Singapore Laksa.  It's spicy coconut milk noodle soup with egg, shrimp, and a little bit of everything.   Mmm!!!  We are never ever disappointed when we go.

My ode to The Smith...this place has a special place in my heart. No matter what location I go, the service is great, the staff is informative and don't pressure you, and the food is always incredible. I've been there for Brunch, Lunch, and Dinner, so I have a very good perception overall of the quality. For Brunch, I would highly recommend the Belgium Waffle or the Potato Waffle Benedict...do you see a trend happening? The best part about brunch-a free cocktail or fresh squeezed juice with a menu option. We went for dinner the other night, and our server was great. We ordered the fried green beens and the potato chips covered in blue cheese fondue. Holy Happiness. For dinner, I had the special, which was paella. My friend had the chicken pot pie, and I will definitely be trying that next time! Both were large portions, served steaming hot, and delicious. Cocktail recommendations: The Sweet Wilbur made with Berkshire bourbon,  sugar maple, cider, bitters, and vanilla salt. The Tickled Pink was delicious too! Overall if you're looking for a good place to stuff your face, meet friends, take a few drunken photos in the photo booth, and guarantee good food, The Smith is your place! Tip: Make sure to make reservations! It's always busy.

Such a nice surprise to actually get GOOD steak on a Philly Cheesesteak Sandwich.  I am not a cheesesteak lover but my boyfriend hence why we wanted to try this new place. I took a bite just to try and I was empressed.  My chicken sandwich was good but I should have listen to them with the suggestion and put the sauce on it. I ended up putting sauce on it at home and it was just the touch I needed.  I think they have a good thing going here. We will be back.
Whole rotisserie chicken $8.50, Yellow rice: $4.50. Well-priced,Delicious, Manhattan-based pollo rico y aros? Priceless.....

I just got take out there with a friend. The food was very fresh, very healthy,very well spiced - delicious overall. The bread was great too. It would be great if they had delivery. The two of us ate for 16 dollars, and we are stuufffffed.

Apparently not a new addition to the neighborhood - opened six months ago, yet somehow I never noticed!  I'm getting lazy... As a warmup to Sunday night movie night, this place makes a good stop on the way to see an Action flick and waste some time. Pumpkin fries with spicy mayo, I'll take it.  These were damn tasty.  Also had a very basic pad thai, which although on the oily side, certainly did hit the spot for me.  It wasn't a traditional pad thai, but a sort of asian fusion take on the dish.  Nice. What really was the best though was the papaya salad which had apple, pears & cashews.  Now that is a great spin on an old favorite and very welcome.  Come just for this salad! The space overall is very large, and open, with a bit of an unfinished industrial feel.   Touched up here and there by some interesting artwork, it is topped off by the big red neon LOVE sign near the entrance.  A bit loud for a date, if that's what you're going for.  But for a basic hangout, or to fraternize with the NYU peeps, this is a good spot.   "Cooking is like LOVE; it should be entered into WITH ABANDON or not at all" - Julia Child Nice quote on the wall!
best margaritas I ever had!

This place serves fattening, disgusting, awesome mouth orgasms.   And, since it's not the kind of place that you can go to and say, "What's healthier? The fried PB&J or the grilled donuts with ice cream and chocolate covered bacon?", there's no guilt. Or, maybe, guilt but less of it.  I mean, I'm here. I have to eat something!  Even if it is fried chicken and waffles with bacon and maple syrup.  OH!  BAD, very bad.  At least I didn't get the "Red Velvet Baby Maker" adult milkshake... BTW, the service rocked both times!  The second time, we got nail art tips from our male waiter.  He was such a cutie!

This place is more like a 3.5 stars! On a whim we decided to try this rather new Thai restaurant and definitely enjoyed it! It was pleasantly different from what we were expecting. I'll cut to the chase. Get the LARB.  We got the crispy pork larb dish and we absolutely LOVED it. The other dishes, while different and interesting, are nothing compared to the larb. Delicious! We ordered another clam dish in a red sauce and it was only ok. I don't think the clams were cleaned very well, and to be honest I noticed that a lot of the clam shells were empty. Another note is that the portions are rather small. So perhaps for Asian cuisine standards, the value isn't as good. If we were to come back, we will order wayyyyy more larb (and try the other types of larb too)!

Cheap pitchers. Kareoke on Thursdays. (but be warned, they play you singing without the music in the bathrooms) Great bar atmosphere. AND THEY HAVE CURLY FRIES. They also usually have $1 tacos, or some sort of cheap food special.
Like how they're open late! Good pizza, as well. A good place to come if you're hungry late.
El menú es limitado pero el sabor de los fideos es extraordinario, el ambiente es informal y sirven bebidas alcoholicas
Some of the best Mexican I've had in NYC. Small and cramped but the quality of food and drink make up for it.

This place is delicious. So delicious. There's great deals, especially for lunch.  If you're looking for some good traditional lunch food that even the Japanese frequent often this is the place to go.

Edit: I just wanted to say that since I've moved out of New Haven (as of 6/2008), I've had dreams and cravings for the Ebibaba roll. It's THAT incredible! My boyfriend and I had dinner at Miya's tonight to celebrate-- and I have to say, even occasion aside, it was hands down the BEST dinner I've ever had. EVER. Sushi and non-sushi, and for a Californian, that's saying quite a bit. For one, the sushi, though non-traditional, is the epitome of so many things that define our culture today-- it is simultaneously experimental, creative, and diverse, all the while satisfying, surprising, and delightful. The space Bun and his staff have created feels like home, and the hospitality is warm and friendly. Miya's has a wonderfully eclectic environment, from the NYT-mentioned record of Puccini's Madame Butterfly in the women's bathroom to the portraits on the wall and the sushi-themed clock in the main room. The menu is practically a novel of Miya's creation-- and at that, a delight to read. Bun is also incredible company, and I'm constantly amazed by what he creates. Favorites/don't-miss-dishes: Ebibaba roll (the most incredible roll of the night-- an amazing combination of lemon dill sauce, tempura shrimp, potatoes-- OMG), Mighty Mother Earth roll, Zoompa roll, and the Water Piglet roll (probably one of my all-time personal favorites-- tuna, cranberries, goat cheese, yum!)... not to mention the dessert roll, Seven Deadly Sushi (an amazingly flavorful dessert roll with super small scoops of rose ice cream, another OMG). So good. Miya's reminds me why I live... to eat. :-) Love it!

oh MAN I had a great lunch here this weekend!  I developed a craving for Mexican that was too strong to ignore, so I hopped on my trusty steed and cycled down to Los Gallos.  This place has been getting almost as much buzz as Hardena, but I wasn't overly impressed with Hardena, so I wasn't quite sure what to expect. What I found was a pleasant space with Mexican groceries, bins of dried hot peppers and a radio pumping out Spanish Monster Ballads.  The menu was straightforward and so was my order; I decided to go for the chicken tacos.  I took a seat at one of the five tables, and about ten minutes later I was serenaded with three tacos, two sauces and a grilled jalapeno.   What struck me the most was how fresh and clean the flavors were - starchy corn tortillas cooked perfectly, melted queso fresco, a sprinkling of onions & cilantro, and a delicious avocado-based spicy sauce for dressing.  What this place lacks in frills it makes up for in taste and price ($5.50 for all of that!) I wish that Los Gallos was closer to Center City so that I could go more often for lunch.  However, I will definitely be making weekend trips to explore their menu.

Luke 's Lobsters is am affordable hidden gem for the lobster,shrimp, and crab lover. Serving a heaping 4 ounces of meat on hot dog rolls with a tasty seasoning may sound unimaginable,  but the food there is absolutely delicious. They allow you a choice of a combo which allows you a drink of your choice and a bag of chips (kettle in various flavors.) Their sodas are organic and incredibly delicious. I liked the Blueberry Root Soda. They call your order by your ticket number and their is little to No wait for it. The only negative about the place is that for it to be such a great place to eat, the seating area is very small. I would recommend this place to anyone who wants an affordable, quick, delicious seafood helping while downtown in Philadelphia.

Amazing food.. was impressed by the authenticity of all of it. I don't understand why this place only has an average rating! The food was absolutely delicious. Service wasn't super amazing and we weren't allowed to sit outside, but the people were nice and the atmosphere was relaxed. I ordered two eggs with bacon and got way more than just that.. Homemade ketchup that went amazingly with the potatoes; Homemade applesauce with green apple chunks; Biscuits with homemade apricot jam; Boyfriend's pumpkin bread. Recommended!

As far as pizza in New Haven goes, this is the best place I've tried. I think the pizza dough is better than the other hot spots. I like it better than Sally's or Pepe's - what can I say - the decor is comforting to my eyes, the service rocks, the beer is good - I can spend some time in here. At Pepe's or Sally's, I just don't feel that comfortable, and who enjoys their food when they aren't comfortable. Did I mention it's open late? And it's around the corner from my place.

Brought a visiting foodie friend here for dinner about a year and a half ago. The food was delicious if overpriced, BUT... after my husband made a pun involving the pickled peppers on the menu, the server glared at him and asked curtly "Are you done? I can't handle this today." This was immediately followed by a long awkward silence. What the hell? We were given a new server immediately although our original server was clearly still working. My (slightly drunk) friend asked our new server jokingly "aren't we fun?" and the new server replied dryly "Yes, you are having fun." Oh well, perhaps it was worth the story but I am sad to say that even though I loved the food and it is about a block from our apartment, we have vowed to never return. If you do decide to go, remember: NO PUNS.

I've been to Cafe Renata several times while visiting friends in Philly.  What a cute place!  The owners go out of their way to make you feel at home.  I've tried the soup and a couple of sandwiches and was completely satisfied. The baked items are AMAZING, very fresh and oh so homemade !!!!!!!  Love this place.  Keep up the good work !

VERY VERY well served & cooked Mexican food .. also has scrumptious cheeseburgers and chicken fingers.. New they sell beer which is even better =) , recommended to all who likes a good place to relax and enjoy your food .. easily 5 Stars Very well set up also !

Yes, it's as good as everybody says.  Anyone who wrote a bad review did so because they had developed unrealistically high expectations beforehand.  If I had to say something wrong, I'd mention that they can go a little to heavy on salad dressing sometimes. Stop reading reviews, and just go.  You'll be happy you did.

the only real diner in the upper valley! I grew up in west lebanon (across town) and the four aces was the diner of choice back in the day. white river had two diners...the polkadot and lena's lunch. just up the hill from there was the tally house and howard johnsons, but now they're mostly all gone. if you're in the mood for quick, nothing magical, just coffee and grub, perhaps you might be better served at denny's on route 12a in west lebanon new hampshire. why waste time talking about the place being "real"? well, it's central to this...the folks that own and run the diner are on hand and at your service upon request. there is live chatter at the counter or you can have a seat at a table and talk with a friend. the bottom-less cup of coffee is special to the atmosphere...a person isn't ever made to feel rushed or herded out like cattle in order to make a turn over rate. daily specials: they've got them great attitude: they've got them coffee and food: they're making great food...and having fun doing it

The people really make this place. Everyone is genuine seeming and polite. They do a decent job with some southern staples but the menu just seems a little short for me. The beer selection is small as well but very well rounded. I'm sure anyone could find something that they like. They also carry Blenheim Ginger Ale. I'll keep coming back.

Going to Geno's is kind of like running up the Art Museum stairs, jumping up and down like Rocky and then getting your photo taken in front of the Rocky statue.  At the end of this excursion you feel dissatisfied and left wondering "why the hell did I do that?"  There's a reason the Rocky statue is hidden off to the side of the Art Museum.  It's just not that good.  Go inside the museum.  It's amazing!  Run the eight mile loop around Kelly/West River and finish at the top of the steps soaking in the view and feeling the burn of your quads.  Watch the actual Rocky movie to see what Philly used to look like and shed a tear when he wins but don't run up the steps like a tourist because that's what you think you're supposed to do.  There are so many other places to get amazing cheesesteaks.  Don't settle for a hyped up experience.
I cant even get into depth about my love affair with Uva. I just dont have adequate time! I will update later, but Uva is my go to wine bar Italian restaurant in the Upper East Side. IN LOVE.

My wife and I went this past Saturday with a friend and our 19 month old daughter.  We forgot her booster seat and the waiter was nice enough to run out to his car to grab one he keeps around for his own kids.  What a nice gesture.  The food was great and the beer selection was outstanding.  Great Food, Great Beer, Awesome People!  Can't wait to go back.

Jerry's is definitely my favorite sushi. The place is small and fun, they have hand made origami birds hanging everywhere and this huge drum they play if its your birthday and they give you warm moist towels when you sit down. They treat their guests with a lot of respect and really make you feel wanted and like they appreciate your business. Yes, the place is older and not contemporary but I have never found it to be unclean in any way. I love their ginger dressing (I actually get a large container to take home with me when I go) there tuna is very good and it's one of the very few places that I don't have to ask them to please NOT chop up my fish to tiny tiny pieces before making me a spicy tuna roll, they give you the whole large piece of fish in the roll. The special rolls are good like the Jimmy roll, Jerry roll but my absolute al time favorite roll from anywhere is the Double Daiko roll. I don't think it's on the menu but its amazing so ask about it. This place is great. I would MUCH rather come here for Sushi then one of the trendy places who's food is not as good and where the people act as though your an inconvenience to them.

This place is a great little gem in Manhattan. From the outside, you could easily miss it. Inside, it has a very nice hipster vibe, wood decor, a fantastic centerpiece bar, and a nice overall ambience. The staff is a bit inattentive and you have to wave down the waiter to be noticed (we were sitting in a corner), but the food, that is the winner for sure. I ordered a fillet mignon that was a pretty good sized portion (came with spicy onion sauce, tomatoes, and fries--very filling) and with tip and all it was $22. Compliments to the chef because the meal itself was extremely tasty and well-cooked. Would recommend this place.

I tried the famous Ippudo with my friend last night. But unfortunately I felt too much MSG in the soup, in my ordered "Shiromau Ramen". It was all the fats pork soup, so I couldn't taste it but later on my foot become red and swollen :(  I will be not returning...

Great falafel, though be sure to specify if you want the included hot peppers or not since they're pretty spicy. The sandwich is a great deal at a little over $6 and I even got some extra tzatziki sauce on the side.
Kinda pricey considering that you can get larger and cheaper sandwiches elsewhere. However, the five spice pork belly was nicely made, and the sandwich was crispy. Will come back again.

Went there for happy hour and loved it! five dolla holla and a buck a shuck? Winning! My friend and I love oysters! They were delicious. Only thing was after we left, we were still hungry haha but thats because we have a big appetite. We order the blue point oysters, chicken satay and mussels. For Drinks we have the blue hurricane. I think they were a little water down, but thats my opinion. Everything was good, our bill was 36 dollars for 3 drinks and alot of apps because we ended up reordering everything AGAIN :) We will be coming back! *Tip- Go early the bar area is small and will get cramp when all the business peeps are out of the work.

People only say good things about this place out of loyalty for Bill Woods. Other than that it's the worst place in the gayborhood to eat. I've tried time and time again to swallow my proclivities and I'm dissapointed every time. One of the worst meals I've ever had and the service followed. Stay away.

In NYC on business and get so, so tired of the places catering to out-of-towners. Found this on Yelp.  What a delightful discovery.  Was well worth the cab ride up there. Being older than the rest of the clientele (okay, may have been as old as most of the diners' parents) will tell you what mattered to us: - creative food & atmosphere - quiet music We could engage in conversation without shouting. - wonderful service - immaculate from floor to tables to restroom We both commented that this reminded us of one of our favorite restaurants which happens to be in Rocheport MO called Abigail's. We had pasta of the day and the Vietnamese beef salad which were both excellent.  This is such a teeny tiny negative, but the side salad with the pasta had only greens and a light dressing (quite yummy).  I think a couple bites of fruit on it would have added a lot. Took a long time to get our food, but it didn't matter.  The atmosphere was soooo friendly.  We just enjoyed feeling like we were not in let-us-rip-you-off Manhattan. Big disappointment that the date bread pudding was not available.  Server even apologized (apologized!!) and gave us the chocolate souffle.  Gee, a cold glass of milk would have been good with that. We were concerned we might not get in after reading the reviews of it being so small.  It is, but should that happen, there are many restaurants in the neighborhood.  Worth the wait if you have the time, though.

Very nice atmosphere, interior, Euro-shabby chic dressed waitstaff, etc. Party of three arrived at 9 pm on a Saturday night for dessert and drinks. Were told by Borat the maitre'd we would have to wait 15 minutes for a table. Stood by bar for 45 minutes, watching several parties of better dressed people be seated. Were pitied by bus boy and one waiter, who gave us some nuts to nibble while we waited. Everyone was gracious and nice. Finally seated with our drinks, ready to order. When he discovered we only want to order dessert, Borat informs us that only dinner is being served but we do have the option of "the sofa," saying with a slick smile "You can stay there all night." Not being the bitchy type, we blithely followed him over to a small sofa tucked behind the Fooz-ball table, in front of a window so drafty we put our jackets back on. There was no table in front of said sofa so we awkwardly held our drinks or had to turn around to put them on the chilly windowsill. (Did I mention it was cold?) Luckily, Borat came to our rescue and brought us a CHAIR to use as a table. A CHAIR. As in the thing one's derriere touchs, not generally used for food consumption. Laughing at the absurdity of the suddenly terrible service we were receiving, we quickly ordered 2 desserts (which tasted fine), paid our bill, and walked past Borat, who cowardly averted his gaze as we walked past him. The food looked delicious and I'm sure if you were ordering a full meal you will enjoy yourself. And if you're looking to sit on a frigid sofa balancing your plate in your lap like family Thanksgiving at Grandma's, ask for the VIP sofa seating.

We thought the food was excellent! The menu was interesting and varied and the food was really good! The place is small (we sat near the entrance which was a bit cold when others came in), but we had a really excellent meal and would recommend this restaurant!

Chicken Florentina with spinach/mozzarella over gnocchi. It's just so--I mean, it's like--and the sauce--that gnocchi--oh my God--it's just--I DIE. (Somewhat literally, because this dish has got to be pretty horrible for you, but take one bite and you will no longer care.) Piccolo's was my go-to when I went to TCNJ, and I still crave it (particularly the aforementioned beauteous gnocchi dish) all the time. The pizza has creative, yummy toppings, and any entree I tried was really good (but granted, I just went for the chicken florentina 9 times out of 10). I never really noticed the service because gnocchi is much more important to me; ditto with price. This place brings out my inner fattie and I'm totally OK with that. YUM.

I knew the old owners and they were nice. Went in more recently to find out they retired and its under new management. The new staff was even friendlier and actually conversated with the people rather than just watching them eat. As for the food, I'd say its pretty consistent as it was with the old owners, however i do taste a slight improvement on the pizza which is always a good thing.

Great environment and layout.  Had brunch there and generally brunch places are really cramped but the seating and decor of the restaurant made me feel as if I were in a garden/outdoor type setting. The food was average --the only thing that really stood out was the short ribs hash.  We also had the breakfast nachos, something I only tried because I've never seen that any where else before, but not really something I'd recommend for breakfast.  The menu was also lacking with only about 5 main dishes. All in all I think it was the feel of the restaurant that made it for me.  Definitely would want to try dinner there sometime.

I love White Dog. The menu got a little stale about 2 years ago, where it was the same for months on end and the meals weren't that great, but since they swapped up the menu ---- amazing! Really enjoyed some of the flatbreads and salad dishes. Everything is always so fresh and flavorful. The service is always friendly - the hostesses are helpful and smiling and the staff have a sense of humor and are always available when you need them. The cocktails kick butt too. I love coming back here every time I'm in Philly.

Bocca rossa is a perfect place to Unwind......As soon as you walk in your greeted by friendly people !!!! It's has the New York feel with a taste of Italy.  The happy hour specials are unbeatable...can't go wrong with 1/2 price bottle of wine an prosecco !!!! The food blows any italian ristorante outta the water, true authentic Italian cuisine at it's best !!!!! I highly recommend to anyone visiting or going out in hartford !!!! Perfect location with the perfect people !!!!!

Why oh why did I even go back here? Because it's a stone's throw (literally) from The Half Door? Damn the convenience of it all! The Half Door has pretty decent food- why didn't I just eat there? It was late, in my defense, and some post-beer pizza was just the thing to satiate a fast food-esque guilty pleasure. Two massive, massively greasy slices of pizza at Sisson Pizza made me truly reconsider some of my life choices--  after the first bite alone. Filled with remorse but a sense of no going back, I finished both slices and shook my head in disdain. This just isn't good pizza. There's no other way about it. So, as the 2 stars say--  meh. I've experienced better.

This is one of those tiny little places that unless you knew it was there you'd miss it. You have to check it out. The hotdogs are delicious and they come in some interesting combinations. The owner is friendly and the food is good. I will definitely eat there again, and again.

I guess it was my fault for expecting a lot from Village whiskey after hearing so many people rave about the burgers. I had the village burger with a few add-ons. Honestly, the burger was good but I've had WAY better burgers from some of the local neighborhood bars near my house for half the price. At &18+ per burger if you want a couple extras (cheese, fried egg, etc), try it once to say you did then stick to the neighborhood spots. Duck fat fries were very good I will say, but a tiny portion for the price. The cocktail I had was definitely unremarkable. Plus, our bartender/server had a strange arrogant attitude that was offputting. All-in-all just a really lackluster experience.
Good place. Tasty food and attentive staff.

I had heard so many things about this place, but I went I was pretty disappointed.  Even without the hype, I don't think I would have been that impressed.  (I'm rating the  When it comes to siu lung baos IN the US, there are better places such as Din Tai Fung. (even though those have a Taiwanese spin)  There is even a better place in New York (I'll have to dig up the name of the restaurant).   If you do go, stick with the pork dumplings.  The seafood one was not good.  In any case, this place does not live up to the hype.

After hearing a recommendation from a friend, I decided to go out and check this place I must say the place looks really nice and the stuff is very friendly but for paying top$$$ for the food I was expecting  little more from this restaurant. Again the food is not bad, but its defiantly overpriced.

Stopped in for a midweek late meal based mostly on location. (We were parked nearby). The restaurant was almost empty.  We received a friendly welcome and were seated immediately! Although their menu include a variety if foods we both settled on pancakes and tea. I ordered a side of crispy "Taylor Pork Roll", for $4.95; my husband ordered a tiny bottle of Real Maple syrup for an additional $2.50. I can't tell you how disappointed I was in the tasteless buttermilk pancakes : (.    My husband ordered buckwheat and commented that he should have ordered the buttermilk.   The meal was $30 something and we won't be back.  For heaven sake, get a good pancake recipe PJs...you are a Pancake House!!! My three stars are for service!!!  We had a Great waiter and everyone said goodbye and thank you when we left :-)
I absolutely love this restaurant!  Great staff, good food. Nice ambiance.  Highly recommend!!
the best!
Tuesday nights are half off the app tapas plates!! Gotta love that. We ordered like 6 different plates and I had the coconut mojito and I was in heaven. I will be back.

This place is Amazing! I first came here with a girlfriend of mine who highly recommended this place. It's a very cute, cozy wine bar with a phenom menu! The wine is excellent and for the cheese lovers an interesting variety of cheese plates. The must-try's: Gnocchi...the best I've ever had! (believe the hype!) Nutella cake with hazelnut ice cream Tip: Reservations aren't accepted over the phone for a party of less than 5. However, we were able to score a rezo for 2 on open table! :)

My husband and I visit Samba quite often for lunch and never are disappointed. The food is always fresh and to the highest quality. We are always welcomed by the owner with the warmest of greetings followed by friendly attentive staff. Whoever decorated this restaurant needs to visit my house. Love love this place!

I'd really like to review the food at Churrasco Grill, but we never got that far.... We walked into the restaurant for lunch at 12:15PM on a Wednesday.   There were no customers at the time....and nobody greeted us...OK - We figured we could seat ourselves...We walked in and chose a table.   I'm guessing one of the reasons the person / people in back didn't know we were there was the TV BLASTING in the dining room...I enjoy a good soccer game, but this was way too loud for a dining room during business hours....We looked in the back - saw someone standing there....Yelled "hello"....No response...Tried 2 more times over 5 minutes...He never turned around.  Nobody ever came to the dining area.  Being totally unable to get his attention, our choice at this point was to walk into the kitchen and ask for help, or walk out and drive to a restaurant that would value or business.  We chose the latter.  Maybe we will try another time, but that probably won't be for a while.

All I can say is "WOW!".  All I have is love for Momofuku Ssam Bar!  My boyfriend brought me here last week, and the place is not very romantic nor does it have any ambiance, but the food was so good!

Sampan was a great meal for my group of girlfriends. We ended up doing the Chef's Tasting: 7 selections + soft serve for $40. I actually think we got more than 7 dishes though! This was a great value for the amount of food we got. We were STUFFED and happy by the end of the evening. FYI, if you do the Chef's Tasting, your entire group has to decide on the 7 dishes you choose, you don't each get to choose your own 7 :) Standouts: edamame dumplings, bao bun, kim chee fried rice, shrimp pad thai, crab wonton taco. Also the soft serve was so good! Each person gets two little cones of soft serve and each was a different flavor. The night we were there it was Cheerio Chocolate (literally tasted like Cheerios breakfast cereal) and Deamsicle (vanilla and orange). Only gripe: the cocktails are small/weak for the price being charged. Stick with wine or beer, you'll get more for your money.

They recently renovated so we stopped in while passing by.  The food is really good.  We've been there several times since, and everything we had comes out hot and tasty.  The big menu offers lots of choices and you aren't confined to ordering a "special fish" of the day like some places.  The fish that you liked today will be there next month.  Love that!  Tip:  Try their lemon potatoes as a change---really delicious.

The table side guacamole is unreal and the food is great! Also, the daily specials on margaritas are always fantastic. I've had some great and some not so great wait staff experiences, but overall I would highly recommend this place.

This place is great!  I've been there with friends several times.  The food never takes long.  Twice it was impressively fast!  Their waffles are exceptional.  Not all diners make good waffles, but this one does.  One time, my friend wanted an adjustment to the kind of cheese on his nachos, and the waiter was real nice about it and saw to it.  All kinds of food are done really well here~.  The atmosphere is great, and it's my new favorite diner in Essex County!
Did brunch this weekend. It was simple straight-forward and delicious.

Terrible! Just terrible! Pricey for what you get. For being Latin fusion the food is quite bland and boring, and took almost 45 minutes to arrive at our table...cold. The service is also lacking, slow and aloof. And don't even get me started on the parking situation. They valet your car right in the middle of Center Blvd! In traffic! The cops arrived the night we dined. What a disaster! I give this place 6 months.

I have been here twice. Right across the street from Carnegie Hall. The pizza is awesome and soups are good. Convenient when going to Carnegie Hall but wouldn't go out of my way for because it is a little expensive. Staff is very good. I would suggest reservations.

I went here with my boyfriend last night, a Tuesday night, because I bought a Living Social coupon. I probably wouldn't have gone to PYT otherwise, and it seemed like everyone else around us had the same deal. It was too cold to sit outside, but we did see a group sitting around a fire pit which looked cozy. Anyway, before we went, I read some reviews on Yelp, and noticed that every other review mentioned bad service. I gave PYT the benefit of the doubt... until I saw it for myself. I met my boyfriend at the bar where he was having a drink (happy hour until 8!), then we asked the hostess for a table to sit and have dinner. She was not happy. In fact she seemed like it was a huge annoyance to have to seat us. Our waitress didn't come to our table for a good 20 minutes. She forgot to get us waters for almost our entire meal. It seemed like the one waitress was taking care of the entire (full) restaurant! Though she was the nicest person working there.  We waited on our burgers for almost an hour. Mine was lukewarm, slightly undercooked, but not bad tasting. The ceaser salad was pretty good too, and whatever pumpkin beer they had on tap was excellent.   We should have stayed and eaten at the bar where we probably would have gotten quicker and better service. I think the bad service might be attributed to the fact that they had a higher volume of guests from the Living Social deal... but they could have prepared better for that! My boyfriend said it best, the decor and seating makes it seem like a froyo place, not a burger joint. After all that... I won't be going back.

So, so happy that we stumbled upon this place after drinking at Frankford Hall. The Californian in me loves Mexican, but cannot stand higher-end places like Tequilas or El Vez. To me, Mexican needs to be tasty, rich in flavors, hearty and NOT $20 for three teeny tacos. Hubby and I thoroughly enjoyed our date night dinner here. Guac is the usual, but the braised shortrib tacos were AMAZING (mixed with sweet potato on the bottom, and topped with garlic greens). Highly reco these if they are offering this special - the portions are huge and I was stuffed after 1.5 (granted, I had a bowl of chicken tortilla soup before-hand). The soup was super rich and flavorful, with large chunks of avocado and shredded chicken - this was not the usual, watered-down chicken tortilla soup that you get at most places. I literally slapped my husband's hand when he tried to take a bite (oops!). Hubby ordered the pork shoulder stew w/potatoes (Tinga Poblano de Cerdo) which was slow-cooked to yummy-ness. The flavors were deep and soulful...it was a super homey dish. This place is a slight trek from Rittenhouse Square and parking is kinda meh, but I highly reco checking it out if you're craving Mexican!

Friend and I dined here recently and everything from start to finish was perfect. Waiter was friendly and well informed about the menu and preparation of food. We tried the dips with pita bread. Three different dips bursting with flavor and warm fresh pita bread. Also had the crawfish appetizer special, which was excellent as well. For entrees, we had the delicious stuffed peppers and baby chicken that was probably the best I've had, crispy skin and moist chicken. The lemonnana drink was refreshing. The French press coffee was also wonderful. For dessert, the assortment of Cypriot pastries were yummy. The sticky date and chocolate cake was an absolutely perfect dessert - I am salivating thinking about the moist cake, warm caramel sauce and cool ice cream. It is a rarity but this is one restaurant I actually look forward to visiting again. The food is outstanding and the flavors are bright, something you do not forget. I love that the chef uses many fresh herbs in his dishes. I always disliked dill but after eating here, I've been converted! He used it well, so now I love it and actually cook with it at home. It is obvious the chef truly cares about the quality and taste of the food he serves. He checked on our table and made sure we were enjoying our meal. The prices are also extremely reasonable for the high quality of food. I can't wait to go back for brunch next time I'm in philly.

My January 14, 2009 lunch at Tia Pol The idea of having a business lunch at Tia Pol sounded exciting: tapas, wine, good conversation. The problem wasn't with the food. It was the server behind the bar whose hairy butt was exposed every time he reached for something above the bar. (Emphasis on the hairy...) Good Tapas! Bad ass....Can't seem to separate the image . Al Paradise

I'm updatin to four stars as this place has corrected the most serious problems with their menu, but the menu is still over-sweet and over-rich, really there is so much sugar flowing out of this place from the menu to the taps it's a diabetes factory, but it's up to you to handle your nutrition - local saturated fats and simpe sugars are still those things, local doesn't automatically mean healthy. Putting a couple of pieces of kale next to 1100 calories of saturated fats doesn't make it healthy. But still, in the tiny market of Burlington your options for actually good tasting food on an actually nutritious menu is very limited and when found as expensive as this place.
