Food is recently uninspiring so I agree with most comments posted. Fresh food shouldn't rely on chemicals nor preservatives so I'm lost as to why they choose to use these type of ingredients. It's just old fashioned thinking in a new world.

Love them.   I am a Parisian born lucky NY resident and grew up on good patisseries and treats.    I have lived in NY for more than 20 years and this is like being home.   Like Proust madeleine, this is my little paradise here.    Like a luxury treat in an awesome location.   I am a fan.

In over twenty five years of eating and drinking in NYC I had the really disappointing experience of being "cut off"  for the first time last night at Char - and yes, this by the same ringlet haired bartender mentioned by T.K. in his review. As someone who has held two NYC liquor licenses myself I'm pretty aware of this is supposed to work. And three middle aged people averaging a drink an hour talking quietly amongst themselves does not match any criteria that I can imagine for refusing patrons drink. The bartender is really reserved and lacking completely in personality but that was fine until after three hours of us eating and drinking he announces that "for our own good" he's cutting us off. Two of us had had three drinks and one of us had one! It was so lame and while I've enjoyed Char on two previous visits I would never go back to this establishment.

Five stars for the unlimited sangria for Sunday Brunch! Who can't get behind that?! However, two stars for the food. I have been to Calle Ocho twice now, and while it is one of my favorite places to meet friends on Sunday, the food leaves a lot to be desired.

People are awesome, expensive overly fancy drinks and a crowd of pretentious downtowners this is the place for you. While the atmosphere looked appealing the place was wall-to-wall with trendy looking people
Great food! Portions are small but, very tasty and you don't leave with the Thanksgiving "I'm stuffed" feeling.

Loveee this place. Nothing like bringing a few Pommes Frites virgins here and popping their proverbial cherry with a nice cone of fries and that oh so delicious Mango Chutney Mayo.  It is the only dipping sauce I ever get because I KNOW it's so good and won't disappoint. I haven't been back in a while, mainly because I've become VERY slightly health conscious, and no longer work in the area.  I'll definitely stop in the next time I'm in the area, it always seems so packed when I pass by on the bus.

Pros: great ramen, friendly staff, price, everything. cons: bathroom, too crowded, long waiting. they have the best ramen in town. Though it definitely worth the wait, try to avoid lunch time 12-2, or the dinner 5-7. Try to go there 2-5, then you will not have to wait too long for the delicious ramen ! CASH ONLY.

I went to Jamonera on a Sunday night to try out their 10 course tasting menu.  The decor inside gives a good feel as you walk to your table.  The restuarant itself is small and there is one bathroom that is awkward to wait for if there is someone else in line. The tasting menu was a great deal.  You get a lot of food for only $40.  I would highly recommend the mushrooms served on toast, crispy rice, and the shrimp with skinny noodles.  They were by far the best.  I am not giving Jamonera 4 stars because I thought a few of the dishes were made wiht too much vinegar.  The flank steak was ruined by vinegar, which was very disappointing. I also go the wine pairings with the meal and the waitress brought out 3 different wines, one for each of the course groupings I would go back if someone else was buying.  Not if I am paying, there are too many better places out there.

One of my favorite things to do is bike across town and down the west side path to Pier I cafe.  they have tastey pitchers of white sangria and Blue Moon  - and are very generous with the orange slices too.  Their veggie burgers are good and the Old Bay fries are a must.  We got a hummus app 1 time...that was the only thing Ive ever had here that wasn't good.  it's so nice out tonight....i think i just made my evening plans.

I went to Havana Social over the weekend for a friends birthdays for brunch and was pleasantly surprised with how great of a place it is. I usually do not get involved with the Manhattan brunch scene but Havana Social really changed my perspective on that. They were very accommodating with having a large party while taking care of smaller groups that were eating as well. The staff was extremely friendly and attentive the entire time we were there. When it came time to take our order and refill drinks, they were always there to check on us throughout our meal. In addition to the wonderful service, the ambiance of the place was fantastic! The attention to detail was spot on and the decor was awesome. What might be most important to some people was that the food was amazing! Even the plating of the food was quite nice and an added bonus to such a great meal. I ordered the steak and eggs and I was surprised with how great it was. Usually you don't expect to get all of that in one restaurant and I can't wait to go back!

Came here on a rainy Sunday for brunch before going to see a movie.  The menu was full of some of my favorite things; started with the mac and cheese ended with an Old Fashioned boozy milkshake.  Mac and Cheese was definitely the highlight, rest of the meal was pretty lackluster.  Not my favorite Starr restaurant by far.

Have been to the Moshulu many times. As a foodie, I think it's one of the best dining experiences in Philadelphia. Have had brunch, lunch, dinner and attended events here and have had great food and service each time...not to mention amazing views. And yes the brunch deal is probably the best in the city with unlimited champagne! Worth every penny.
Tasty. Great Malaysian food

I went to Eataly Italy twice in two days ... saturday night 7pm and told 90 wait for table, so sunday night returned and got instant table for two at fish restaurant. Octopus started was devine as was the salad for a light start. My partners fish main was NOT nice.  The Halibut special was an over cooked piece of "what could have been".  I had the scallops which was what it said on the menu and 'nice'. atmosphere was great with a great buzz of people and venue.   Service was disappointing.... waitress looking around at other tables and people as mentioning the specials ... waitress asks 'how's everything' during meal, and before i can respond she has turned around to another table and not even listening .. The best move was the gratuity example amounts circled in ball point pen for me to 'notice' when signing the credit card slip... desert (two small italian delights? passionfruit something, and nanoli?) was delicious with a lovely espresso made by a really nice barista. i'd go for the venue and atmosphere, but not the meal...

This pizza was ok.  After hearing much hype over the artichoke garnished pizza, I expected more.  Instead, i thought it was way too heavy and thick.  It almost felt like I was eating soup.  The margherita pizza was a nice treat however and was full of flavor.  I suggest trying.

We got the Tournedos Rossini (filet mignon with foie gras).  I thought it was really great- my medium rare was done perfectly, and if you like foie gras, it's a really neat touch.  I was actually much more into the side vegis though- the pureed/mashed carrots were addictive, and the brussel sprouts were good too (though both tasted too good to be healthy- probably lots of butter in there).  We also got the Big Profiterolles for dessert which I definitely recommend.  Overall- really good experience, great service, and cute restaurant setting.

Had a great experience!   Came in a group of three and ordered Philly Cheesesteak Egg Rolls (when in Rome...), Tofu Tempura (yumm yummm!!!), and the Chicken wrap dish.  It was a perfect amount of food for three people.  We also enjoyed some drinks: Pomargaritas and Astronauts (formerly known as the "Buzz Aldrin"). Loved the modern retro vibe! One of the most pleasant surprises of the night was the service.  I was extremely late for my reservation, so I was expecting to be skipped over and pushed aside, since this is such a popular place, but the hostess knew exactly who I was as soon as I rushed in, and sat me and my party immediately.  Huge kudos for that! Only one regret: not coming in a group of two so I could experience the hanging chairs!   ... I must say, though, sitting in the car seats was pretty cool.   i suppose I'll just have to come back again on a date.

Just one word. DELICIOUS. AUTHENTIC SOUTH INDIAN CUISINE YOU'LL EVER FIND.we went there since all our regular restaurants were closed by ten and this was the only one open at ten thirty.i had ordered south indian dosa(which is a rice & lentil crepe). The sambhar (lentil curry-staple to southern india) that came with that was so authentic that it literally transported me back to India.we were waited by sashi.he was very attentive and courteous.overall had an amazing experience. Will definitely be back for more. At least for their tasty sambhar.wish i had taken some pics of the food. Well,there's always a next time. Oh and btw since its authentic indian cuisine you might have to tell the waiter to turn down on spices if you cant handle it.

Stopped here for drinks and grabbed some guac as well on a Sunday afternoon.  Margaritas were excellent, guac was good, and our server was very friendly.  We sat outside but when I ducked inside for the bathrooms the inside looked nice as well.  Pricey ($10 for the margaritas) but good enough I didn't mind too much.  Would definitely return and try some more off the food menu.

It's really hard to find fault in this restaurant. To my luck (and surprise), there were a few spots open for outdoor dining, which I absolutely recommend for any sunny day!  The scene is great for people watching and relaxing outdoors. The service was great--a waiter who consistently checked on us (but not too much as to seem pushy or overbearing). The food was even better! For lunch, we shared an interesting cheese plate with spiced honey. We followed that up with flakey pizza (on flat bread) that was full of savory flavors. For lunch, the value was more than reasonable for the food we received!
Small portions, overpriced and rude staff

Underwhelmed from an expectation standpoint. The reviews about the food being overrated are true. Nevermind the money you pay, I do agree with it being overpriced. However, if you leave that out the food is at best mediocre and at worst bad. The Mac 'n cheese was totally lackluster and I expected a lot from the description. Burger was ok. Salad was not good. And the presentation left a lot to be desired. The one thing they get right is the ambience, but that only takes you so far. Unless they are trying to say that the food quality is that superior, it's really hard to understand the appeal.
Awesome fried chicken and waffles!

YUM! This is a warm and inviting restaurant with excellent homemade Italian food, excellent service, and reasonable prices. BYOB, which makes it even more excellent! I had the rigatoni alla norma, which is by far the best I've had in a long time. Sit outside, and you may feel like you are in Italy! Manhattanites don't know what they are missing.
good service tasty food music was a little too loud though, struggled to hold a conversation.

After waiting an hour and a half to be seated, my party of five was put at a table for four. While normally this would be acceptable, a larger table for six was open right next to us. When asked if we could move we were told this table was being held for a larger party. Five minutes later, TWO people were seated there. Although the food is great and very reasonable the people who work here clearly have no common sense and cannot run a restaurant efficiently. Be prepared for sub par service with your delish fajitas.

From my last experience at IHOP it So far so good! As soon as we came In we where seated and right away greeted by a waitress. Food came very fast and hot!  And the bill at the end was great for all the food we had. I would definitely come back!!

This is a horrible representation of what Puerto Rican cuisine should be.  The black beans tasted like they came out of a can and were boiled with just a little bit of salt!  The breaded steak was soggy and not at all tasty. Guess they forgot the adobo!  The seem to be catering to the non Hispanic that now have taken over the neighborhood.  They do not know the difference between authentic Puerto Rican food and what they are being served. Never coming back!

Cute little place with friendly staff. They have a really nice outside area in good weather. Only ate here once. My gnocchi was alright, the ravioli dish was good and the chicken francaise was excellent. The desserts were good too. We all split the ricotta cheesecake and the tiramisu.

Will never eat at tacobell again! The smoked pork is divine! It's more like real spanish food rather than american-mexican. quite affordable too. We've ordered from here twice now. Roomie loves the tacos, I love the huarache. We always get the #1 combo; taco, tostada and huarache for $8.25. Just wish they were open later. They close at 9:30pm, and I get out of work at 9pm. :(

my nephew got the southwestern steak while i got the bbq ribs, both wrapped in wheat. they came out hot, fresh, and oh so filling. each crepe cost only $4.50! will def return. and in fact, we did return -- for dessert 3 hours later after touring temple's campus! for $4, we shared a generous crepe packed with blueberries and raspberries, lined with raspberry sauce and nutella. my nephew could not finish his half of the crepe; i was pretty full myself, but the crepe was so good i managed to finish it off.

dear Yelp, whoever is telling you to remove this review should really go jump off a bridge and land on his face. this is NOT a secondhand review because I WAS THERE WITH MY PARTY, i ate the food and sat in the restaurant. this is honest review for anyone who's thinking about going to Basso. DO NOT GO TO THIS PLACE. see below for my original review that was probably seen by Basso and then reported it to Yelp (REAL classy you guys..) Wow seriously Basso? A friend of mine received a phone call about a review that was left, apparently it's not good enough. Please do not harass your customers over an honest review, this is unbelievable and extremely embarrassing on your part. Your food is good, I admit, but the review left was an honest review based on the overall experience, so RELAX. Did you really have to stoop so low as to chase down your customers with harassing phone calls and emails? Isn't this unlawful use of someone's private information? I would not come back again, and to everyone else reading the review, there are plenty of good Italian restaurants out there (Basta Pasta, Gemma, Via Della Pace, etc). But if you do go, remember never to reserve so they don't have your contact information, definitely don't leave a negative review either, or else they'll track you down. Your actions are extremely insulting to customers everywhere, please reconsider your place in the culinary world.

Overall it's a nice restaurant. Cool atmosphere, interesting menu, nice addition to the neighborhood in terms of variety of cuisine, but the food was lacking. Many of the reviews here convinced me to visit right away, but I left feeling pretty disappointed. My date and I ordered the Asparagus Terrine, Gnocchi appetizer, french fries, and Lamb Tatsoi w/ apricot. The ingredients were definitely fresh, but needed a lot more seasoning. Overall the meal tasted very bland and we had to rely on the black pepper to liven up the dishes a bit. I understand that it's good to use salt sparingly, but the lack thereof really made these dishes extremely underwhelming. If this was the bland Midwest, I would have understood the lack of spices and flavor, but not NYC of all places. Also, from the pictures that I saw here on Yelp, the lamb dish used to come with brussel sprouts and parsney chips... Other times kale and a ragu. What I had last night was braised (more like pulled lamb) on a bed of fresh spinach with ONLY ONE pickled onion and a dab of apricot puree. Pretty boring. The server was nice and pretty helpful, but there was a guy playing the most annoying things on the piano before finally getting into "enjoyable" melodies 45 minutes into whatever practice session he was on. Not entirely sold on this place. I feel like this type of cuisine might be better appreciated by others, but just didn't do it for me or date at all.

Tia Pol, a tiny slip of a tapas bar located on the western reaches of Chelsea was opened in July 2004 by two friends who spent time in Madrid and wanted to bring a taste of tapas back to NYC. This place is more innovative than your average tapas bar - the menu features regional Spanish dishes from all over the country. Catalonia is represented, as is the Basque Country, Galicia, Jerez - they're all here. Croquettes and juicy slices of chorizo are delicious and the wine list is well-chosen and diverse. If you like dry Sherry, now is your chance to experiment. They have a great selection of the Lustau sherries and the staff are always eager to discuss your beverage choices. Do NOT miss out on the INCREDIBLE fried chickpeas. Simply deep fried and then tossed in paprika and sea salt, these little crunchy/creamy nuggets are so addictively tasty! Tia Pol has gotten super popular and it's often crowded, but go a little earlier in the evening and you'll have a chance to sit back and chow down before things get too crazy.

Not worth the price and everyone raves about the truffle fries which I have had at the Capital Grille.  The Capital Grilles are much bettter... The Burger is very average.  Bettter than a Casual dining burger but, nothing special.  The fresh ricotta I had was a little too runny.  I expected a little more attention to detail and a lot more finese...

Avoided the place that was here for several years, then it shut down. It was raining and I saw a new sign up that said KITCHEN OPEN LATE. Under new management doesn't begin to say what has happened in this bar. Really friendly bartender. I had the Retro Burger and it was great. Good place to watch the game. NOW I HAVE A NEW NEIGHBORHOOD BAR!!!

Great Food! Nice Atmosphere! I Love It when they got the cigar roller there too! Coco Mojitos is excellent if you like sweet drinks! Sometimes Alittle too crowded and the tables are really close together upstairs. Other than that. Great Cuban Place To Try!
Came here for brunch, which is offered everyday. Food was amazing, price was right and service was great!

I'm very unhappy with the place at the moment. I call 4 times to make a delivery and got hung up on multiple times. When my order finally came it was completely wrong. Personally never ordering from here again.

Sandwich Theory is the best.  It's the best!  I've been coming here for a few years and I always try the specials, or whatever is new on the menu - I'm NEVER disappointed!  Ben (works/owns? the place) is a really funny guy and always has creative and clever ways to tweak dishes, whether it be a breakfast burrito or a Cobb salad.  He really puts the theory in Sandwich Theory.  Go Ben, and go ST!!!

Great beers on tap and in bottles and a delicious burger! The fella and I mentioned we were splitting the burger and fries, and they nicely split it before they brought it to us. We got there around 5:00 on a Wednesday night, and we were seated immediately... I was impressed considering the other reviews, but by the time we left, they were packed. Loved the atmosphere - dark wood, warm lighting, garage door they can open when it's nice outside. Service was amazing and the food and beer was delicious!

After stumbling upon this gem on a random Saturday evening we learned there was an excellent brunch deal and knew we had to come back. We went on a Saturday afternoon and they immediately sat us. The food was amazing. Most of my group got pizzas (the breakfast one was spectacular) and I opted for baked eggs which were good as well. For 20$ and food quality that good we will definitely be back soon!

hella good! really nice basic falafel and also interesting others.. its a 5 dollar pita sandwich (minimum) but if you get over that, its real tasty, my homie gersh is a regular and she hooked up the spot, good lookin out girl, catch you on the next trip. The red falafel balls are on point. Also I always have respect for a great pairing for a limonada, Respect indeed.

My girlfriend and I stumbled upon this place on open table..and it was AMAZING. The decor is excellent, the staff is very nice and friendly, as well as helpful.. and the FOOD: Tuna Tartare- incredible Squash dumplings- instantly a top NYC dish I had the duck for an entree and my gf had the fish. Both were excellent.. I will definitely be back

Oh sweet Jesus, do I love Brauhaus Schmitz. A good friend had been telling me about Brauhaus for over a year before I finally got a chance to sit down for dinner with him. I ordered veal schnitzel, weiner art, with potato pancake, a pretzel, etc. I wanted to try a little of everything. But the human body can (should?) only hold so much starchy, fried food. Veal is not an easy meat to prepare. Slightly undercooked or slightly overcooked, it's completely ruined. So naturally, fried veal seems a little tricky - it would easily come out very tough. Instead, it was perfect, and a thick cut of veal to boot. Everything I had was excellent, and I'll definitely be going back to try more of the menu. This is hands-down the best german restaurant I've ever experienced.

If the idea of ordering something from the menu and then having something totally different show up in front of you appeals to you, then this is the restaurant for you. What dish #1 was supposed to be: broccoli and cheddar scramble with creme fraiche and chives. And according to the waiter, one of their most popular dishes. What dish #1 actually was: watery scrambled eggs and broccoli, withOUT creme fraiche or chives. I'm a really terrible cook but even I could have made a better scramble than this. At least my egg scrambles aren't wet. What dish #2 was supposed to be: baked brioche french toast with almond custard. What dish #2 actually was: three pieces of custard. I kid you not, it was literally just custard. I may have found 3 flakes of what potentially was bread, but 99.7% of this plate was custard. We specifically asked the waiter what this dish was like, and he said oh it's really good but kind of heavy. Would have been helpful if he told us it was heavy because it was custard. It got to the point where we were both wolfing down french fries because they were the lightest part of our meal. That's never good.
Decent dumplings, nothing special

I chose this place for our (day before) Valentine's dinner. I was looking for something .. different .. then what is usually found around this area. This place stands out in the best of ways - a total change of pace. Saturday night around 9:00, everything was busy: the floor, the bar, the parking lot, ect. The dinning space seems small,crowed, and loud,  but it all just seems to work. They also had a few tables in the front of the house by big windows looking out into the main street which seem very romantic and appropriate for the occasion.   The host says "Okay, we have this table right here (middle of the floor, loudest area of the room) or there's seats in the wine cellar.' We looks at each other and say "WINE CELLAR". Best. Choice Ever. It seems strange at first: to long tables with place settings. We sit down across from each other .. we are between 2 other couples, about half a arms length away from them. After a little while, I got used to it and it had grown on me .. it was quite and relaxing and exactly what I was looking for. Food was awesome. It's not a incredibly extensive menu, but what they do offer is note worthy. Go for the mussels or the cheese platter as a appetizer .. the ravioli's were a great dinner too.  The menu also changes seasonly. Wine list was major.  Since it was a special night, I was lucky enough to drink vino from the "Caption's List" .. thats a list you don't want to miss !  :) Service was perfect. They were friendly and professional. The decor was modern and trendy with a vintage wine cellar below it all. I will absolutely be coming back here !

5 start restaurant in the category of Mid Priced BYOB. Great sized portions. excellent quality of food. great service and its BYOB, what more can you ask for. they only take reservations during the week. A great place for a date or to celebrate a speacial occasion.
If you like wine and generous pours... look no further...

Came here for lunch after a UCONN game.  It was obviously crowded and there was a wait but that was totally expected given the time.  There is plenty of space behind and around the bar so your group can grab some drinks while you wait. The restaurant manager was extremely friendly.  He regularly walked up to our group to keep us posted on which tables they were waiting on to finish so we could get seated. If you order the guacamole it is made fresh at your table with ingredients that are already sitting in a bowl on your table when you arrive.  They also bring warm tortilla chips and salsa.  I ordered the spicy shrimp quesadilla which I would argue was not spicy but I'm not complaining because it was still delicious.

Even though prices have increased (by a quarter or two), this is still my favorite banh mi ga (chicken) in the city. Its also the cheapest, most filling sandwich I have ever had. It costs $4.75 (used to be 4.25), but can easily be shared. It has fresh, crisp veggies and tasty, juicy chicken on a freshly baked bun. The bread here is enough to get me to come back over and over. I come out of my way to go here for a quick lunch. I like splitting the sandwich with a friend and then heading to Quickly or another nearby bubble tea place for a ridiculously cheap and filling meal for under five bucks!! Also, you never know when you might want to buy jewelery when you're scarfing your bahn mi. So they've got you covered. And they have outlets here...so I can charge my phone while I eat my yummy sandwich!

I came down to Prime 16 on a Thursday night to satisfy a craving for a good burger. I had never been, but have heard good things related to the food and beer selection. That's pretty much all I needed to hear. This is definitely one of the more upscale "burger joints" you'll ever go to. The hostess told me it would be about 40 minutes for a party of two. No problem. The beer list was good, so I had plenty to keep me occupied. I ordered myself a BBC Lost Sailor IPA, while my brother ordered a Brooklyn Lager, and by that time, our table was ready, only 10 minutes. The menu has an extensive list of burgers. My brother had the "Cowboy Burger", which had Canadian Bacon and a fried egg on top of the beef, while I got "The Smoker", which was topped with smoked applewood bacon, mushrooms, and gouda cheese. Both of our burgers were delicious. Some of the best we've ever had. The fries are very good as well, although the sweet potato fries are tops here. Our waitress was very good, didn't say a whole lot, but she was there anytime you needed her, unprompted, which was pretty impressive. The beer list is great as well. 20 rotating drafts as well as a pretty big bottled beer list. Pretty impressed with the selections. All in all, the food and service was excellent and I will definitely be coming back. There were so many other burgers I wanted to try, and along with the diverse beer list, that's plenty enough to keep me coming back.

From the first juicy sip of sangria to the happy group of hipsters at the bar, I loved Firebox on the spot. The space is minimalist with drama: thirty foot ceilings in the bar, antique beams and exposed brick. But it's really about the locally sourced food; pictured is my delirious starter of house-made charcuterie: chicken liver mousse, house-cured salmon and duck pastrami.  An entree of pan roasted cod perched on a bed of braised kale with bits of fingerling potatos and bacon floated on a mussel studded broth.Yum! Should have stopped there, but who could pass up chocolate semi-freddo, a dreamy dessert, halfway between mousse and ice cream? Heavenly. Here's more good news: Firebox is operated by the Billings Forge Community Organization whose aim is to revitalize the Frog Hollow neighborhood that it calls home, through job training and employment. The Kitchen at Billings Forge is a bakery, urban farm-to-table caterer, and center for cooking classes (check out the schedule here) and the Studio at Billings Forge provides a community space for educational workshops, enrichment programming and a low cost entertainment venue for local performances.

Had a tasty brunch here with some girlfriends.  They were very accommodating, even seating us as we arrived instead of waiting for the entire party to arrive (unheard of at brunch in Manhattan!).  The food was very good; simple dishes, well-executed.
Simply amazing!!! Came to this place because of the Yelp reviews. Ordered the Hot & Sour soup ($1.25) and 10 Dumplings ($2.00) and had leftovers!! Not much room to eat in but the place is awesome!!

Went to lunch here with a largish group. The owner or manager--the in-charge person, was not the warmest, but the waitstaff was terrific, responsive, and helpful in their suggestions. The food came quickly and it was plentiful. Look, I don't expect haute couture atmosphere from a local Chinese place, but it was perfectly nice. And the food was quite good-very, very good, actually, and I've spent plenty of time in excellent Chinese restaurants across the US (and China, but that doesn't actually count)...(except with Peking duck...)...(but I digress...) Anyway, definitely give this place a whirl if you're on Church street and overwhelmed by the crowds. It's off the beaten path, very tasty, and you won't regret it (unless you order the hot and sour soup and don't do the hot part very well...)

The wait time is usually pretty crazy, however it is a high volume establishment. It is a tad over priced and if you dont speak french you may have a difficult time understanding the menu. So I went with a burger and it was okay but not worth 16$, shake shacks would have been just as good for half the price!

We have just dined at Frere de Lys, what a wonderful experience in NY and a great find for UES. We are visiting from Australia. The meals were excellent my husband had the salmon and I the chicken, beautiful flavours, what a delightful restaurant, the decor is simple but beautiful so enhances the AMBIENCE, the personalities of these two young men running this restaurant make it a memorable dining experience.

Wonderful service, lovely food, excellent dinner!  They have pre-selected sides that they suggest to go with the main courses, but were very accomodating about making changes.  Especially good and unusual, I thought, was the red grapefruit-based sauce on the almond-crusted trout - yummy!

My girlfriends favorite italian byob. she loves it, i wish we could afford to go back tonight but I have -16.00 in my checking account. The price is affordable (if you have positive money in yours) and it ALWAYS tastes Great! The two guys that run the place are incredibly nice, they know our names, shake my hand, and couldnt be more friendly (they dont even roll their eyes at me when i walk in wearing my eagles hat). Class act! love it!

This pizza place uses the BEST ingredients.  They take a while to deliver, but worth the wait.  The mozzeralla is top quality.  Sause is authentic.  The crust has a very unique flavor.  They also have GREAT salads.  Expect to pay double versus any other pizza joint.  ....i think i'll order one right now!!!

Wanted a nearby place to stop by after a class at Society Hill Dance Academy, so Yelped and came across this place.  Walked by to check the menu before class and were greeted (warmly on the edge of too much pressure) by a woman out front of Las Bugambilias.  She told us the place was authentic best around, etc. etc. etc. so we told her we'd be back, which we decided before her advances anyway but she probably felt good fro "winning us over". Interior here is pretty cool.  I've never been in a Mexican grandparent's home before, but I imagine it's similar to this place.  A cool grandparent who has traveled the world and likes to booze. Menu here is large.  I don't want to say too large, but it made it tough to choose something.  Guess I'll have to come back.  Had the Enfrijoladas and tried some of the Enchiladas Verdes as well.  Neither were the bee's knees, but both far above average.  Guac was similar - not the best I've ever had but very good and something I'd order again.  Service was generally solid, drinks I had were big and strong so no complaints there. To compare it elsewhere it was better than Xochitl (and way cheaper, more selection) and probably not as good as Lolita, but the fact they have such a large menu and the space is more comfortable, cheaper leads me to thing I'd come back here before the others.  Similar to a Cantina, minus hipsters and noise.

Amazing Thai food. I got the Pad See Ew with Beef and it was fantastic. Love the thick noodles. And, for about $11 I'd say it was worth it. It's a small charming little place and I loved whatever Thai music they were playing (sounded like it might have been from a Thai movie soundtrack maybe?). My only (small) complaint is that the tables for two where WAY too close to each other. I know it's a Manhattan thing, but I'd rather just sit and eat at the bar with the person I'm with than sit at a table for two that's just too close to another. Also, I don't know if I was just lucky when I went, but the service was almost too fast!

The four of us went there today for lunch. The ambience is very Mediterranean and mellow, we liked it. We had the Tunisian giabetta sandwich and enjoyed every bite! The Mediterranean salad trio was very good as well. The other couple had some lamb dishes and says it was great.. I would love to come back with the kids but it seems to tiny to fit a stroller in between the narrow lanes in between the tables. I would probably think the same for a wheel chair.

Based on (2) visits, Cookshop is meh for sure.  The food is all pretty good, but for those prices, it should be pretty good.  While I am not one to usually complain about service/atmosphere, I do feel the quality of service suffers quite a bit because this place is Cookshop.  Last night, the server forgot my wine after about 20 min and just said oops sorry while my friends finished their food and I sat with nothing in front of me.    Not even a comped dessert.  Whatever.  Prob won't spend another $40 here again; not worth it.

We have been going to Hawthorne's since its opening weekend and have been recommending it to others.  We live around the corner and go here about once a week for a casual beer after work, or to stop in for a mixed six pack while on a stroll with our 1 year old son.  The weekday staff is always friendly and helpful.  Food is hit or miss.  The sandwiches are unmemorable and usually dry.  The brunch fare is ok; the breakfast burrito was good the last time we had it.  The beer is overpriced, but the price is about the same as other single serve places in the city, so I cannot complain about that.   What I can complain about is the service (or lack thereof) we received this past weekend from the female owner of Hawthorne's who was seating patrons for brunch.  We tried to get a table with my wife and son and our stroller and asked for a high chair.  She curtly replied that she could give us one but we would have to park our stroller outside.  I said we did not want to leave it outside because someone might steal it.  She rolled her eyes at me and my wife and said "you really think someone is going to steal a stroller?"  (inner voice-Yes lady, this is Philadelphia, people will steal anything!)  To which I said, yes, someone will, or we could just leave?  Another eye roll and she ran off to her husband behind the counter (the other owner).  We put our coats on and left without even sitting down.  We saw one of the weekday waitresses on our way out and complained to her about the situation and she apologized.  The female owner is rarely there.  If she was, she would have recognized that we support her establishment on a weekly basis. It is a shame that we had so many nice experiences at Hawthorne's, yet it is this one terrible customer service experience (and from the owner no less!) that forever changes my opinion of this place and makes me post a review on Yelp.  We will no longer patronize Hawthorne's.

Rating: 3.0, Date Dined: 7/29/2011 Café Katja is a snug and dependable place for Austrian food, further enhanced by an affable hostess who is obviously passionate about her restaurant. Service and Atmosphere The restaurant and its bar are tiny. There is a lot of squeezing by people to get around in this narrow16-20-seater but I guess that adds to the hole-in-the-wall, tucked-away vibe. Café Katja is appointed with functional wooden tables, chairs, stools, ledges. The waitress was very engaging and said that our wait would be shorter if we'd be willing to share a table for four with another couple. She called it "European style", so when in Rome, why not? The seating is not particularly comfortable. My friend sat on the banquette with a water pipe pressed against his back. But I guess this is how they prevent people from lounging around forever. Once again, the service was very pleasant and our waitress took great care in selling the dishes and explaining them to us. At the end of the meal, when she accidentally dropped another table's fork into our spatzle that we wanted to take home, she had the kitchen make us another to go without any hesitation. Perhaps the most charming aspect is that our waitress was all smiles, all of the time. Food & Drink My friend and I shared 4 dishes. The emmentaler sausage was very cheesy. It was accompanied by quark dumplings (fluffy but bland) and a creamy savoy cabbage. We also had the bratwurst with a traditional pickled red cabbage sauerkraut. Of the two sausages, I preferred the emmentaler. The soft pretzel was addictive. Its smooth crust on the outside encased a chewy, doughy interior. The dipping spread was a quark cheese blended with paprika, cornichons and onions - I loved this. Having just come back from a trip to Germany, I liked Café Katja's version better than the 3 other versions I sampled in Berlin. As a "side" we had the cheese spatzle with caramelized onions and chives main course. Anything covered with this much cheese is guaranteed to be tasty, but once it lost temperature, it was less exciting. We sampled a few of the beers on tap. They come in multiple sizes for sampling. The beers stand up to the restaurant's meaty-carby fare. Hearty Austrian food (enough for three people, really) and 3-5 beers came to around $73 for a dinner for two. Perhaps the mystique of this place was a bit lost on a sweltering Friday night in July, but I could see this as a go-to LES dinner spot on a chilly Fall or Winter evening.
service was much better before the renovation, still, it's ok. food is not bad. ok if you want to play it safe. very busy and if you want to people watch sit by the open front window
I love the cheese empanada they have here. The sangria is pretty good. Is a small place though, if you are in a hurry this is not the place to go. The wait is about 1 hour minimum.
Best Mexican I've had in Philly. The red and green chilli salsas are spicy amazing things. Thanks, Yelp!

Came here for Saturday brunch with a few friends. The food wasn't the worst, although serving sizes are extremely skimpy. For the amount of food received, prices are exorbitant, and should have been reduced by at least a third. The presentation of the food was sloppy, with food arriving jostled and out of place. However, it's possible that this was a result of negligence from the waiter. Service was lackluster. The food took a long time to come out, and the waitstaff were rushed, inattentive, and somewhat rude. This may not be important to some, but I was unsettled at how long we had to go before empty water glasses were filled or before empty appetizer dishes were cleared. Overall I was very underwhelmed. If you're hungry and/or don't like overpaying for tiny portion sizes, I'd suggest that you eat somewhere else.
Ordered the mac'n'cheese. It was really good, but the portion was way too small. :( They are open 24/7 :) They automatically include tip 20% :( Will give them one more try.

Food Quality: Fresh & Tasty, but not memorable Service: Inattentive and Slow Pricing: Overpriced for what you get My wife and I dined here tonight, on Sunday.  We entered around 5:30pm and the place had just a few people on the inside. Despite this, our sloppily dressed server was VERY SLOW to bring our simple drink order over. After asking someone to send server over, we entered an order for a Grilled Seafood appetizer special for $25.00, and a Braised Lamb special for $21.00.  Both dishes were generous in size and came out after 10-15 minutes and both tasted good.  Server took forever again to realize we were done, which enabled us to stare at our dirty plates for 15 minutes.   Afterwards, we walked over to dessert case, where the Asian woman who is co-owner of this place allowed us to try one of the deserts.  We proceeded to order 2 orders of pistachio baklava to go, only to learn when we were handed the bill that they were $7.50/each or $15.00 in total - this admittedly gave me some serious price shock. Now that I've tried the baklava after returning home, I can confirm that it tasted ordinary and was a total rip off. My wife and I do not plan to return here again.

Freshly prepared Lebanese food is healthful and delicious, and Wafa does it right and she does it with pride.  Hummus with olive oil was creamy and tasty.  I had never seen split pea soup in a Middle Eastern context before but it was hearty and hit the spot on a cold and gray day.  Wafa came out to make sure all was to our liking. Service by Wafa's son was attentive and friendly.  It is definitely worth a trip.
Terrific French atmosphere, beautiful waitresses, the best Americano in New York.  They also have lined up pretty good french pastries which are surprisingly hard to find in New York.

I like the Smith. It radiates a  casual cool in all aspects. Who cares if that cool was fabricated very meticulously? It works. The food is good - nothing incredibly spectacular, but enjoyable. It is a bit on the expensive side to the food that you get. Drinks can get pricey, especially the wines. Service is fine. The main course though is the atmosphere: The music being played is definitely cool and the staff have hipster tendencies. Dim lighting, fancy booths, funky lighting fixtures, wooden ceiling, tiled walls, nude photographs, and the sinks in the bathroom are awesome. For some reason, there always seem to be tons of hipster parents with their hipster kids here.

As you can see, my tender Yelping morsels, I'm chopping an awful lotta wood these days.  After all, there's not much surf IN NYC so what's a brutha supposed to do with all his free time? Get my grind on. So, we met a couple of the homies here last night for dinner - they were kind and cool enough to roll in from Jersey and set us up at this spot.  It's located on restaurant row right off Broadway.  We'd been asked three times if we were in a hurry to see a show (we replied "no" each time we were asked but that didn't stop everyone from asking us)...this lead me to believe that they are of the churn-n-burn mentality to roll people in-n-out right quick.  Smart formula given the proximity to where people see shows. It's actually a really cool set up - several different dining spaces and a really lopey little bar.  Very tight quarters but I reckon that would be standard for the area and NYC in general.   Service was decent enough.  For the amount of food one receives, the menu prices are extremely reasonable - in fact, I'd argue it's cheap.  Most entrees come with a salad.  One can add the three pastas (mid-course) they serve (which change daily) to the entree for an additional fee.  There're two wine lists - one more exhaustive (and expensive), the other less expensive (and cheaper)...if one knows his wines, the latter provide provides a nice arbitrage opportunity. Here's a quick breakdown of what we ordered: -Osso Buco - my boy was pretty happy with his selection (I didn't taste it) - my other boy scooped up the bone marrow so it was kinda like a 2-fer -Salmone - grilled and served with roasted cauliflower - this is what I ordered...it was a tad bit dry but generally okay -Ribeye steak - this thing was huge...like Shaq-sized foot huge...my girl couldn't put a dent in this thing, even after sharing much of it with the table I added the pasta mid-course to my meal.  The daily pastas from yesterday were swiss chard ravioli (kind of bland), farfalle in a tomato based sauce (the pasta was overcooked and the sauce tasted like it came from a can) and seafood (shrimp) linguini (this was actually pretty decent though the pasta was overcooked here as well). For desert, we ordered apple strudel served with vanilla ice cream topped with carmel sauce.  Interestingly, the strudel was a long, thin slice and had golden raisins in it...it added a little bite to the desert.  There was also a desert special - strawberries with whipped cream and some sort of balsamic vinaigrette...the berries were good.  Pretty tough to mess up whip cream...I didn't really care for the vinaigrette. In short, I would go there again ONLY if I were strapped for cash, starving or in a hurry to catch a show nearby. Not my favorite Italian but sometimes, it's about the company more than the food.  Luckily, the homies were solid so it took the focus off of and away from the mediocre offerings here. But, as always, decide for yourself... Great eating to you!

This was my first time having real ramen and I wasn't disappointed. My first visit was for a friend's birthday dinner here just a couple of weeks ago. We arrived on a Friday night between 6:30-7:30. Unfortunately, they don't take reservations and there were 8 people in our party so we had about an hour wait. A few of us decided to go just a couple of blocks down to grab a couple of drinks to pass that time.   We were seated in our own private area, which was good since if you're in a smaller party, you're usually grouped with other guests in several community tables. We ordered two orders of the hirata chicken wings and samurai ribs for appetizers. They were both quite delicious and I loved the sauce of the chicken wings. We also ordered a bottle of sweet sake for the table, which was pretty good considering I'm not a big fan of sake. I ordered the shiromaru hakata classic ramen. It was a great dish but I wished there was more of the pork. For dessert, we ordered 2 orders of the matcha brulee and one of the mascarpone cheese & ice cream..mm soo good. It was an overall great experience. I'd probably rate it more like a 3.5 to 4 and would come back again maybe at an earlier time to beat the rush for dinner or lunch here.

awesome pizza! the crust is perfectly thin, and there is a myriad of fresh toppings you can choose if you want to make a custom pizza. when we got there it was about 7pm and most of the tables were open. once we were leaving (around 8) it was completely full, and it was a a wednesday. even if you go early or later on you wont wait long, the service is really fast! the prices are so reasonable, my friend and i split a greek salad to start then each got our own 9" pizzas and with tip it was about $35, and the pizza was some of the best i've had so far!

DO NOT TAKE YOUR CHILDREN TO TRES CARNES!!!! They play profanity laced and racially derogatory music while customer are in establishment. I took my children after school last week for tacos...and we were greeted with foul and derogatory music playing at full volume. I complained to so called management to no avail. I have also posted this on the local mommy boards. Not a place for families.

A good friend of mine had a wedding there this past weekend and I can't even begin to tell you all of the things that went wrong.   While the place looked beautiful (completely decorated by the wedding party, dessert bar from a separate company) and the company was wonderful, this restaurant couldn't have done worse. For starters, my friend (the bride) was given one price, and after paying a deposit, the co-owner (who by the way has yet to respond to any emails or texts sent her), decided to charge more about 3-4 weeks before the actual event.  After that mess was settled, and my friend was directed to the "Events Manager" (who wasn't deemed manager of anything until the co-owner finally decided not to deal with the event at all).  The Events Manager had NO idea what was agreed upon and what was being done.  The last payment which was due on the day of the event, was requested on the day before at the last minute. They gave the wedding party about an hour to set up and the wedding commenced. The menu the bride decided on was buffet style with an open bar on premium drinks.  Apparently, the bartenders had NO idea that there was an open bar and charged some of the guests for some of the drinks they were not supposed to get charged for as that portion was already paid for.   The buffet area was quite interesting to say the least.  The food was presented on dinner plates for the guests to pick off of.  Not to mention the fact that the refills did not come fast enough, leaving some guests hungry.  The wedding party paid for 80 guests, maybe 10 didn't show up, and there wasn't even enough food for 60 guests.  On top of being charged extra for allowing the extra staff (unassociated with the restaurant -- dj's, photographer, emcee, etc) to eat being that some guests did not show up.  Oh, and did I mention that the bride was billed midway through the night for them.  Because of course, the manager in charge could not possibly wait until the end of the night.  The manager, who followed the bride around as she was trying to help clean up at the end of the night.... just waiting for a very small payment.  Did I mention that the groom's father didn't get a chance to eat?  Oh... should I also mention that the black beans weren't entirely cooked, the yellow rice (which was supposed to be paella - but I guess they thought it would be cute to bring out yellow rice when no one was paying attention because they didn't make enough), was tasteless, don't even get me started on the extremely underseasoned ropa vieja.... and the weak drinks some were charged for.   But I think the highlight for me, the entire night, was watching the Events Manager take pictures of the wedding with her phone, without anyone's permission.  The wedding which was a private event, the set up which the restaurant did not assist with, and pictures of the guests.  Yet at no time, was there a consent form allowing them to take pictures of the event nor was it included in the contract.  Tasteless?  Absolutely. I'm sure I'm leaving out many, many other things, however, after this week and that event, there will be plenty more complaints. If you're in the restaurant business, before you agree to do a private event (especially a wedding) maybe you should do your research and keep in mind that whatever you put in a contract, you're legally bound to.  And had the wedding party not been gracious, they could have very well refused to pay that final balance on the bill.  Good riddance Cubana Social.  We will never ever do business with you and we will make sure people know you're inept to handle private functions.

If I could give it zero stars I would. I guess the one star can be for the food. It was ok. Waited 25 minutes for our waitress to come over and even welcome us. Waited another 25 minutes for drinks, and we only had soda. Then after 24 additional minutes we hadn't even gotten our appetizer. The waitress brought out free guacamole. Waited 25 more minutes then she kept asking us if we wanted more chips. Still no appetizer. We cancelled it. 30 minutes later our entree comes. We eat it. We see a cockroach crawling down the wall. The waitress brings free dessert. Finally the check comes and the appetizer we never got was on the bill. Needless to say it was a miserable experience.

Long story short, kinda expensive but really delish Turkish fare. I've been to this place multiple times and the food always hits my satiety centre. Adana kebab and lamb shish are great. Their appetizers are ok. Try the cheese sticks and falafel. It could be a little pricey which always bothers me but still I go there. Try the Turkish tea as well. They have two parking spots right next to the restaurant reserved for the customers.
Akamaru, pork buns and shishito - flash fried Japanese peppers with yuzu salt

This is the only bar in Philly that I go to religiously.  Probably because all my friends do  and I know everyone who works there.  So this is, undoubtedly, a  biased review.  JB's = my second home.  Great beer, excellent food (now with fatter fries!!) and the best damn music in the city.  Period.

I am a native Philadelphian born and raised in West Philly.  We typically ate cheesesteaks from local pizza joints.  Well since joining the military 17 years ago, I decided to take my children to have a Famous Pat's and Gino's Steak.  Oh how aweful it was.  Pat's steak was bland, fatty, the fixin's area was dirty, bad customer service.  The steak was so bad, we decided not to go to Gino's and just tossed the Pat's steak in the trash.  We left and headed for a corner pizza joint.  Don't waste the time and money on a Pat's steak.  Go to South street or a local pizza joint in the hood.

The staff was the friendliest, accommodating our table of seven without much wait. The guacamole was amazing and probably my favorite thing. Our server even brought us a refill on the nachos seeing how we inhaled our first bucket. (we have a guacamole problem) I had the mole enchilada and a jamaica- both delicious. The boyfriend got the lamb which made me slightly (very) jealous because it was bursting with flavor. In the end both our plates were amazing. I have to say again, service here was fantastic. I didn't feel rushed- our waitress was extremely patient explaining the menu and taking our orders. She was friendly and made small talk. She also accommodated our various payment forms, and double checked if we needed change.

Best Turkish food since my trip to Turkey. I fell in love with Mediterranean cuisine when I went to Eskeshir. Back in the states Mediterranean translates to Greek food and you miss the middle eastern influence. Well, this place has it. Don't go there for Greek food you may be disappointed, but for good lamb and baklava you gotta try it.

Hate to be one of the few not in love with this place but there it is. We ordered the steak and chicken tacos.  They weren't bad per se, just very ordinary.  Not spicy at all and wasn't in love with the tortilla.   I'm fully willing to say maybe we just got a bad batch.  We'll have to try it again.

This place is located in the East Village.  The food is incredible and authentic as it gets.  My favorite dish is the Pernil.  There's nothing more I enjoy than pork.  I always get the large portion because I find myself wanting more.  The Chicken stew is also delicious.  Breakfast is so filling and heavy, and absolutely delicious.  I've been here 2-3 times a day because I find it hits the spot.

So into pepe Rosso. Great no nonsense Italians with no nonsense pasta. It's not anything inspired, just well cooked classic dishes that satisfy the carb carving. To stay or to go. Solid gnocchi, rigatoni in pink sauce with mushrooms. Amazing fresh bread. No diet coke! No skim milk!

This wonderful pizzeria is the creation of indie filmmaker Ron Brown and Jon Greenberg, who previously worked at Paulie Gee's and, before that, the original Robicelli's. Perhaps it is not too surprising, then, that the pizza at Barboncino is remarkably similar to that of Paul Giannone. Even the Ferraro oven, imported directly from Naples, is the same as that of the popular Greenpoint pizzeria, just a bit smaller. This is all for the best, since these guys learned their pizza lessons well: The pie is thin, chewy, airy, and nicely spotted with char dots[1]; the tomato sauce is fresh and tangy; and the fiordilatte mozzarella[2] is as tasty as it is creamy. In fact, the Margherita pizza ($11) is such a beautifully balanced and light thing that I felt that I could easily eat five pies. The full bar that serves cocktails, nicely priced at just $10. It also has Dogfish Head 90 Min. IPA on tap, together with Brooklyn Chocolate Stout. The people behind Barboncino clearly put great care and a lot of effort in creating a dark, sexy ambiance that is also warm and welcoming. The two-level massive room sports lots of dark wood, exposed bricks, and great attention to details. The recently opened outdoor patio is more intimate. Barboncino is a great place to meet up with some friends, for a low-key date, or even to just enjoy a pizza and a beer by yourself at the bar[3]. Start with an appetizer: the Neapolitan Meatballs are just as good as an appetizer ($9) as they are as a pizza topping. The best part of the salumi board ($19) is the accompanying piece of pizza dough (or "pizza pane"; which also comes in a garlic version for $4) freshly baked in the oven. I cannot praise enough the fire roasted peppers with burrata ($12): the peppers are drizzled with extra virgin olive oil, capers, and parsley are sweet and juicy, and the burrata is wonderfully light and milky. In fact, this burrata is absolutely delicious! The pizza menu is fairly basic, if not particularly innovative. - The Eggplant and Zucchini ($13; tomatoes, red pepper flakes, fiordilatte, garlic, and extra virgin olive oil) is perhaps my favorite pie: very flavorful, with a nice earthiness to it. - The Cremini Mushrooms and Fennel Sausage ($17; fiordilatte, garlic, thyme, pecorino romano, and extra virgin olive oil) sounded better than what it tasted, and fell a bit flat in flavor. - Similarly underwhelming was the Artichoke and Smoked Pancetta ($17; fiordilatte, garlic, pecorino romano, and extra virgin olive oil). - Soppressata Piccante ($15; tomatoes, fiordilatte, garlic, oregano, and extra virgin olive oil) was solid. - The Neapolitan Meatballs ($15; fiordilatte, house-made meatballs, parmigiano reggiano, basil, and extra virgin olive oil) is perhaps the best pie on the menu. - The Arugula ($14; cherry tomatoes, fiordilatte, shaved parmigiano reggiano) was nice, light, and refreshing. The pizza is excellent by itself, but add prosciutto di parma if you want some extra flavor ($4): it's tasty and comes just slightly crisp on the edges. - I am generally suspicious of seafood-based pizza, but the Cherry Stone Clam pie ($17; fiordilatte, garlic, parsley butter, and extra virgin olive oil) was nothing short of wonderful, and transformed me into a believer/worshipper. - A potato and anchovies white pizza served as a special was excellent, and in fact it would later become part of the regular menu -albeit briefly. A potato and rosemary white pizza special, on the other hand, left me unimpressed. For dessert, ice cream comes from Il Laboratorio del Gelato, and it's fantastic (I recommend hazelnut and pistachio). A tiramisu' dessert special[4] was surprisingly light and fluffyly delicious; I highly recommend it. Despite some shortcomings with some the toppings, the pizza here is consistently good. If this is their starting point, Barboncino set the bar pretty high. A very solid 4.5 stars. ------------------------------ [1] Be aware that the charring is more substantial than at other places. [2] They use exclusively fiordilatte on their pizza. [3] I've done that several times, and got to know more about the history of the neighborhood from some of the local patrons that hang out at the bar. [4] Made by Enrico, a pizzaiolo who happens to be from Cagliari, Sardinia; the island where my family is from.
eating there since it opened great recent addition but takeout was not as good as sit down

Stopped in on a Monday night after a few beers and tried The 500 burger, which comes with lettuce, tomato, cheddar cheese, bacon and house sauce, on a big, rounded, picture-perfect bun. Spicy fries too. ($10.25 or so for both.) It was good, not remarkable. I have to admit, I prefer 5 Guys sloppy mess of a burger for the taste. Still, I devoured that 500 burger and did enjoy it. The fries were great. The place itself is small, with rap music playing, and there was only 1 other customer at 8:30 p.m. The staff was nice to me, a first timer, helping me through my confusion with the menu. (I did mention the few beers, right?) It took 5-7 minutes to get the burger. I liked sitting next to the window, watching the night foot traffic pass by on Sansom Street. Perhaps it's just the location, but it seemed every person who passed glanced in at me. Anyway, a nice experience overall.

I'm addicted to this place. Hopefully it's just a phase. But the more I eat it, the more I like it... I'm always thinking about how perfectly toasted the bread is and the delicious spicy mayo they put on it. When in doubt, go with the coconut tiger shrimp. Yum! Quick line, friendly service. I usually do take-out, but from my experience the seating area upstairs is small & cramped, but tolerable. My only problem with their sandwiches is I'm always hungry after just eating one, so don't expect one sandwich to fill you up completely unless you aren't a big eater.

Came here for Restaurant Week and was not at all impressed with food. We had the clams for appetizers and they have this garlicky bread crumbs on top that were super salty and made it hard to taste the reset of the dish. My companion had the tuna as an entree and it was just ok. I had the risotto and it was the best thing I tasted all night. Desserts were just ok. On a plus side service is very good and everyone from the hostess to waiters is very very nice.

Holy crap... this is the best restaurant in Brooklyn.  Such a comfortable atmosphere and some of the nicest people I have ever met on staff.  I live in Queens and have been just about everywhere in the city and this is by far one of my favorites.  If you haven't had a chance to check it out put it on your to do list!  xo

Vic has become my new favorite sushi place. It's cheap (two rolls for about 7$, three for 10$). It's good (the avocado roll makes me stop and say 'mmmm,' and I've heard similar noises about the fishy ones too). Plus, they're super friendly (we're always treated really well). It's a very small place, with only five seats at the sushi bar- this does, however, give you a great view of the sushi being made, which is a plus- something about how that chef rolls up the maki is just beautiful! You can dine in, but it's easy to just enjoy the show and go elsewhere, too. Just remember to tip before you go- they deserve it! And- AND- they're open until 10pm, and deliver, too! So much love.

I rarely get around to writing reviews due to my own forgetfulness, but had to make extra effort to express my opinion of this place. We ordered the Brussels, shrimp bun and miso soup with pork. All I can really say is that the richness of flavor blew my mind. Never had anything like it. Absolutely delicious and will make you seriously consider ordering seconds. Whether you're into this genre of food or not, you owe it to yourself to check this place out. The space itself was intimate, friendly and attentive staff. We were seated right away and were in and out in about 45 min. This was lunchtime on a Monday.

Came here for drinks with friends after dinner.  The cocktail menu did not disappoint.  I wish we had eaten here as well because the food also looks fabulous.  The owner, Nicole was greeting guests at the door, which made us feel extra special.   The atmosphere is amazing.  I loved the plastered walls, the colors and the general vibe. I tried the classic Pina Colada and it was delicious.  Charlie is in a neighborhood with a lot of excitement and it did not disappoint!

I have a simple and easy to use guide to describing how I feel about a given restaurant that I call "the French Fry Ratio". During a meal I simply try and keep track of how many fries are left on my plate vs. how much food I have eaten. Upon my last visit to Petisco I found, to my shock, that I ate my entire entree (Coconut crusted chicken sandwich, oh good God, you guys, seriously, oh my god, amazing) before touching a single french fry. THAT is quality food. Petisco is a small restaurant with intimate environs and a relaxed feel. Its specials and deserts are written on the mirrors rather than formal triple laminated card-stock and the wait staff is friendly and personable. The Food is out of this world. I've only been to Petisco three times, but each entree has exceeded my expectations. The extensive burger/sandwich menu seems to be the most popular (for good reason) but don't overlook their more formal fare- the honey glazed lamb chops were so good I briefly left my body and floated above myself, watching as I chewed the delectable morsels of lamb. I would go on, but frankly you are wasting your time reading this. Go, eat and be merry.

This location has been a french bistro in the area for decades, and this newly opened version at this corner spot still has the quaint feel, and friendly vibe of predeceding restaurants here. People in the west village come for a cozy glass of wine and excellent charcuterie, and nicely presented oyster. Joseph Leonard stresses simple preparations, which is hit or miss. The beef bourguignon was not as flavorful as you'd hope for, while the coq au vin was quite tasty. They do not take reservations and since there are all of 30 tables (perhaps), be prepared to wait and crowd in at the tiny bar. The service is accommodating and watching the staff in the kitchen prepare meals in the mouse-sized kitchen is entertaining. The experience here is worth the cramped quarters and mixed meal successes if you're in the area.

If you know what good sushi is, then you should avoid this place like the plague! I grew up in the area and I remember how good the sushi was under the original ownership. Imagine: sushi prepared by actual Japanese sushi chefs who knew their craft. Unheard of these days (outside of NYC & environs). Several years ago, the place changed hands, and the quality plummeted. Today, the "sushi" is made with sub-par fish by Chinese cooks who know nothing--and I mean Nothing--about Japanese cuisine. And as if this weren't enough reason to run away, the service is absolutely rude.

Best Italian restaurant!! Excellent food and amazing staff!! would recommend this restaurant  to anyone who loves a good Italian meal. Very nice atmosphere as well. The owner and manager made my whole family feel at home. Waiters and waitresses were awesome couldn't have asked for better service. Everything was perfect...oh and can't forget the sangria! Red, white and blue all amazing!
Really enjoyed their hummus salad...big and filling!

From the made-wrong martini that was spilled in my lap to the poorly- prepared food, this place should be put out of it's misery. Bad service, a bartender who didn't know what a Manhattan was, and  poorly-presented food that lacked flavor, this is a train-wreck.

I was really excited to go to Yakatori Boy. I have heard many people talk about it as ...THE PLACE to go to for Karaoke, but I couldn't have been more disappointed. I made a reservation for a private room over a week in advance and when I got there they still made us wait 20 minutes before we could even get in the room. The host staff was pretty rude when I questioned why the room wasn't ready. Once we were in the room our TV didn't work and it probably took at least another 20 minutes for someone to come and pretend to help us fix it. The song selection was awful. No one ever came in to take a drink order for anyone and they were very quick to drop the bill (with gratuity already added) and kick us out. Not a fan at all. Not going back.
They have a great vodka sauce pizza, the best part is the thin crispy crust. have yet to try the pastas
Love this place. Vegetarian friendly, delicious food, and the staff is great. Delivery is fast and everything is priced appropriately.

I noticed that I only gave Geronimo 4 stars before and I really don't know what I was thinking. This place rocks 5 stars without breaking a sweat. Also loved Hell Night, a special spicy food lover's night that they do once a month.
Ok, I would have given this place 5 stars for their great food and the fact it's BYOB.  4 stars because I went there last night and a sign on the door said it was closed by the Health Department :(

Been here twice for happy hour on Fridays. The nachos are fantastic, 5 stars, can't be beat. The pitchers of margaritas are tasty and, at $15, not a bad price, but are FILLED to the brim with ice. I'd guess there's maybe 2-3 shots of tequila in the entire pitcher, given the ice/marg mix ratio. If it weren't for that - oh, and the fact that you have to walk up a million stairs to use the bathroom - this place would be an easy 4, maybe even possible 5 star candidate. But, overall, a good place for groups for happy hour. And, again, the nachos are great!

DELISH! Wasn't sure how it was going to be because when we called to make a reservation, the person on the phone laughed because no one does that. My family of four got enough food for about eight people, and we enjoyed every bit of it. From the Bacon Cakes to the Jalapeno Tots to the Special Artichoke Burrito, it was all scrumptious. Our waitress Susan had a dry sense of humor which was entertaining, although I think she was more entertained by us. I would definitely go back the next time I'm in Philadelphia!

Came for lunch on Saturday at noon. Place was pretty busy but we got seated right away. Banchan wasn't the greatest, all we ended up really eating was just the kimchi. The yellow croaker is always a great start though. For an appetizer we decided on the Seafood pancake (Haemul pa jeun) which was probably the best I've ever had with their sauce. We wanted to get the lunch special of the soondabu with some kbbq, but it wasn't available on the weekends. So we got an order of the Kalbi and I got a beef soondabu medium spicy. The kalbi was okay, I've definitely had better. The soondabu tasted extremely weird. It had like a charcoal taste to it, very unappetizing. Decided to pack it up and take it home to finish it off for dinner, when i had it for dinner the taste was gone so it was probably the bowl that they served it in. Service was friendly but a little slow, pretty expensive for what we got, but the seafood pancake was amazing!

Went here for the lobster...food was good! Had twin 1 lb.lobsters and my husband had the 1 1/2 lb. It was cooked well and served with some nice sides. Better than buying, cooking and eating at home when you are craving some end of summer lobster. Service was nice, mellow. Room for improvement...no one acknowledges that you are leaving....thanks for coming would have been nice to hear from one of the several people standing near the door.
I been to many Thai  restaurants!!! By far this is my FAVORITE! Excellent food, good prices, and great service! #1 pad Thai in New Jersey.

Actually 2 1/2 stars Nigiri sushi was very mediocre..soggy tuna,  price was not.  Udon was o.k. Tempura was good. If I had a choice of eating here again, I'd wait until I was somewhere that I had more confidence in a good result, sushi wise. Service was attentive.

This place is pretty good. I got the og bao little hard to eat but really delicious. The pork was cooked perfectly. Also got the hangover fries, good flavor. I added some jalapeño to mine and it was perfect. I was really surprised by the bubble tea. Usually restaurants that offer bubble tea have a bad quality tea, but the bubble tea here is solid. Get the mango stars!!!

I was there with a friend last month! We were by the area and we wanted to eat something really good, I Yelped my mobile and I found PURE! At the beginning I was not sure about following all the reviews and going there but I didn´t think to much..We jumped into a cab and once we arrived we realized we did our best decision! Food was really good, oh my good I loved the dumplings!! Believe me you have to try them! 100% recommended. It´s a food for the soul.   Don´t forget to drink a Singha Beer!

start your review...I recently attended a spa party for breast cancer survivors and was a nominated guest.  Upon arrival I felt very welcome and comfortable. the services were excellent and I had a wonderful time. I also visited on a another time for a facial I needed some pampering while under going treatment.  the employees are all so very nice and comforting.  For me this is the place to go for peace, quiet, relaxation and to collect my thoughts.
Service is terrible.  They mostly ignore you.  Food is on par with an okay diner.  Ice cream is pretty darn good.  Stick to ice cream.

Yum yum yum. Found this place on yelp and it didn't disappoint. A very unique selection of menu items (and your typical American Chinese staples if you aren't as adventurous) and decent service. The Kung pao chicken was especially good as was the stir-fried pork with long peppers. Two thumbs up.

My friend Nikki & I "I'm hungry." "I'm starving. Where do you want to eat?" "I've been thinking about Oasis all day!" "OASIS, ALL DAY EVERYDAY." I hate when they run out of lentil soup 3 o'clock in the morning when I've been drinking wine all night. Hey guys, make an extra bucket, I'll take it.
Any plate with eggs are good. The eggs are rich and soft, $14 fix menu is a bargain.
Best burger ever.  Like an In 'N Out burger on steroids.  The duck fat fries are great too.

I want to like you Green Eggs Cafe, I really do.  But each time I  visit, things seems to go further down hill.  I like your convenience (a few blocks away).  I like your design and atmosphere (lots of room, bright, outdoor seating). But, the kinks i What I don't like is the poor service (our weekend visit had one person at our table waiting an extra 20 minutes for their entree, constantly tracking down servers for sugar, salt and pepper, ketchup, etc.). What I don't like is the inconsistent food ( a cold biscuit on top of my kitchen sink, multiple chicken bones in the chicken salad sandwich, under-cooked fries, over-cooked eggs and bread that was green and not in a good way). Green Eggs, please get some more competent servers, more consistency with what is coming out of the kitchen and how about breaking down and putting some sugar, salt and pepper, ketchup, and hot sauce on the table so I don't have to spend 15 minutes tracking down a server to get a small spoonful. I promise I won't steal it.   And come on....no one charges for ice tea refills, unless you are at a bar.  As summer approaches how about keeping a pitcher of ice tea ready for those free refills.  Can you really be saving/making that much money on these items?   I sure hope things start to improve soon instead of continuing to slide.

Tinto 114 S 20th St, Philadelphia, PA 19103 (215) 665-9150 While it is normally my want to display a photo of the outside of the building, this photo says everything I want to say about Tinto: sophisticated, intimate, Basque, cozy and sultry. Basque of course refers to the region of North Central Spain that straddles the area between north central Spain and south western France.  This tapas restaurant serves to reflect this fusion and Chef Jose Garces certainly does a marvelous job fusing all the best of France and Spain.  Coincidentally, Tinto is Spanish for "stained" and "red" as in red wine, so the hundreds of bottles of wine throughout the restaurant is of course no surprise. The restaurant is an intimate setting with an open style kitchen (see back of this photo) with a luxurious bar with small rectangular wooden shelves lined with hundreds of wine bottles. It is lit with gorgeous incandescent lighting which casts a golden glow over everything--the perfect date spot. Without further adieu, allow me to present the culinary masterpiece that is Tinto. Since this blog is titled, Fine Food, Good Drinks, I can't help but mention the sangria I chose to accompany my meal. Sangria is a typical beverage from Spain and Portugal. It normally consists of wine, chopped fruit, a sweetener, and a small amount of added brandy. Chopped fruit can include orange, lemon, lime, apple, peach, melon, berries, pineapple, grape, kiwifruit and mango. A sweetener such as honey, sugar, syrup, or orange juice is added. Pintxos: OLIVES House Marinated Mixed Olives.  Pintxos appears at the top of the Tinto menu, and I learned it was the Spanish word for "tapas".  The marinated olives were delicious and arguably one of the best dishes of the evening.  With so many to choose from there was not a clear winner in my book, however. ALMONDS: House Smoked Marcona Almonds. Someone call the fire department because these almonds were smokin'. Well, not literally, but they were smoked and the flavorful sea salt, almonds and wooden smokey taste made this appetizer a delight to the palate. Marcona almonds, the "Queen of Almonds," are imported from Spain. Marcona almonds are prized for being more tender, sweet, and delicate than regular almonds, with a nice buttery flavor that is due to their high oil and moisture content. GAZPACHO Goat Cheese Mousse, Strawberry, Rhubarb, Crispy Serrano. Jamón serrano is a type of jamón (dry-cured Spanish ham), which is generally served in thin slices, or occasionally diced.  Gazpacho is a chilled soup and this particular variety was fruity, summery tasting, sweet and creamy due to the goat cheese.  The Serrano ham was a nice accouterment with the salty cured meat balancing the sweetness of the fruit and cheese.  The rhubarb was an interesting addition to the dish, as I have never had a gazpacho served with it before. Rhubarb is a perennial vegetable, though it is generally used as a fruit in desserts and jams. You only eat the stalks, which have a rich tart flavor. ARUGULA Serrano Ham, Mission Figs, Fried Goat Cheese, Spiced Almonds, Sevilla Orange Vinaigrette.  Probably the most interesting addition to the arugula salad here was the addition of the balls of fried goat cheese.  Absolutely delicious.  The Orange vinaigrette wasn't half bad either. Certainly cleaned the plate here. DIVER SCALLOPS Quince, Uni Emulsion, Parsnip, Crispy Serrano.  You can see the little chunks of serrano ham mixed in with the greens.  The little yellow chunks are the quince, a yellow fruit similar to the apple. Quince is a small deciduous tree that bears a pome fruit, similar in appearance to a pear, and bright golden-yellow when mature.  The scallops can be dipped in the vanilla parsnip puree- which was amazingly creamy and sweet. ORGANIC CHICKEN Brussels Sprouts, Chorizo, Fingerling Potatoes, Herb Jus.  The chicken was fantastic, tender, sweet, loved the brussel sprouts.  The herb jus was rich and sweet. Postre (Dessert): Gateau Basque.
